revision.text:
{{other people}} {{Use mdy dates|date=December 2017}}
{{Infobox person | name = George Papadopoulos | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = George Demetrios Papadopoulos | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1987|08|19}}<ref name=ctpath>{{Cite news|url=https://chicago.suntimes.com/news/chicagoans-path-from-trump-campaign-to-conviction-to-cooperation/|date=October 30, 2017|title=Chicagoan’s path from Trump campaign to conviction to cooperation|work=Chicago Sun-Times|access-date=October 31, 2017|first1=Lynn |last1=Sweet |first2=Dan|last2= Mihalopoulos |first3=Jon |last3=Seidel}}</ref> | birth_place = [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | other_names = | citizenship = United States and Greece | education = {{unbulleted list|[[Niles West High School]]|[[DePaul University]] (BA)|[[University College London]] (MSc)<ref name="CT"/>}} | criminal_charge = [[Making false statements]] | criminal_penalty = {{ubl|14 days in federal prison|$9,500 fine|200 hours of community service|1 year of [[United States federal probation and supervised release|supervised release]]<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/ex-trump-campaign-adviser-george-papadopoulos-sentenced-to-14-days-in-prison-1536353828 |title=Ex-Trump Campaign Adviser George Papadopoulos Sentenced to 14 Days In Prison |last=Viswanatha |first=Aruna |date=2018-09-07 |work=Wall Street Journal |access-date=2018-09-07 |language=en-US |issn=0099-9660}}</ref>}} | spouse = {{marriage|Simona Mangiante|March 2, 2018}} | criminal_status = Serving sentence<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-46347887/ |title=George Papadopoulos: Ex-Trump adviser goes to prison |last=Heath |first=Brad |date=November 26, 2018 |work=USA TODAY |access-date=November 26, 2018 |language=en}}</ref> | children = | occupation = | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = | partner = }} '''George Demetrios Papadopoulos'''<ref name="CT">{{cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/breaking/ct-met-george-papadopoulos-russian-investigation-20171102-story.html|title=Week after bombshell, George Papadopoulos largely remains a mystery man|work=Chicago Tribune|date=November 7, 2017|author=Meisner, Jason; O'Connell, Patrick M.}}</ref> ({{IPAc-en|ˌ|p|æ|p|ə|ˈ|d|ɒ|p|ə|l|ɒ|s}}; born August 19, 1987) is a former member of the foreign policy advisory panel to [[Donald Trump]]'s [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 presidential campaign]]. On October 5, 2017, Papadopoulos [[plea]]ded guilty to [[making false statements]] to [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] agents about the timing and the possible significance of his contacts in 2016 relating to U.S.-Russia relations and the Donald Trump presidential campaign.
==Early life and education== George Papadopoulos was born August 19, 1987 at [[Swedish Covenant Hospital]]<ref name=ctpath/> in Chicago, Illinois,<ref name="WhoIsUSAToday">{{Cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/onpolitics/2017/10/30/who-former-trump-campaign-aide-george-papadopoulos/814546001/|title=Who is former Trump campaign aide George Papadopoulos?|work=USA Today|access-date=November 1, 2017|language=en}}</ref> to Greek immigrants<ref name=ctpath/><ref name=short>{{cite news | work = Time | url = http://time.com/5002832/george-papadopoulos-guilty-plea-indictment/ |first=Haley Sweetland |last= Edwards| title = The Short, Happy Political Career of George Papdopoulos | accessdate = October 31, 2017 | date= October 30, 2017}}</ref> originally from [[Thessaloniki]].<ref name="GreekReporter">{{cite web|url=http://usa.greekreporter.com/2017/10/31/george-papadopoulos-the-greek-american-who-wanted-attention/|title=George Papadopoulos: The Greek-American Who Wanted Attention|publisher=Greek USA Reporter|date=October 31, 2017|author=Kokkinidis, Tasos}}</ref> His father, Antonis, was heavily involved in the local politics of the Greek-American community<ref name="GreekReporter"/> and the former president of the Pan-Macedonian Union of the United States.<ref name="GreekReporter"/> His mother, Kate (Kiki), was born in Greece and listed her hometown on her son’s birth certificate as [[Worcester, Massachusetts]].<ref name="CT"/> For years he lived at a large house on the corner of a tree-lined street<ref name="CT"/> in [[Lincolnwood, Illinois]]<ref name=ctpath /> and graduated from [[Niles West High School]] in [[Skokie, Illinois]], in 2005. He graduated with a [[bachelor's degree|bachelor's of arts degree]] in political science from [[DePaul University]] in 2009.<ref name="CT"/><ref>{{cite news |work = Chicago Tribune | date = October 30, 2017 | accessdate = October 30, 2017 | last= Skiba | first= Katherine | url = http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/politics/ct-met-chicago-russia-papadopoulos-20171030-story.html | title= Former Trump campaign adviser, DePaul alum from Chicago pleads guilty to lying to FBI}}</ref> He went on to earn an [[Master of Science|MSc]] degree in [[Security Studies]] in 2010 at [[University College London]].<ref name="CT"/><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.linkedin.com/in/gpapadopoulos7|title=LinkedIn: George Papadopoulos|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> He speaks [[Arabic]], [[English language|English]], [[French language|French]] and [[Greek language|Greek]].<ref name="WhoIsUSAToday"/>
==Early career== Papadopoulos was an unpaid intern at the [[Hudson Institute]] from 2011 to 2015 specializing in the eastern Mediterranean and later worked as a contract research assistant to a senior fellow at the institute.<ref name=short/><ref name=contacts>{{cite news|last1=De Young|first1=Karen |title=GOP foreign policy elites don’t know whether they’ll serve if Trump is president|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/gop-foreign-policy-elite-doesnt-know-whether-theyll-serve-if-trump-is-president/2016/04/15/5cd1e87c-0016-11e6-b823-707c79ce3504_story.html |accessdate=October 30, 2017|work=The Washington Post|date=April 15, 2016}}</ref>
He described himself as an "oil, gas, and policy consultant" on his [[LinkedIn]] page.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/10/30/politics/who-is-george-papadopoulos/index.html|title=Who is George Papadopoulos?|last1=Herb|first1=Jeremy|last2=Cohen|first2=Marshall|date=October 30, 2017|publisher=CNN|accessdate=October 31, 2017}}</ref> In 2014, Papadopoulos authored [[op-ed]] pieces in Israeli publications. In one, published in the ''[[Arutz Sheva]]'', Papadopoulos argued that the U.S. should focus on its "stalwart allies" [[Israel]], [[Greece]], and [[Cyprus]] to "contain the newly emergent Russian fleet"; in another, published in ''[[Ha'aretz]]'', he contended that Israel should exploit its natural gas resources in partnership with Cyprus and Greece rather than [[Turkey]].<ref name=haaretz>{{cite news |url =https://www.haaretz.com/us-news/1.819951 | date= October 30, 2017 | accessdate = October 30, 2017 | title =Trump Campaign Adviser Who Pled Guilty to Lying to FBI Has Surprising Ties to Israeli Settlers | first1=Amir | last1= Tibon | first2= Alison Kaplan | last2= Sommer | work = Haaretz}}</ref> He directed an international energy center at the London Centre of International Law Practice.<ref name="ModelUN">{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/checkpoint/wp/2016/03/21/meet-the-men-shaping-donald-trumps-foreign-policy-views/|title=One of Trump’s foreign policy advisers is a 2009 college grad who lists Model UN as a credential|last=Ryan|first=Missy|date=March 22, 2016|work=The Washington Post|access-date=November 1, 2017|last2=Mufson|first2=Steven|issn=0190-8286}}</ref>
In September of 2015 Papadopoulos left the Hudson Institute and joined Energy Stream, a London energy consultancy, as an oil and gas consultant for four months before joining Ben Carson's Presidential campaign.<ref>NBC News, "Who Is George Papadopoulos? Energy Expert and Junior Trump Staffer Sought to Be Russia Power Broker by Alex Johnson," Oct.30.2017, Updated Oct.31.2017. https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/who-george-papadopoulos-energy-expert-junior-trump-staffer-sought-be-n815826</ref>
Beginning in December 2015, Papadopoulos served on the National Security and Foreign Policy Advisory Committee for [[Ben Carson]]'s campaign for the 2016 Republican presidential nomination.<ref>{{cite press release| url=http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/index.php?pid=111655 | publisher=The American Presidency Project | accessdate=October 30, 2017 | date=December 8, 2015| title= Dr. Ben Carson Announces Foreign Policy Advisers }}</ref> He left the Carson campaign in February 2016.<ref name=short/> Following his indictment, he was described by ''[[HuffPost]]'' as "a little-known, little-qualified 30-year-old."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/george-papadopoulos-big-deal_us_59f72de7e4b077d8dfcb085b|title=Robert Mueller Flipped A Trump Campaign Adviser. That's Bad News For The White House.|first1=Ryan J.|last1=Reilly|first2=Amanda|last2=Terkel|date=October 30, 2017|work=HuffPost}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/31/business/wrong-george-papadopoulos-twitter.html|title=He’s George Papadopoulos, Just Not That George Papadopoulos|first=Zach|last=Wichter|date=October 31, 2017|work=The New York Times}}</ref>
== Involvement in Donald Trump's presidential campaign == In late 2015, Papadopoulos sent his resumé to the [[Ben Carson]] presidential campaign, which hired him as a foreign policy adviser for three months, December 2015 through February 2016.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://time.com/5002832/george-papadopoulos-guilty-plea-indictment/|title=The Short, Happy Political Career of George Papadopoulos|last=Edwards|first=Haley Sweetland|date=October 31, 2017|work=Time|accessdate=11 September 2018}}</ref> According to court records, Papadopoulos joined Trump's foreign policy adviser team as a volunteer adviser in early March 2016. [[Sam Clovis]], who at the time was national co-chairman of Donald Trump's campaign team, approved him as an adviser. In his campaign job interview on March 6, Clovis allegedly told Papadopoulos that one of the campaign's foreign policy priorities was to improve U.S.-Russia relations, though Clovis later denied saying that.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-russia-clovis/former-trump-campaign-adviser-denies-encouraging-aide-on-russia-dealings-idUSKBN1D02MT|title=Former Trump campaign adviser denies encouraging aide on Russia dealings|last1=Lynch|first1=Sarah N.|last2=Hosenball|first2=Mark|date=October 31, 2017|agency=Reuters|accessdate=November 2, 2017}}</ref> Donald Trump announced Papadopoulos as one of his campaign's foreign policy advisers on March 21, 2016, in an interview with the editorial board of ''[[The Washington Post]]''.<ref name="ModelUN"/> Trump, reading from a list, said: "He’s an energy and oil consultant, excellent guy".<ref name=short/>
Employed at that time with the [[London Centre of International Law Practice]] (LCILP), Papadopoulos returned to London and, on March 14, 2016, was part of an LCILP visiting delegation to the [[Link Campus University]] in Rome. There he met [[Joseph Mifsud]],<ref>Smith, Lee. "The Maltese Phantom of Russiagate", Real Clear Investiagations, May 30, 2018</ref> who was at the time a teacher at the [[University of Stirling]] in Scotland; Mifsud, who was born in Malta, had connections to high-ranking Russian officials.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.newsweek.com/george-papadopoulos-who-joseph-mifsud-professor-697441|title=Who is Joseph Mifsud, the professor in the George Papadopoulos investigation?|last=Kutner|first=Max|date=October 31, 2017|work=Newsweek|accessdate=October 31, 2017}}</ref><ref name="missing">{{cite news|url=https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/7213113/joseph-mifsud-missing-dead-trump-russia-probe/|title=Professor accused of being link between Donald Trump and Vladimir Putin ‘missing and may be DEAD’|last=Hodge|first=Mark|date=September 9, 2018|work=The Sun|accessdate=9 September 2018}}</ref> On March 24, Papadopoulos met with Mifsud in London, who brought along with him a Russian woman, Olga Polonskaya, whom Mifsud falsely identified as Putin's niece.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/10/30/politics/who-is-george-papadopoulos/index.html|title=Who is George Papadopoulos?|first1=Jeremy|last1=Herb|first2=Marshall|last2=Cohen|publisher=CNN|access-date=October 31, 2017}}</ref><ref name=drinks/> On April 26, at a breakfast meeting at the Andaz London Liverpool Street hotel, Mifsud told Papadopoulos that he had information that the Russians have "dirt" on [[Hillary Clinton]] in the form of thousands of e-mails.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-43488581|title=Joseph Mifsud: The mystery professor behind Trump Russia inquiry|last1=Sweeney|first1=John|last2=Bowen|first2=Innes|date=March 21, 2018|work=BBC News|accessdate=11 September 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/ct-mueller-papadopoulos-russia-probe-20180817-story.html|title=Mueller says George Papadopoulos lied during Russia probe|last1=Hsu|first1=Spencer S.|last2=Helderman|first2=Rosalind S.|date=August 18, 2018|work=The Washington Post|publisher=Chicago Tribune|accessdate=11 September 2018}}</ref> (In September 2018, a court filing said that Mifsud was "missing", had not been heard from in months, and "may be deceased".<ref name = "missing"/>)
From March to August 2016, Papadopoulos "was identified as having contacts with senior members of the Trump campaign on at least a dozen occasions."<ref name="FactCheck"/> Papadopoulos's wife, then his fiancée, said in 2017 that his job in the campaign was to set up meetings with foreign leaders and that he had been in regular contact with high-ranking campaign officials.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/george-papadopoulos-fiance-trump-fbi-simona-magiante-2017-12|title=Fiancée of Trump campaign official who lied to FBI says he was 'constantly in touch' with top Trump officials|publisher=[[Business Insider]]|language=en}}</ref> Papadopoulos sent emails concerning meeting with Putin to at least seven campaign officials. Clovis, as Trump national campaign co-chairman, encouraged Papadopoulos to fly to Russia to meet with agents of the [[Russian Foreign Ministry]], after Papadopoulos had been told that Russia had "dirt" on Clinton it wanted to share with Trump's campaign.<ref name="who's who">{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/whos-who-in-the-george-papadopoulos-court-documents/2017/10/30/e131158c-bdb3-11e7-97d9-bdab5a0ab381_story.html |title=Who’s who in the George Papadopoulos court documents |first=Rosalind S. |last=Helderman |work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=October 30, 2017}}</ref><ref name=NBCNewsPlea>{{cite news|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/trump-campaign-adviser-george-papadopoulos-pleads-guilty-lying-n815596 |title=Secret Guilty Plea of Ex-Trump Campaign Adviser George Papadopoulos Reveals Russian Ties |author= Tom Winter and Tracy Connor |publisher= [[NBC News]] | date=October 30, 2017 | accessdate=October 30, 2017}}</ref><ref name=NYTGuilty>{{cite news |first1=Matt |last1=Apuzzo | first2= Michael S. |last2=Schmidt |authorlink1=Matt Apuzzo |authorlink2=Michael S. Schmidt |title=Trump Campaign Adviser Met With Russian to Discuss ‘Dirt’ on Clinton|work=The New York Times |date=October 30, 2017 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/30/us/politics/george-papadopoulos-russia.html }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first1=Matt|last1=Apuzzo|authorlink1=Matt Apuzzo|first2=Adam|last2=Goldman|authorlink2=Adam Goldman|first3=Michael S.|last3=Schmidt|authorlink3=Michael S. Schmidt|first4=Matthew|last4=Rosenberg|authorlink4=Matthew Rosenberg|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/30/us/politics/paul-manafort-indicted.html|title=Former Trump Aides Charged as Prosecutors Reveal New Campaign Ties With Russia|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=October 30, 2017|accessdate=October 30, 2017}}</ref> This occurred after public knowledge that Clinton had deleted thousands of her emails, but before there was public knowledge of the [[Democratic National Committee cyber attacks|hack of Democratic National Committee]] and of [[John Podesta]]'s [[Podesta emails|emails]], the latter two of which U.S. intelligence agencies believe were carried out by Russia.<ref name="KnewofOutreach">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-campaign-adviser-pleaded-guilty-to-lying-about-russian-contacts/2017/10/30/d525e712-bd7d-11e7-97d9-bdab5a0ab381_story.html |work= The Washington Post | accessdate= October 30, 2017 | date=October 30, 2017| title=Top campaign officials knew of Trump adviser’s outreach to Russia|first1= Rosalind S. |last1=Helderman |first2= Tom |last2=Hamburger}}</ref>
On or about May 10, 2016, at London’s Kensington Wine Rooms, Papadopoulos told the top Australian diplomat to the United Kingdom, [[Alexander Downer]], that Russia was in possession of emails relating to Clinton. In July, after the DNC hacking had become known, the Australians told U.S. authorities about Papadopoulos's comment, leading the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] to open a [[counterintelligence]] investigation into the [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|Donald Trump presidential campaign]] on July 31, 2016.<ref name=drinks>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/30/us/politics/how-fbi-russia-investigation-began-george-papadopoulos.html|title=How the Russia Inquiry Began: A Campaign Aide, Drinks and Talk of Political Dirt|last=LaFraniere|first=Sharon|date=December 30, 2017|work=The New York Times|access-date=December 30, 2017|last2=Mazzetti|first2=Mark|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331|last3=Apuzzo|first3=Matt}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/federal-politics/political-news/joe-hockey-discussed-downers-russia-revelations-with-fbi-20180101-h0c58c.html|title=Joe Hockey discussed Alexander Downer's Russia revelations with FBI|last=Wroe|first=David|date=January 2, 2018|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|access-date=January 2, 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}}</ref>
Papadopoulos later said that he had told the Greek Foreign Minister, Nikos Kotzias, during a meeting in late May 2016, that the Russians had Clinton-related emails. He said his "biggest regret" was not immediately reporting Mifsud's comment to U.S. intelligence, and the "stupidest thing I did was actually gossiping about it with foreign diplomats".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/07/us/politics/george-papadopoulos-interview-trump.html|title=Excerpts From the New York Times Interview With George Papadopoulos|date=September 7, 2018|work=The New York Times|accessdate=7 September 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.thenationalherald.com/212864/papadopoulos-told-kotzias-that-the-russians-had-hillarys-emails/|title=Papadopoulos Told Kotzias that the Russians Had Hillary’s Emails|date=September 12, 2018|work=The National Herald|accessdate=13 September 2018}}</ref>
Between March and September 2016, Papadopoulos made at least six requests for Trump or representatives of his campaign to meet in Russia with Russian politicians. In May, campaign chairman [[Paul Manafort]] forwarded one such request to his deputy [[Rick Gates (political consultant)|Rick Gates]], saying "We need someone to communicate that [Trump] is not doing these trips. It should be someone low-level in the campaign so as not to send any signal." Gates delegated the task to the campaign's correspondence coordinator, referring to him as "the person responding to all mail of non-importance."<ref name=NBCNewsPlea/><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-campaign-emails-show-aides-repeated-efforts-to-set-up-russia-meetings/2017/08/14/54d08da6-7dc2-11e7-83c7-5bd5460f0d7e_story.html|title=Trump campaign emails show aide's repeated efforts to set up Russia meetings|last1=Hamburger|first1=Tom|last2=Leonnig|first2=Carol D.|authorlink2=Carol D. Leonnig|last3=Helderman|first3=Rosalind S.|date=August 14, 2017|work=The Washington Post|access-date=August 15, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/trump-adviser-made-repeated-attempts-set-russia-meeting-article-1.3411305|title=Trump campaign adviser made repeated attempts to set up meeting with Russia: report|last=Brennan|first=Christopher|date=August 14, 2017|website=Daily News|location=New York|access-date=August 15, 2017}}</ref>
In an interview about [[Russia–United States relations]] with [[Interfax]] in September 2016, Papadopoulos said that [[Barack Obama]] had failed to follow through on his promises to cooperate with Russia, and asserted that the U.S. had made insufficient joint efforts with Russia against terrorism.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.interfax.com/interview.asp?id=704556|title=George Papadopoulos: Sanctions have done little more than to turn Russia towards China|last=Baygarova|first=Ksenia|date=September 30, 2016|agency=Interfax|access-date=August 15, 2017}}</ref> As foreign policy adviser during Trump's campaign, Papadopoulos helped set up a New York meeting between Trump and [[Abdel Fattah el-Sisi]], the Egyptian president.<ref name=drinks/> On January 20, 2017, just hours before Trump was going to be inaugurated, Papadopoulos and incoming [[White House Chief of Staff]] [[Reince Priebus]] met with [[Minister for National Defence (Greece)|Greek Defense Minister]] [[Panos Kammenos]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Kammenos ‘confident of close cooperation’ with Trump administration|url=http://www.ekathimerini.com/215454/article/ekathimerini/news/kammenos-confident-of-close-cooperation-with-trump-administration|publisher=''Kathimerini''|accessdate=November 1, 2017|date=January 20, 2017}}</ref> On January 22, 2017, shortly following Trump's inauguration as President, Papadopoulos met with the head of Israel's [[Shomron Regional Council]], [[Yossi Dagan]], in Washington D.C. Papadopoulos was reported to have communicated to Dagan the Trump administration's desire to work closely with Israel on the question of [[Israeli settlement|Israel’s West Bank settlements]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.jpost.com/Arab-Israeli-Conflict/Trump-Advisor-we-look-forward-to-new-ties-with-Judea-and-Samaria-479282|title=Trump advisor: ‘We look forward to new ties with Judea and Samaria’|publisher=The Jerusalem Post|date=January 22, 2017}}</ref> <ref name=haaretz/><ref name=Who>{{Cite web|url=http://www.newsweek.com/who-george-papadopoulos-trump-adviser-russia-650716|title=Who is George Papadopoulos, the Trump Campaign Adviser Who Suggested a Meeting with Russian Leaders?|last=Kutner|first=Max|date=August 14, 2017|website=Newsweek|access-date=August 15, 2017}}</ref>
Senator [[Richard Burr]], the chair of the [[United States Senate Select Committee on Intelligence|Senate Intelligence Committee]] that is investigating [[Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections]], said in October 2017 that the panel was interested in Papadopoulos because he had sent e-mails attempting to set up meetings between Trump and Putin.<ref name="silva20oct">{{cite news|last1=Silva |first1=Christianna |title=Russia Update: Senate investigators consider meeting with Trump campaign official, George Papadopoulos |url=http://www.newsweek.com/russia-update-senate-investigators-consider-meeting-george-papadopoulos-trump-690000|accessdate=October 21, 2017|work=[[Newsweek]] |date=October 20, 2017 |language=en}}</ref> The recipients of emails about outreach to the Russian government reportedly were Clovis, [[Corey Lewandowski]], Manafort, Gates, representative of the Russian Ministry of Foreign Affairs Ivan Timofeev, and others.<ref name="who's who" />
In 2018 his wife predicted that Papadopoulos's role in the [[Special Counsel investigation (2017–present)|Russia investigation]] would be similar to that of [[John Dean]] of the [[Watergate scandal]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Helderman|first1=Rosalind S.|title=George Papadopoulos is the ‘John Dean’ of the Russia investigation, his fiancee says|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/george-papadopoulos-is-the-john-dean-of-the-russia-investigation-his-fiancee-says/2018/01/22/8e47b016-ff4d-11e7-9d31-d72cf78dbeee_story.html|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=January 22, 2018}}</ref> Democrats on the [[United States House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence]] later arranged for her to testify before the committee, but the plans fell through when the Republican majority refused to reimburse her for travel expenses from [[Chicago]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/07/11/george-papadopoulos-wife-house-intelligence-710966 |publisher=[[Politico]]|title=Papadopoulos’ wife won’t testify before House Intelligence members |first=Kyle |last=Cheney |date=July 11, 2018}}</ref>
== Arrest and guilty plea == [[File:Statement of the offense.filed.pdf|thumb|The Statement of Facts of Guilt, filed October 5, 2017, and unsealed October 30, 2017, showing the facts admitted by Papadopoulos as part of his guilty plea]]{{Main|2017 Special Counsel investigation}}
Papadopoulos was interviewed by FBI agents on January 27, 2017, regarding any Trump campaign connections with Russia. After the interrogation, Papadopoulos deactivated his [[Facebook]] account, which contained correspondences with Russians, and created a new account.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/future_tense/2017/10/30/george_papadopoulos_charged_by_robert_mueller_was_suspiciously_bad_at_facebook.html |title=The Trump Campaign Adviser Who Pleaded Guilty Was Very Bad at Facebook |first=April |last=Glaser |date=October 30, 2017 |access-date=October 31, 2017 |work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]}}</ref> Papadopoulos was arrested at [[Washington Dulles International Airport|Washington-Dulles International Airport]] on July 27, 2017, and detained overnight for his arraignment the following day. He has since been cooperating with Special Counsel [[Robert Mueller]] in [[2017 Special Counsel investigation|his investigation]].<ref name=NYTGuilty/>
On October 5, 2017, Papadopoulos pleaded guilty in the [[United States District Court for the District of Columbia|U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia]] to [[making false statements]] to FBI agents relating to contacts he had with agents of the Russian government while working for the Trump campaign.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.justice.gov/file/1007341/download|title=Plea Offer and Defendant's Acceptance|work=United States v. George Papadopoulos|date=October 5, 2017|publisher=United States Department of Justice|dead-url=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.justice.gov/file/1007346/download|title=Statement of Facts of Guilt|work=United States v. George Papadopoulos|publisher=United States Department of Justice|date=October 5, 2017|dead-url=}}</ref> The guilty plea was part of a [[plea bargain]] reflecting his cooperation with the Mueller investigation.<ref name=NYTGuilty/> Papadopoulos's arrest and guilty plea became public on October 30, 2017, when court documents showing the guilty plea were [[Under seal|unsealed]].<ref>{{cite web |first=Joseph |last=Tanfani |url=http://www.latimes.com/politics/washington/la-na-pol-essential-washington-updates-former-trump-campaign-aide-george-1509374196-htmlstory.html |title=Former Trump campaign aide George Papadopoulos pleads guilty to lying to the FBI agents in Mueller probe |work=Los Angeles Times |date=October 30, 2017}}</ref> Following his guilty plea, Trump described Papadopoulos as a "young, low level volunteer named George, who has already proven to be a liar" and said few people in his campaign had heard about Papadopoulos.<ref>{{cite news|author=Peter Baker|title=Trump Belittles George Papadopoulos as 'Low Level' Adviser|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/31/us/politics/trump-manafort-papadopoulos-mueller.html|newspaper=New York Times|date=October 31, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = http://edition.cnn.com/2017/10/31/politics/donald-trump-george-papadopoulos/index.html | accessdate = October 31, 2017 | date= October 31, 2017 | title=Trump dismisses Papadopoulos as 'low-level volunteer' but once touted him | publisher = CNN | first =Elizabeth | last = Landers}}</ref> [[FactCheck.org]] and [[PolitiFact]], among others, noted that during the campaign, Trump named Papadopoulos as one of his five foreign policy advisers—alongside [[Keith Kellogg]], [[Carter Page]], [[Walid Phares]] and [[Joseph E. Schmitz|Joseph Schmitz]]—and described Papadopoulos as an "excellent guy".<ref>{{Cite news|author=Louis Jacobson|url=http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/article/2017/oct/31/was-george-papadopoulos-just-volunteer|title=Was George Papadopoulos just a ‘volunteer’?|work=PolitiFact|date=October 31, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|author=Louis Jacobson|url=http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/article/2017/oct/30/how-important-was-george-papadopoulos-donald-trump/|title=How important was George Papadopoulos on Donald Trump's foreign-policy team?|work=PolitiFact|date=October 30, 2017}}</ref><ref name="FactCheck">{{Cite news|author=Robert Farley & Eugene Kiely|url=http://www.factcheck.org/2017/10/papadopoulos-low-level-volunteer/|title=Was Papadopoulos a 'Low-Level Volunteer'?|date=October 31, 2017|work=FactCheck.org|publisher=Annenberg Public Policy Center, University of Pennsylvania|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2017/10/30/politics/sarah-sanders-factcheck-indictment/index.html|title=Fact-checking Sarah Sanders' post-indictment briefing|last=Merica|first=Dan|publisher=CNN|date=October 30, 2017}}</ref>
In a sentencing memorandum released on August 17, 2018, prosecutors stated that a sentence of zero to six months was "appropriate and warranted," noting that Papadopoulos had repeatedly lied to investigators and did not provide "substantial assistance" to the investigation,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lawfareblog.com/document-george-papadopoulos-sentencing-memo|title=Document: George Papadopoulos Sentencing Memo|date=August 17, 2018|publisher=|accessdate=August 18, 2018}}</ref> and that his lies had interfered with the investigators' ability to question and if necessary detain Joseph Mifsud, who left the United States two weeks after Papadopoulos's first interview with the FBI.<ref name="WaPo-sentencing">{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/public-safety/former-trump-adviser-george-papadopoulos-sentenced-to-14-days-in-plea-deal-with-mueller-probe/2018/09/07/bef367a2-b210-11e8-aed9-001309990777_story.html|title=Former Trump adviser George Papadopoulos sentenced to 14 days in plea deal with Mueller probe|last=Hsu|first=Spencer|last2=Helderman|first2=Rosalind S.|date=September 7, 2018|publisher=Washington Post|language=en|access-date=2018-09-07}}</ref> On September 7, 2018, Papadopoulos was sentenced to 14 days in prison, 12 months of supervised release, and 200 hours of community service;<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/news/former-trump-adviser-george-papadopoulos-gets-14-days-in-jail|publisher=[[Washington Examiner]]|title=Former Trump adviser George Papadopoulos gets 14 days in jail}}</ref> he was also fined $9,500. He served his sentence at [[Federal Correctional Institution, Oxford|FCI Oxford]] in [[Oxford, Wisconsin]].<ref name="WaPo-sentencing" />
==Personal life== As of October 2017, Papadopoulos had lived for the past few years with his mother and brother in the [[Ravenswood, Chicago|Ravenswood]] neighborhood of [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]].<ref name=ctpath/> He married Simona Mangiante, an Italian lawyer who used to work for the [[European Parliament]], in March 2018.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/russia-investigation-romance-key-witness-george-papadopoulos-marries/story?id=53534911 |title=Russia Investigation Romance: Key witness George Papadopoulos marries Italian lawyer |last=Stephanopoulos |first=George |date=2018-03-05 |access-date=2018-03-08 |last2=Mosk |first2=Matthew |language=en-US|website=[[ABC News]]|author-link1=George Stephanopoulos}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/chicagoinc/ct-met-george-papadopulos-wedding-0307-chicago-inc-20180306-story.html |title=Mueller witness George Papadopoulos weds Italian sweetheart at Chicago's City Hall |last=Janssen |first=Kim |work=chicagotribune.com |access-date=2018-03-08 |language=en-US}}</ref> He had met her through Mifsud. During the months between his guilty plea and his sentencing, she became his public spokeswoman.<ref name = "wife"/> In a September 9 interview on ''This Week'', she said she understands why the FBI was suspicious of her because her international background might have been considered a "red flag". She commented, "I always said I respect Mueller’s interest in my profile because clearly it’s quite alarming, the fact that I marry George Papadopoulos in the middle of this storm." George Papadopoulos said that even his family had been concerned that she might be "some sort of Russian spy," a concern he dismissed.<ref name="wife">{{cite news|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/papadopouloss-wife-acknowledges-special-counsel-team-suspected-russian/story?id=57705038|title=Papadopoulos's wife acknowledges that special counsel team suspected her of being a Russian spy|last=Hadar|first=Roey|date=September 9, 2018|work=ABC News|accessdate=10 September 2018}}</ref>
== See also == * [[2016 Democratic National Committee email leak]]

== External links == * {{cite web |last=Gerstein |first=Josh |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2017/12/04/george-papadopoulos-arrest-fbi-277760 |title=George Papadopoulos' late night with the FBI |work=Politico |date=December 4, 2017}} * {{cite web |last=Witte |first=Griff |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/for-trump-adviser-at-center-of-russia-probe-a-rapid-rise-and-dramatic-fall-in-his-ancestral-land/2017/12/10/91bb696a-d390-11e7-9ad9-ca0619edfa05_story.html |title=For Trump adviser at center of Russia probe, a rapid rise and dramatic fall in his ancestral land |work=The Washington Post |date=December 10, 2017}}
{{Special Counsel investigation (2017–present)}}

revision.comment: added a missing band from the Manchester 2005 date
revision.text:
{{Primary sources|date=June 2015}} The '''Good To Go Tour''' is a British multi-artist package [[concert tour]] that features a mix of established acts from the American punk/rock/ska/pop genres and rising UK bands.
==History== The first Good To Go Tour took place in October 2005 and presented Southern California's rock superheroes, [[The Aquabats]], in their first tour of England alongside [[Never Heard Of It]], one of the America's most successful wholly independent rock bands. The bill was completed by [[Army of Freshmen]] (who joined for a few dates following a two-week tour with the Grammy nominated [[Bowling for Soup]]), and [[Sonic Boom Six]], Manchester's genre-defying female-fronted rockers.
The tour aims to deliver exciting and diverse line ups so that fans can learn to rely on the Good To Go Tour name to bring them the best in American and British music. "The whole point of this tour," said founder Ed Sellers, "is to have something that fans can look forward to, that they know will bring them interesting and fun line ups. The choices of bands are diverse enough to bring together fans from different musical backgrounds, but close enough that everyone can enjoy an entertaining and exciting show and maybe find a band that they didn't know a lot about before."
The Good To Go Tour also promises to stay true to its support of smaller, independent British bands. As an outlet to offer upcoming UK acts the opportunity to share the stage with established American acts that they might have been influenced by, the tour has given local bands in many towns some great opportunities. It works both ways too, allowing the tour an access to the street level promotion and enthusiastic word of mouth that can be invaluable in building a local buzz amongst fans, particularly with the advent of social networking sites such as [[MySpace]].
==The beginning== Whilst not called a Good To Go Tour, 2004's Brand New Hero Records Tour was a precursor to what eventually became the Good To Go Tour. In September/October 2004, this twelve date UK tour featured [[The Littlest Man Band]], [[Suburban Legends]] and [[Army Of Freshmen]], who made a return the following year as part of the first Good To Go Tour.
*19/09/2004 [[Nottingham]], [[England]] - Rock City *20/09/2004 [[Sheffield]], England - Corporation *21/09/2004 [[Southampton]], England - Joiners *22/09/2004 [[Northampton]], England - Soundhaus *23/09/2004 [[Liverpool]], England - [[Carling Academy Liverpool|Liverpool Carling Academy 2]] *24/09/2004 [[Birmingham]], England - [[Carling Academy Birmingham|Birmingham Carling Academy 2]] *25/09/2004 [[Manchester]], England - Satan's Hollow *26/09/2004 [[Leicester]], England - Charlotte *28/09/2004 [[Norwich]], England - [[The Ferry Boat Inn|Ferry Boat Inn]] *29/09/2004 [[Glasgow]], [[Scotland]] - Cathouse *30/09/2004 [[Milton Keynes]], England - Pitz *01/10/2004 [[London]], England - Underworld
==Tours== ===Good To Go Tour 2005=== In October 2005 the inaugural Good To Go Tour ran between the 20th-29th inclusive, featuring:
*[[The Aquabats|The Aquabats!]] *Never Heard Of It *[[Army Of Freshmen]] *[[Sonic Boom Six]]
The tour took in the following dates: *20/10/2005 [[Leicester]], [[England]] - Charlotte ''(The Aquabats!, Never Heard Of It, Sonic Boom Six)'' *21/10/2005 [[Camberley]], England - Camberley Football Club ''(The Aquabats!, Never Heard Of It, Sonic Boom Six, Three Quarters, Leading Brand)'' *22/10/2005 [[Norwich]], England - Ferry Boat Inn ''(The Aquabats!, Never Heard Of It, Sonic Boom Six, Fun!Yeah!, Flick The Switch)'' *23/10/2005 [[Nottingham]], England - Junktion 7 ''(The Aquabats!, Never Heard Of It, Grown At Home, The Chernobyl Children)'' *24/10/2005 [[Portsmouth]], England - [[The Wedgewood Rooms|Wedgewood Rooms]]'' (The Aquabats!, Never Heard Of It, Sonic Boom Six)'' *25/10/2005 [[Yeovil]], England - Ski Lodge ''(The Aquabats!, Never Heard Of It, Grown At Home)'' *26/10/2005 [[London]], England - [[Carling Academy Islington]] ''(The Aquabats!, Never Heard Of It, Army Of Freshmen)'' *27/10/2005 [[Liverpool]], England - [[Carling Academy Liverpool|Liverpool Carling Academy 2]] ''(The Aquabats!, Never Heard Of It, Army Of Freshmen)'' *28/10/2005 [[Manchester]], England - Satan's Hollow ''(The Aquabats!, Never Heard Of It, Army Of Freshmen, The Minions ( of Jeffrey).)'' *29/10/2005 [[Northampton]], England - [[Roadmender (nightclub)|Roadmender]] ''(The Aquabats!, Never Heard Of It, Army Of Freshmen, The Chernobyl Children)''
===Good To Go Tour 2006=== July and August 2006 saw the second Good To Go Tour, featuring a line-up of:
*[[The Aquabats|The Aquabats!]] *[[Allister]] *[[The Riverclub]] *[[Failsafe (UK band)|Failsafe]]
Failsafe - whilst not playing the entire tour - played the Carling Academy dates and a select few. The tour ran from 25 July to 7 August inclusive.
*25/07/2006 [[Bristol]], [[England]] - [[Carling Academy Bristol|Bristol Carling Academy 2]]'' (The Aquabats!, Allister, The Riverclub, Failsafe)'' *26/07/2006 [[Cardiff]], [[Wales]] - [[Cardiff University]] ''(The Aquabats!, Allister, [[MC Lars]], The Riverclub)'' *27/07/2006 [[Yeovil]], England - Ski Lodge ''(The Aquabats!, Allister, The Riverclub, [[The Display Team|Mumrah]])'' *28/07/2006 [[Camberley]], England - Agincourt ''(The Aquabats!, Allister, The Riverclub, Save The Lecture, Against The Odd)'' *29/07/2006 [[Bournemouth]], England - [[The Opera House (nightclub)|Opera House]] ''(The Aquabats!, Allister, MC Lars, The Riverclub)'' *31/07/2006 [[Leeds]], England - [[Josephs Well]] ''(The Aquabats!, Allister, The Riverclub, Sonic Boom Six, Mumrah)'' *01/08/2006 [[Manchester]], England - [[Jilly's Rockworld]] ''(The Aquabats!, Allister, The Riverclub, Failsafe)''<ref>See [http://www.makenoisemanchester.co.uk/community/index.php?showtopic=6696 Make Noise Manchester Forum].</ref> *02/08/2006 [[Edinburgh]], [[Scotland]] - Studio 24 ''(The Aquabats!, Allister, The Riverclub)'' *03/08/2006 [[Newcastle upon Tyne]], [[England]] - [[Carling Academy Newcastle|Newcastle Carling Academy 2]] ''(The Aquabats!, Allister, The Riverclub, Failsafe)'' *04/08/2006 [[Birmingham]], England - [[Carling Academy Birmingham|Birmingham Carling Academy 2]] ''(The Aquabats!, Allister, The Riverclub, Failsafe)'' *05/08/2006 [[London]], England - [[Carling Academy Islington]] ''(The Aquabats!, Allister, The Riverclub, Failsafe)'' *06/08/2006 [[Portsmouth]], England - [[The Wedgewood Rooms|Wedgewood Rooms]] ''(The Aquabats!, Allister, The Riverclub, Not Advised)'' *07/08/2006 [[Norwich]], England - [[Norwich Arts Centre]] ''(The Aquabats!, Allister, The Riverclub)''
===Good To Go Tour 2007=== The third tour took place in May [[2007 in music|2007]], with a line-up of: *[[Wheatus]] *[[MC Lars]] *[[Army Of Freshmen]] *[[Punchline (band)|Punchline]]
Army Of Freshmen was originally scheduled to play all fifteen of the dates but had to pull out of the final five due to other tour commitments.
The tour was scheduled for the following dates:<ref>See [http://www.myspace.com/goodtogotour Good To Go Tour Myspace profile (includes tour dates and full support information)].</ref>
*03/05/2007 [[Oxford]], [[England]] - [[The Zodiac (club)|Zodiac]] ''(Wheatus, MC Lars, Army of Freshmen, Punchline)'' *04/05/2007 [[Yeovil]], England - Ski Lodge ''(Wheatus, MC Lars, Army of Freshmen, Punchline)'' *05/05/2007 [[Newport, Wales|Newport]], [[Wales]] - TJs ''(Wheatus, MC Lars, Army of Freshmen, Punchline, Ouzo 38)'' *06/05/2007 [[Southampton]], England - Nexus ''(Wheatus, MC Lars, Army of Freshmen, Punchline)'' *07/05/2007 [[Bristol]], England - [[Carling Academy Bristol|Bristol Carling Academy 2]] ''(Wheatus, MC Lars, Army of Freshmen, Punchline)'' *08/05/2007 [[Wrexham]], Wales - Central Station ''(Wheatus, MC Lars, Army of Freshmen, Punchline)'' *09/05/2007 [[Manchester]], England - Music Box ''(Wheatus, MC Lars, Army of Freshmen, Punchline, Never Say Die)'' *10/05/2007 [[Newcastle upon Tyne]], England - [[Carling Academy Newcastle|Newcastle Carling Academy 2]] ''(Wheatus, MC Lars, Army of Freshmen, Punchline)'' *11/05/2007 [[Birmingham]], England - [[Carling Academy Birmingham|Birmingham Carling Academy 2]] ''(Wheatus, MC Lars, Army of Freshmen, Punchline)'' *12/05/2007 [[London]], England - [[Carling Academy Islington]] ''(Wheatus, MC Lars, Army of Freshmen, Punchline)'' *13/05/2007 [[Derby]], England - First Floor Club ''(Wheatus, MC Lars, Failsafe, Punchline, 3 Storeys High)'' *14/05/2007 [[Leicester]], England - Charlotte ''(Wheatus, MC Lars, Punchline, 3 Storeys High, Glitch)'' *15/05/2007 [[Edinburgh]], [[Scotland]] - Exchange ''(Wheatus, MC Lars, Punchline, 3 Storeys High)'' *16/05/2007 [[Leeds]], England - Joseph's Well ''(Wheatus, MC Lars, Punchline, Make it Better Later)'' *17/05/2007 [[Norwich]], England - [[The Waterfront, Norwich|Waterfront]] ''(Wheatus, MC Lars, Punchline, The Escaped)''
===Good To Go Tour 2008(i)=== The first Good To Go Tour of 2008 took place in February, with a line-up of: *[[MxPx]] *[[Punchline (band)|Punchline]] *[[The Get Go]]
The tour took in the following dates: *07/02/2008 [[Norwich]], [[England]] - [[The Waterfront, Norwich|Waterfront]] ''(MxPx, Punchline, The Get Go)'' *08/02/2008 [[Birmingham]], England - [[Carling Academy Birmingham|Birmingham Carling Academy 2]] ''(MxPx, Punchline, The Get Go)'' *09/02/2008 [[Newcastle upon Tyne]], England - [[Carling Academy Newcastle|Newcastle Carling Academy 2]] ''(MxPx, Punchline, The Get Go)'' *10/02/2008 [[Manchester]], England - Manchester Academy 3 ''(MxPx, Punchline, The Get Go)'' *12/02/2008 [[London]], England - [[Carling Academy Islington]] ''(MxPx, Punchline, The Get Go)'' *13/02/2008 [[Portsmouth]], England - [[The Wedgewood Rooms|Wedgewood Rooms]] ''(MxPx, Punchline, The Get Go)'' *14/02/2008 [[Oxford]], England - [[The Zodiac (club)|Zodiac]] ''(MxPx, Punchline, The Get Go)'' *15/02/2008 [[Yeovil]], England - Orange Box ''(MxPx, Punchline, The Get Go)'' *16/02/2008 [[Stoke on Trent]], England - Sugarmill ''(MxPx, Punchline, The Get Go)'' *17/02/2008 [[Glasgow]], [[Scotland]] - Garage ''(MxPx, Punchline, The Get Go)''
MxPx then departed from the tour. Punchline and The Get Go continued for a further four shows.
*18/02/2008 [[Wrexham]], [[Wales]] - Central Station ''(Punchline, The Get Go, In City Light, A59)'' *19/02/2008 [[Newport, Wales|Newport]], Wales - TJs ''(Punchline, The Get Go)'' *20/02/2008 [[Bournemouth]], England - iBar ''(Punchline, The Get Go, El Paso De Cebra)'' *21/02/2008 [[Swindon]], England - Bar 12 ''(Punchline, The Get Go)''
===Good To Go Tour 2008(ii)=== The second Good To Go Tour of 2008 took place in July, and featured: *[[We Are the Ocean]] *[[Canterbury (band)|Canterbury]] *[[All Forgotten]]
The tour took in the following dates: *03/07/08 [[Peterborough]], [[England]] - The Met Lounge ''(We Are The Ocean, Canterbury, All Forgotten)'' *04/07/08 [[Birmingham]], England - Birmingham Carling Academy 2 ''(We Are The Ocean, Canterbury, All Forgotten)'' *05/07/08 [[York]], England - The Duchess ''(We Are The Ocean, Canterbury, All Forgotten)'' *06/07/08 [[Newcastle upon Tyne]], England - Newcastle Carling Academy 2 ''(We Are The Ocean, Canterbury, All Forgotten)'' *07/07/08 [[Glasgow]], [[Scotland]] - Barfly ''(We Are The Ocean, Canterbury, All Forgotten)'' *08/07/08 [[Aberdeen]], Scotland - Drummonds ''(We Are The Ocean, Canterbury, All Forgotten)'' *10/07/08 [[Liverpool]], England - Liverpool Carling Academy 2 ''(We Are The Ocean, Canterbury, All Forgotten)'' *11/07/08 [[Sheffield]], England - Sheffield Carling Academy 2 ''(We Are The Ocean, Canterbury, All Forgotten)'' *12/07/08 [[Yeovil]], England - Orange Box ''(We Are The Ocean, Canterbury, All Forgotten)'' *13/07/08 [[Oxford]], England - Oxford Carling Academy ''(We Are The Ocean, Canterbury, All Forgotten)'' *14/07/08 [[Cardiff]], [[Wales]] - Barfly ''(We Are The Ocean, Canterbury, All Forgotten)'' *15/07/08 [[Bristol]], England - Britsol Carling Academy 2 ''(We Are The Ocean, Canterbury, All Forgotten)'' *16/07/08 [[London]], England - Carling Academy Islington ''(We Are The Ocean, Canterbury, All Forgotten)'' *17/07/08 [[Southampton]], England - Joiners ''(We Are The Ocean, Canterbury, All Forgotten)''
===Good To Go Tour 2009=== In April 2009 there was a three date 'Funsize' Good To Go Tour. The short length was due to The Aquabats! only being able to play three UK shows before their appearance at Groezrock Festival in Belgium.<ref>See http://blog.goodtogotour.com</ref> With support from Allbright at the London show only, this three date tour featured: *[[The Aquabats|The Aquabats!]] *[[MC Lars]] *[[Failsafe]]
The tour took in the following dates: *14/04/09 [[Leeds]], [[England]] - The Cockpit ''(The Aquabats, MC Lars, Failsafe)'' *15/04/09 [[Glasgow]], [[Scotland]] - The Cathouse ''(The Aquabats, MC Lars, Failsafe)'' *16/04/09 [[London]], England - O2 Academy Islington ''(The Aquabats, MC Lars, Failsafe, Allbright)''
==Other Tours== As well as the Good To Go Tour and the 2004 Brand New Hero Records Tour, the organisers of the Good To Go Tour have also put together other tours.
===Army of Freshmen UK Headline Tour 2008(i)=== In June 2008, Army of Freshmen embarked on their first UK headline tour, taking in the following dates:
*02/06/08 [[Manchester]], [[England]] - Music Box ''(Army of Freshmen, Failsafe, Smudge)'' *03/06/08 [[Portsmouth]], England - Wedgewood Rooms ''(Army of Freshmen, Last Letter Read, Splendid Eddie, Hung Up)'' *04/06/08 [[Wrexham]], [[Wales]] - Central Station ''(Army of Freshmen, A59, XMS3, Sliced Peach)'' *05/06/08 [[Newport, Wales|Newport]], Wales - TJs ''(Army of Freshmen, Panz Agenda, Winch House, Sliced Peach)'' *06/06/08 [[Tamworth, Staffordshire|Tamworth]], England - Palace ''(Army of Freshmen, Frontline, Falling Faster, Kills With One Bite)'' *07/06/08 [[Peterborough]], England - The Met Lounge ''(Army of Freshmen, White Clouds and Gunfire, Flick 66, Frontline)'' *08/06/08 [[Leeds]], England - The Cockpit ''(Army of Freshmen, Mike TV, Make it Better Later, Second Chance, Fat Phace)'' *09/06/08 [[Glasgow]], [[Scotland]] - The Cathouse ''(Army of Freshmen, DB68, 3 Storeys High)'' *10/06/08 [[London]], England - The Underworld ''([[Zebrahead]], Army of Freshmen, Sherwood, Go:Audio)'' *11/06/08 [[Norwich]], England - The Queen Charlotte ''(Army of Freshmen, Mike TV, Lost?, Spot)'' *12/06/08 [[Newcastle upon Tyne]], England - Newcastle University ''(Army of Freshmen, Midterm Break, Astro Chimp)''
===Army of Freshmen UK Headline Tour 2008(ii)=== In November 2008, Army of Freshmen return on their second headline tour of the UK, organised under the Good To Go Tour umbrella, taking in the following dates:
*13/11/08 [[Peterborough]], [[England]] - The Met Lounge *14/11/08 [[Glasgow]], [[Scotland]] - The Cathouse *15/11/08 [[Edinburgh]], Scotland - Studio 24 *16/11/08 [[Birmingham]], England - Birmingham Carling Academy 2 *17/11/08 [[Manchester]], England - Manchester Academy 3 *18/11/08 [[Wrexham]], [[Wales]] - Central Station *19/11/08 [[London]], England - The Underworld *20/11/08 [[Newport, Wales|Newport]], Wales - TJs *21/11/08 [[Swindon]], England - Furnace *22/11/08 [[Leeds]], England - Rios *23/11/08 [[Southampton]], England - Talking Heads
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Peacock|date=August 2018}}
{{lowercase}}
'''govWorks Inc.''' was a [[dot-com company]] that was founded in 1998 by [[Kaleil Isaza Tuzman]], Tom Herman and Chieh Cheung. It went bankrupt when the [[dot-com bubble]] burst in 2000. govWorks's rise and fall is documented in the 2001 [[documentary film|documentary]] ''[[Startup.com]]''. The firm, originally known as Public Data Systems, produced software to help government clients track contracts and purchasing functions. As the Internet boom accelerated, the company transitioned toward becoming an Internet [[web portal]].
During the company's existence, cities such as [[Grand Island, New York|Grand Island]], [[New York (state)|New York]], showed interest in using its services.<ref>{{cite news |title=Service on Net is Considered for Collecting Taxes and Fees |work=The Buffalo News |date=2000-10-05 |author=Levy, Michael }}</ref> A survey was also conducted by ''[[The Economist]]'' which concluded that people preferred to pay fees owed to the government over the Internet due to its convenience.<ref>{{cite news |title=A Survey of Government and The Internet |work=The Economist |date=2000-06-24 |author=Symonds, Matthew }}</ref> Still, govWorks’ couldn’t overcome some of the most common challenges faced by start-up companies and is ranked by Cnet.com as one of the top ten dot-com failures of the time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnet.com/1990-11136_1-6278387-1.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-02-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140210101028/http://www.cnet.com/1990-11136_1-6278387-1.html |archivedate=2014-02-10 |df= }}</ref>
The govWorks website was relaunched in January 2018.<ref>https://www.entrepreneur.com/article/308105</ref> The current iteration of govWorks is related to its predecessor in name only. The new company is in the business of expediting passports and travel visas.
== History ==
The company was founded in May 1998 with 8 employees and was originally known as Public Data Systems. The service delivery model for govWorks which was inspired by Tuzman after he found a two-year-old parking ticket in his New York City apartment,<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.forbes.com/forbes/2010/1025/entrepreneurs-jumptv-kit-digital-startup-the-sequel.html | work=Forbes | first=Christopher | last=Steiner | title=Startup.com: The Sequel | date=2010-10-25}}</ref> was to offer a service that provided the ability for people to pay city fees through their Internet portal. The initial launch of govWorks.com online services to select markets occurred in October 1999 in key cities in Massachusetts and Connecticut with a full scale rollout planned in early 2000.
The firm set out to provide a website portal to allow citizens in local communities to access, pay or apply for city services, jobs or receive community information.<ref>http://fcw.com/Articles/1999/09/23/GovWorkscom-launching-link-to-local-services.aspx</ref> Unlike many other dot-com companies of the time, the services provided by govWorks.com appeared to have a well-defined business plan, a market in need of a service and offered access to city services with ease through their website portal. However, like so many others, govWorks’ mismanagement, demand for capital, speed to market and a lack of proper service execution eventually contributed to the failure of the company. In January 2001, Tuzman and his investors sold the company to [[First Data Corporation]].
According to public statements by govWorks.com co-founder Tom Herman, the sale resulted in a loss for the founders and investors. The company had burned through approximately $60 million in venture capital during its three years of existence.
Just a few months after the founding of govWorks.com, interest in the company was strong and govWorks.com employee count grew to 30 employees as of August 1998 and by October 1998, the company had 70 employees. The Startup.com movie showcased a business culture with energy and excitement; people were interested in joining the company with the hope of getting in at the beginning stages of another dot-com success story. As additional capital investment came into the company and as the company neared its full scale rollout in 2000, the company expanded further with headcount from 120 employees in January 2000<ref>http://www.documentaryfilms.net: http://www.documentaryfilms.net/Reviews/StartUp/</ref> to over 250 employees in April 2000. However, as depicted in the movie, govWorks.com suffered from a number of organizational power struggles<ref>metreo.com: http://www.symphony-metreo.com/news/articles/FT2/FT-Shutdown.html</ref> and governance issues that would eventually lead to the company’s demise.
Towards the end of 2000, when it was clear that the company was hemorrhaging money and not able to fully execute its planned services, the company dramatically reduced its headcount to 60 employees in November 2000 in an attempt to stem the $1 million per month<ref>metreo.com: http://www.symphony-metreo.com/news/articles/FT2/FT-Shutdown.html</ref> in overhead expenditures. The company was sold to First Data Corporation in January 2001. The documentary film, Startup.com which was released by Artisan in May 2001, won the Grand Prize at the 2001 Sundance Film Festival<ref>metreo.com: http://www.symphony-metreo.com/news/articles/FT2/FT-Shutdown.html</ref> and accumulated $765,000 in initial box office receipts.
== Affiliated Companies ==
Collectively, corporate governance of govworks.com was associated with thirty one (31) for-profit and not-for-profit companies and institutions from a variety of market sectors, including:
[[Chase (bank)|Chase Manhattan]], [[Hyatt Legal Services]], [[Stanford University]], Jackson Securities, [[Kohlberg Kravis Roberts]], New York City Investment Fund, [[Mayfield Fund]], Corradini & Company, The Duberstein Group, [[Barnes & Thornburg]], [[Sapient Corporation]], [[Vestar Capital Partners]], Urban Health Initiative, [[Harvard University]], [[JumpStart]], The ASHOKA Foundation, Public Allies, Kirshenbaum Bond Partners, MassHysteria.com, [[Chrysler Corporation]], Into Networks, Endeavor Fund, [[Sportsline.com]], Vignette, Premier Asset Management, Star Media Networks, Patagon.com, COTESA, S.A. de C.V., Chrysalis Capital, First International Resources Inc., ISI Emerging Markets.
== Competitors == One of the strongest competitors to govWorks.com was [[Atlanta]]-based EzGov.com. As depicted so famously in the movie, co-founder of EzGov Bryan Mundy was invited by Tuzman to come and tour govWorks’ offices prior to either company releasing their software. Similar to govWorks, EzGov offered software to local governments and municipalities to allow citizens to pay parking tickets, taxes and obtain other city services on-line 24 hours a day.<ref>http://fcw.com/Articles/1999/11/09/Ezgov-launches-nationwide-portal.aspx?p=1</ref> In January 2001, Mundy and Erin Johansen, 26, of Ontario, Canada died of smoke inhalation during a fire in Mundy's Atlanta, GA home.<ref>http://articles.philly.com/2001-01-19/news/25308502_1_e-commerce-solutions-internet-track-team</ref>
In addition to EzGov, govWorks had other competitors; some of whom offered the same or similar service as govWorks but at a much lower cost or in some cases free, as the competitor service models relied on alternate forms of financing versus govWorks’ client-funded approach.
== Bankruptcy Filing == In March 2001, govWorks.com officially filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.<ref>http://washingtontechnology.com/articles/2001/03/09/govworks-files-for-bankruptcy.aspx</ref> At the time of the filing, the company listed assets worth an approximate $8 million and liabilities of $40 million from the more than $70 million it raised through venture capital. Boalt Holdings, LLC acquired the domain and brand assets in 2017.
== Current Ownership == [https://www.forbes.com/sites/steveolenski/2018/03/06/4-lessons-cmos-can-learn-from-this-brands-resurrection/#336b0fd96085 govWorks was relaunched] in January 2018.
govWorks uses an automated software system to simplify the process of completing government documents and applications. The govWorks brands [http://PassportCenter.com PassportCenter.com], [http://PassportRenewal.com PassportRenewal.com] and [http://TravelVisa.com TravelVisa.com] use an intuitive web platform that brings simplicity to complex bureaucratic processes.
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:American websites]] [[Category:Internet properties established in 1998]] [[Category:Internet properties disestablished in 2000]] [[Category:Dot-com bubble]]

{{pp-semi-protected|small=yes}} {{pp-move-indef}} {{short description|Spectrum of conditions caused by HIV infection}} {{redir|AIDS}} {{Good article}} {{Use mdy dates|date=December 2015}} {{Use American English|date=September 2016}} {{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = HIV/AIDS | image = Red_Ribbon.svg | image_size = 220px | caption = The [[red ribbon#AIDS awareness origin|red ribbon]] is a [[awareness ribbon#Awareness Ribbon origin|symbol]] for [[solidarity]] with [[HIV-positive people]] and those living with AIDS.{{cite web|title=Wear your red ribbon this World AIDS Day {{!}} UNAIDS|url=http://www.unaids.org/en/resources/presscentre/featurestories/2006/november/20061130redribbonen|website=www.unaids.org|publisher=UNAIDS Secretariat|access-date=10 September 2017}} | alt = A red ribbon in the shape of a bow | field = [[Infectious disease (medical specialty)|Infectious disease]] | synonyms = HIV disease, HIV infection{{cite web|title=What Are HIV and AIDS? {{!}} HIV.gov|url=https://www.hiv.gov/hiv-basics/overview/about-hiv-and-aids/what-are-hiv-and-aids|website=www.hiv.gov|publisher=U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS)|access-date=10 September 2017|language=en}}Mandell, Bennett, and Dolan (2010). Chapter 121.{{cite web|title=HIV Classification: CDC and WHO Staging Systems {{!}} AIDS Education and Training Centers National Coordinating Resource Center (AETC NCRC)|url=https://aidsetc.org/guide/hiv-classification-cdc-and-who-staging-systems|website=aidsetc.org|publisher=AIDS Education and Training Center Program|access-date=10 September 2017|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171018065658/https://aidsetc.org/guide/hiv-classification-cdc-and-who-staging-systems|archive-date=October 18, 2017|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} | symptoms = '''Early''': flu like illness
'''Later''': [[Large lymph nodes]], fever, weight loss | complications = [[Opportunistic infection]]s, [[tumors]] | onset = | duration = Long term | causes = [[Human immunodeficiency virus]] (HIV) | risks = Exposure to blood, breast milk, sex | diagnosis = Blood tests | differential = | prevention = [[Safe sex]], [[needle exchange]], [[male circumcision]], [[pre-exposure prophylaxis]] | treatment = [[Antiretroviral therapy]] | medication = | prognosis = Near normal life expectancy with treatment | frequency = 1.8 million new cases (2016)
36.7 million living with HIV (2016){{cite web|title=Global summary of the AIDS epidemic 2016|url=http://www.unaids.org/sites/default/files/media_asset/UNAIDS_2017_core-epidemiology-slides_en.pdf|website=UNAIDS|publisher=UNAIDS|access-date=10 September 2017|date=June 2017}} | deaths = 1.0 million (2016) }} '''Human immunodeficiency virus infection and acquired immune deficiency syndrome''' ('''HIV/AIDS''') is a spectrum of conditions caused by [[infection]] with the [[HIV|human immunodeficiency virus]] (HIV).{{cite journal | vauthors = Sepkowitz KA | title = AIDS--the first 20 years | journal = The New England Journal of Medicine | volume = 344 | issue = 23 | pages = 1764–72 | date = June 2001 | pmid = 11396444 | doi = 10.1056/NEJM200106073442306 }}{{cite book | first1 = Alexander | last1= Krämer | first2 = Mirjam | last2 = Kretzschmar | first3 = Klaus | last3 = Krickeberg | name-list-format = vanc |title=Modern infectious disease epidemiology concepts, methods, mathematical models, and public health|date=2010|publisher=Springer|location=New York|isbn=9780387938356|page=88|edition=Online-Ausg.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Di0_5x82HykC&pg=PA88 |df=mdy-all}}{{cite book| first = Wilhelm | last = Kirch | name-list-format = vanc | title = Encyclopedia of Public Health |date=2008|publisher=Springer|location=New York|isbn=9781402056130|pages=676–677|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eSPK7-CHw7oC&pg=PA676 |df=mdy-all}} Following initial infection, a person may not notice any symptoms or may experience a brief period of [[influenza-like illness]]. Typically, this is followed by a prolonged period with no symptoms.{{cite web|title=About HIV/AIDS|url=https://www.cdc.gov/hiv/basics/whatishiv.html|website=CDC|access-date=11 February 2016|date=December 6, 2015 |df=mdy-all}} As the infection progresses, it interferes more with the [[immune system]], increasing the risk of developing common infections such as [[tuberculosis]], as well as other [[opportunistic infection]]s, and [[tumors]] that rarely affect people who have working immune systems. These late symptoms of infection are referred to as acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). This stage is often also associated with [[Cachexia|unintended weight loss]]. HIV is spread primarily by [[Safe sex|unprotected sex]] (including [[anal sex|anal]] and [[oral sex]]), contaminated [[blood transfusion]]s, [[hypodermic needle]]s, and [[Vertically transmitted infection|from mother to child]] during [[HIV and pregnancy|pregnancy]], delivery, or breastfeeding.{{cite book|veditors=Rom WN, Markowitz SB |title=Environmental and occupational medicine|year=2007|publisher=Wolters Kluwer/Lippincott Williams & Wilkins|location=Philadelphia|isbn=978-0-7817-6299-1|page=745|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=H4Sv9XY296oC&pg=PA745|edition=4th |df=mdy-all}} Some bodily fluids, such as saliva and tears, do not transmit HIV.{{cite web|publisher=[[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]]|year=2003|url=https://www.cdc.gov/HIV/pubs/facts/transmission.htm|title=HIV and Its Transmission|access-date=May 23, 2006|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050204141148/http://www.cdc.gov/HIV/pubs/facts/transmission.htm|archive-date=February 4, 2005}} Methods of prevention include [[safe sex]], [[needle exchange programme|needle exchange programs]], [[treatment as prevention|treating those who are infected]], and [[male circumcision]]. Disease in a baby can often be prevented by giving both the mother and child [[Management of HIV/AIDS|antiretroviral medication]].{{cite web|title=HIV/AIDS Fact sheet N°360|url=http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs360/en/|website=WHO|access-date=11 February 2016|date=November 2015|deadurl=no|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160217160830/http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs360/en/|archive-date=February 17, 2016|df=mdy-all}} There is no cure or [[HIV vaccine|vaccine]]; however, antiretroviral treatment can slow the course of the disease and may lead to a near-normal life expectancy.{{cite news|title=The quest for an HIV vaccine|url=http://www.unaids.org/en/resources/presscentre/featurestories/2012/may/20120518vaccinesday/|date=May 18, 2012|author=UNAIDS|deadurl=no|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120524051113/http://www.unaids.org/en/resources/presscentre/featurestories/2012/may/20120518vaccinesday/|archive-date=May 24, 2012|df=mdy-all}} Treatment is recommended as soon as the diagnosis is made.{{cite book|title=Guideline on when to start antiretroviral therapy and on pre-exposure prophylaxis for HIV|date=2015|publisher=WHO|isbn=9789241509565|page=13|url=http://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/10665/186275/1/9789241509565_eng.pdf?ua=1|deadurl=no|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151014071803/http://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/10665/186275/1/9789241509565_eng.pdf?ua=1|archive-date=October 14, 2015|df=mdy-all}} Without treatment, the average survival time after infection is 11 years.{{cite web|author=[[Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS|UNAIDS]], [[World Health Organization|WHO]] |date=December 2007 |title=2007 AIDS epidemic update |url=http://data.unaids.org/pub/EPISlides/2007/2007_epiupdate_en.pdf |access-date=March 12, 2008 |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080527201701/http://data.unaids.org/pub/EPISlides/2007/2007_epiupdate_en.pdf |archive-date=May 27, 2008 |df= }} In 2016, about 36.7 million people were living with HIV and it resulted in 1 million deaths.{{cite web|title=Fact sheet – Latest statistics on the status of the AIDS epidemic {{!}} UNAIDS|url=http://www.unaids.org/en/resources/fact-sheet|website=www.unaids.org|access-date=21 July 2017|deadurl=no|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170713205307/http://www.unaids.org/en/resources/fact-sheet|archive-date=July 13, 2017|df=mdy-all}} There were 300,000 fewer new HIV cases in 2016 than in 2015.{{Cite news|url=https://www.avert.org/global-hiv-and-aids-statistics|title=Global HIV and AIDS statistics|date=2015-07-16|work=AVERT|access-date=2017-10-07|language=en}} Most of those infected live in [[sub-Saharan Africa]]. From the time AIDS was identified in the early 1980s to 2017, the disease has caused an estimated 35 million deaths worldwide.{{Cite web|url=http://www.unaids.org/en/resources/fact-sheet|title=Fact sheet - Latest statistics on the status of the AIDS epidemic|website=www.unaids.org|language=en|access-date=2018-03-16|publisher=UNAIDS}} HIV/AIDS is considered a [[pandemic]]—a disease outbreak which is present over a large area and is actively spreading.{{cite journal | vauthors = Kallings LO | title = The first postmodern pandemic: 25 years of HIV/ AIDS | journal = Journal of Internal Medicine | volume = 263 | issue = 3 | pages = 218–43 | date = March 2008 | pmid = 18205765 | doi = 10.1111/j.1365-2796.2007.01910.x }}(subscription required) HIV originated in west-central Africa during the late 19th or early 20th century.{{cite journal | vauthors = Sharp PM, Hahn BH | title = Origins of HIV and the AIDS pandemic | journal = Cold Spring Harbor Perspectives in Medicine | volume = 1 | issue = 1 | pages = a006841 | date = September 2011 | pmid = 22229120 | pmc = 3234451 | doi = 10.1101/cshperspect.a006841 }} AIDS was first recognized by the United States [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] (CDC) in 1981 and its cause—HIV infection—was identified in the early part of the decade.{{cite journal | vauthors = Gallo RC | title = A reflection on HIV/AIDS research after 25 years | journal = Retrovirology | volume = 3 | issue = 1 | pages = 72 | date = October 2006 | pmid = 17054781 | pmc = 1629027 | doi = 10.1186/1742-4690-3-72 | url = http://www.retrovirology.com/content/3//72 }} HIV/AIDS has had a great impact on society, both as an illness and as a source of [[Discrimination against people with HIV/AIDS|discrimination]].{{cite book |publisher=[[Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS|UNAIDS]] |year=2006 |title=2006 Report on the global AIDS epidemic |chapter=The impact of AIDS on people and societies |chapterurl=http://data.unaids.org/pub/GlobalReport/2006/2006_GR_CH04_en.pdf |access-date=June 14, 2006 |chapter-format=PDF |isbn=978-92-9173-479-5}} The disease also has large [[Economic impact of HIV/AIDS|economic impacts]]. There are many [[misconceptions about HIV/AIDS]] such as the belief that it can be transmitted by casual non-sexual contact.{{cite web|title=Myth Busters|url=http://austintexas.gov/page/myth-busters|access-date=14 February 2016|deadurl=no|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160222160217/http://austintexas.gov/page/myth-busters|archive-date=February 22, 2016|df=mdy-all}} The disease has become subject to many [[Religion and HIV/AIDS|controversies involving religion]] including the [[Catholic Church and HIV/AIDS|Catholic Church's position]] not to support [[condom]] use as prevention.{{cite web|last1=McCullom|first1=Rob|title=An African Pope Won't Change the Vatican's Views on Condoms and AIDS|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/sexes/archive/2013/02/an-african-pope-wont-change-the-vaticans-views-on-condoms-and-aids/273535/|website=The Atlantic|access-date=14 February 2016|date=26 Feb 2013|deadurl=no|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160308135849/http://www.theatlantic.com/sexes/archive/2013/02/an-african-pope-wont-change-the-vaticans-views-on-condoms-and-aids/273535/|archive-date=March 8, 2016|df=mdy-all}} It has attracted international medical and political attention as well as large-scale funding since it was identified in the 1980s.{{cite book |author=Harden, Victoria Angela |title=AIDS at 30: A History |publisher=Potomac Books Inc |location= |year=2012 |pages=324 |isbn=978-1-59797-294-9 |oclc= |doi= }} {{TOC limit|3}} == Signs and symptoms == {{Main|Signs and symptoms of HIV/AIDS}} There are three main stages of HIV infection: acute infection, clinical latency and AIDS. === Acute infection === [[File:Symptoms of acute HIV infection.svg|thumb|upright=1.25|alt=A diagram of a human torso labelled with the most common symptoms of an acute HIV infection|Main symptoms of acute HIV infection]] The initial period following the contraction of HIV is called acute HIV, primary HIV or acute retroviral syndrome. Many individuals develop an [[influenza-like illness]] or a [[Infectious mononucleosis|mononucleosis-like illness]] 2–4 weeks after exposure while others have no significant symptoms.{{cite book|title=Diseases and disorders|year=2008|publisher=Marshall Cavendish|location=Tarrytown, NY|isbn=978-0-7614-7771-6|page=25|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-HRJOElZch8C&pg=PA25 |df=mdy-all}} Symptoms occur in 40–90% of cases and most commonly include [[fever]], [[lymphadenopathy|large tender lymph nodes]], [[pharyngitis|throat inflammation]], a [[rash]], headache, tiredness, and/or sores of the mouth and genitals. The rash, which occurs in 20–50% of cases, presents itself on the trunk and is [[maculopapular]], classically. Some people also develop [[opportunistic infections]] at this stage. Gastrointestinal symptoms, such as vomiting or [[diarrhea]] may occur. Neurological symptoms of [[peripheral neuropathy]] or [[Guillain–Barré syndrome]] also occurs. The duration of the symptoms varies, but is usually one or two weeks. Due to their [[Nonspecific symptoms#Types|nonspecific]] character, these symptoms are not often [[Medical diagnosis#Pattern recognition|recognized]] as signs of HIV infection. Even cases that do get seen by a family doctor or a hospital are often misdiagnosed as one of the many common [[infectious disease]]s with overlapping symptoms. Thus, it is recommended that HIV be considered in people presenting with an [[Fever of unknown origin|unexplained fever]] who may have risk factors for the infection.Mandell, Bennett, and Dolan (2010). Chapter 118. === Clinical latency === The initial symptoms are followed by a stage called clinical latency, asymptomatic HIV, or chronic HIV. Without treatment, this second stage of the [[Natural history of disease|natural history]] of HIV infection can last from about three years{{cite book|last=Evian|first=Clive|title=Primary HIV/AIDS care: a practical guide for primary health care personnel in a clinical and supportive setting|year=2006|publisher=Jacana|location=Houghton [South Africa]|isbn=978-1-77009-198-6|page=29|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WauaC7M0yGcC&pg=PA29|edition=Updated 4th |df=mdy-all}} to over 20 years{{cite book|author=Charles B. Hicks, MD|editor=Jacques W. A. J. Reeders & Philip Charles Goodman|title=Radiology of AIDS|year=2001|publisher=Springer|location=Berlin [u.a.]|isbn=978-3-540-66510-6|page=19|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xmFBtyPGOQIC&pg=PA19 |df=mdy-all}} (on average, about eight years).{{cite book|last=Elliott|first=Tom|title=Lecture Notes: Medical Microbiology and Infection|year=2012|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-1-118-37226-5|page=273|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=M4q3AyDQIUYC&pg=PA273 |df=mdy-all}} While typically there are few or no symptoms at first, near the end of this stage many people experience fever, weight loss, gastrointestinal problems and muscle pains. Between 50 and 70% of people also develop [[persistent generalized lymphadenopathy]], characterized by unexplained, non-painful enlargement of more than one group of lymph nodes (other than in the groin) for over three to six months. Although most [[HIV-1]] infected individuals have a detectable viral load and in the absence of treatment will eventually progress to AIDS, a small proportion (about 5%) retain high levels of CD4+ T cells ([[T helper cell]]s) without [[Management of HIV/AIDS|antiretroviral therapy]] for more than 5 years. These individuals are classified as "HIV controllers" or [[long-term nonprogressors]] (LTNP).{{cite journal | vauthors = Blankson JN | title = Control of HIV-1 replication in elite suppressors | journal = Discovery Medicine | volume = 9 | issue = 46 | pages = 261–6 | date = March 2010 | pmid = 20350494 }} Another group consists of those who maintain a low or undetectable viral load without anti-retroviral treatment, known as "elite controllers" or "elite suppressors". They represent approximately 1 in 300 infected persons.{{cite journal | vauthors = Walker BD | title = Elite control of HIV Infection: implications for vaccines and treatment | journal = Topics in HIV Medicine | volume = 15 | issue = 4 | pages = 134–6 | date = Aug–Sep 2007 | pmid = 17720999 }} ===Acquired immunodeficiency syndrome=== [[File:Symptoms of AIDS.svg|thumb|upright=1.25|alt=A diagram of a human torso labelled with the most common symptoms of AIDS|Main symptoms of AIDS.]] Acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) is defined in terms of either a CD4+ T cell count below 200 cells per µL or the occurrence of specific diseases in association with an HIV infection. In the absence of specific treatment, around half of people infected with HIV develop AIDS within ten years. The most common initial conditions that alert to the presence of AIDS are [[pneumocystis pneumonia]] (40%), [[cachexia]] in the form of HIV wasting syndrome (20%), and [[esophageal candidiasis]]. Other common signs include recurrent [[respiratory tract infection]]s. [[Opportunistic infections]] may be caused by [[bacteria]], [[virus]]es, [[fungi]], and [[parasite]]s that are normally controlled by the immune system.{{cite journal | vauthors = Holmes CB, Losina E, Walensky RP, Yazdanpanah Y, Freedberg KA | title = Review of human immunodeficiency virus type 1-related opportunistic infections in sub-Saharan Africa | journal = Clinical Infectious Diseases | volume = 36 | issue = 5 | pages = 652–62 | date = March 2003 | pmid = 12594648 | doi = 10.1086/367655 }} Which infections occur depends partly on what organisms are common in the person's environment. These infections may affect nearly every [[biological system|organ system]].{{cite journal | vauthors = Chu C, Selwyn PA | title = Complications of HIV infection: a systems-based approach | journal = American Family Physician | volume = 83 | issue = 4 | pages = 395–406 | date = February 2011 | pmid = 21322514 }} People with AIDS have an increased risk of developing various viral-induced cancers, including [[Kaposi's sarcoma]], [[Burkitt's lymphoma]], [[primary central nervous system lymphoma]], and [[cervical cancer]]. Kaposi's sarcoma is the most common cancer occurring in 10 to 20% of people with HIV.Mandell, Bennett, and Dolan (2010). Chapter 169. The second most common cancer is lymphoma, which is the cause of death of nearly 16% of people with AIDS and is the initial sign of AIDS in 3 to 4%. Both these cancers are associated with [[Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus|human herpesvirus 8]] (HHV-8). Cervical cancer occurs more frequently in those with AIDS because of its association with [[human papillomavirus]] (HPV). [[Conjunctiva|Conjunctival cancer]] (of the layer that lines the inner part of eyelids and the white part of the eye) is also more common in those with HIV.{{cite journal | vauthors = Mittal R, Rath S, Vemuganti GK | title = Ocular surface squamous neoplasia - Review of etio-pathogenesis and an update on clinico-pathological diagnosis | journal = Saudi Journal of Ophthalmology | volume = 27 | issue = 3 | pages = 177–86 | date = July 2013 | pmid = 24227983 | pmc = 3770226 | doi = 10.1016/j.sjopt.2013.07.002 }} Additionally, people with AIDS frequently have systemic symptoms such as prolonged fevers, [[Night sweats|sweats]] (particularly at night), swollen lymph nodes, chills, weakness, and [[cachexia|unintended weight loss]].{{cite web|title=AIDS|url=https://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/ency/article/000594.htm|website=MedlinePlus|publisher=A.D.A.M.|access-date=June 14, 2012|deadurl=no|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120618135541/http://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/ency/article/000594.htm|archive-date=June 18, 2012|df=mdy-all}} Diarrhea is another common symptom, present in about 90% of people with AIDS.{{cite journal | vauthors = Sestak K | title = Chronic diarrhea and AIDS: insights into studies with non-human primates | journal = Current HIV Research | volume = 3 | issue = 3 | pages = 199–205 | date = July 2005 | pmid = 16022653 | doi = 10.2174/1570162054368084 }} They can also be affected by diverse psychiatric and neurological symptoms independent of opportunistic infections and cancers.{{cite book|title=Bradley's Neurology in Clinical Practice: Expert Consult – Online and Print, 6e (Bradley, Neurology in Clinical Practice e-dition 2v Set)|year=2012|publisher=Elsevier/Saunders|location=Philadelphia, PA|isbn=978-1-4377-0434-1|vauthors=Murray ED, Buttner N, Price BH |volume=1|edition=6th|pages=101|veditors=Bradley WG, Daroff RB, Fenichel GM, Jankovic J |chapter=Depression and Psychosis in Neurological Practice}} == Transmission == {{Risk of acquiring HIV}} HIV is transmitted by three main routes: [[human sexual activity|sexual contact]], significant exposure to infected body fluids or tissues, and from mother to child during pregnancy, delivery, or breastfeeding (known as [[vertical transmission]]).
