The television and [[newspaper]]s closely follow this cherry blossom front, as it slowly moves from South to North.{{cite book |last= Akasegawa |first= Genpei | authorlink= Genpei Akasegawa |year=2000 | title= Sennin no sakura, zokujin no sakura: Nippon kaibo kiko |language= Japanese |publisher= JTB Nihon Kotsu Kosha Shuppan Jigyokyoku |isbn= 978-4-533-01983-8 |quote=As cherry blossom front comes up, the whole Japan goes into a war; we just can't sit home and let it go.|url=http://www.ktv.co.jp/hanami/2005/daily/050420.html |location=Osaka Seikei University, [[Kyoto]], Japan }} In 2018 blossoms were scheduled to open in Fukuoka on March 21st, in Kyoto March 27th, in Tokyo March 26th and Sapporo May 1st. |url=https://www.foodiesgolocal.com/cuisine-and-culture/the-food-file/hanami-sakura-food-drink-cherry-blossoms.html | The ''hanami'' celebrations usually involve eating and drinking, and playing and listening to music. Some special dishes are prepared and eaten at the occasion, like ''[[dango]]'' and ''[[bento]]'', and [[sake]] is commonly drunk as part of the festivity. File:"TORINUKE" in 201604 003.JPG|Hanami through the "Tunnel" at [[Japan Mint]] in [[Osaka]], 2016 File:Bunkyo-tokyo-japan-hanami-april2015.ogv|(video) Hanami picknickers in [[Bunkyō]], 2015 File:Maruyama Koen hanami.jpg|''Hanami'' at Maruyama Park behind Yasaka Shrine in [[Kyoto]], 2014 File:Kamogawa hanami.jpg|Hanami parties along the [[Kamo River]], 2005 File:Hanami 2006.jpg|A blossom forecast for 2006, with the predicted dates of blossoms. The numbers are for dates (3.22 is March 22). Note the ''"cherry blossom front"'' moves from South to North. File:Hanami bento by Blue Lotus.jpg|A colourful collection of sweet and savoury snacks to nibble on between sips of sake, while admiring the cherry blossoms. ==Outside Japan== [[File:Chblossomfest.JPG|thumb|left|[[International Cherry Blossom Festival]] in [[Macon, Georgia]]]] Smaller ''hanami'' celebrations take place in Taiwan, Korea, the Philippines, and China.{{cite web | url=http://english.seoul.go.kr/today/news/event/1243608_3328.html | title=''Spring flower festival events'' | publisher=[[Seoul]] Metropolitan Government | accessdate=August 18, 2007 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090202003621/http://english.seoul.go.kr/today/news/event/1243608_3328.html | archivedate=February 2, 2009 | df= }} In the United States, ''hanami'' has also become very popular. In 1912, Japan gave 3,000 sakura trees as a gift to the United States to celebrate the nations' friendship. These trees were planted in [[Washington, D.C.]], and another 3,800 trees were donated in 1965.{{cite web |url=http://www.nps.gov/cherry/cherry-blossom-history.htm |title=HISTORY OF THE CHERRY TREES |publisher=National Park Service, United States }} These sakura trees continue to be a popular tourist attraction, and every year, the [[National Cherry Blossom Festival]] takes place when they bloom in early spring.{{cite web | url=http://www.nationalcherryblossomfestival.org/ | title=National Cherry Blossom Festiva | publisher= Official Site | accessdate=August 16, 2007 }} In [[Macon, Georgia]], another cherry blossom festival called the [[International Cherry Blossom Festival]] is celebrated every spring. Macon is known as the Cherry Blossom Capital of the World, because 300,000 sakura trees grow there.{{cite web | url=http://www.cbfmacon.com/index.php?saturday,_march_24th | title=International Cherry Blossom Festival Online | publisher= Official Site | accessdate=August 16, 2007 }} In [[Brooklyn|Brooklyn, New York]], the Annual Sakura [[Matsuri]] Cherry Blossom Festival takes place in May, at the [[Brooklyn Botanic Garden]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bbg.org/abo/pressroom/special/2007/2007hanami.html |title=''Brooklyn Botanic Garden Celebrates Hanami'' |publisher=Brooklyn Botanic Garden, Brooklyn, New York |accessdate=August 17, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070808145320/http://www.bbg.org/abo/pressroom/special/2007/2007hanami.html |archivedate=August 8, 2007 }} This festivity has been celebrated since 1981, and is one of the Garden's most famous attractions. Similar celebrations are also held in [[Philadelphia]]{{cite web | url=http://jasgp.org/sakura/ | title=''Subaru Cherry Blossom Festival of Greater Philadelphia'' | publisher= Japan America Society of Greater Philadelphia, [[Philadelphia|Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]] | accessdate=August 17, 2007 }} and other places through the United States. The largest collection of sakura in the United States is in [[Newark, New Jersey]]'s [[Branch Brook Park]], whose over 5,000 cherry trees of 18 varieties attract 10,000 visitors a day during its annual Cherry Blossom Festival.{{ cite web | url=http://www.essexcountyparks.org/parks/branch-brook-park/faqs | title=Branch Brook Park FAQs | accessdate=March 26, 2016 }}{{cite news|last1=Di Ionno|first1=Mark|title=The story behind Branch Brook Park's cherry blossom trees|url=http://www.nj.com/news/index.ssf/2016/03/the_story_behind_branch_brook_parks_cherry_blossom.html|accessdate=9 February 2018|work=The Star-Ledger|date=27 March 2016}} Hanami is also celebrated in several European countries. For example, in Finland people gather to celebrate hanami in Helsinki at Roihuvuori. Local Japanese people and companies have donated 200 cherry trees which are all planted in [[Kirsikkapuisto]]. Those cherry trees usually bloom in mid-May. In [[Rome]], in Italy, the hanami is celebrated in the park of the Eur, where are a lot of cherry trees were donated by Japan in 1959.{{cite web|url=http://www.rerumromanarum.com/2015/04/passeggiata-del-giappone.html|title="Passeggiata del Giappone"}} In Stockholm there is an annual [http://sivertlindblom.se/folio/offentliga-arbeten/exteriorer/kungstradgarden-norra-delen-1997-98/ festivity in Kungsträdgården [22]] where a lot of people celebrate hanami. [http://sivertlindblom.se/hanami-korsbarsblomningen-i-kungstradgarden/ [23]] ==See also== *[[Leaf peeping|Momijigari]], autumn leaf viewing *[[Subaru Cherry Blossom Festival of Greater Philadelphia]] *[[Tsukimi]], moon viewing ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Hanami}} *[http://www.jasgp.org/cherryblossomfestival Hanami in Philadelphia! Information on the Subaru Cherry Blossom Festival of Greater Philadelphia] *[http://watch.opb.org/video/2334984303/ Hanami] Documentary produced by [[Oregon Field Guide]] *[http://www.japanzine.jp/article/jz/1093/field-guide-to-japan-hanami-fun-facts ''Hanami Fun Facts''] — ''Japanzine:Field Guide to Japan'' by Zack Davisson *[http://www.japanzine.jp/article/jz/1082/hanami-manners-101 ''Hanami Manners 101''] — ''Japanzine'' by Emily Millar *[http://www.kyotoview.com/ ''Kyotoview''] — ''Hanami In Kyoto *[https://sakura.weathermap.jp/en.php ''Cherry Blossom Forecast''] Yearly map of blossoms in Japan [[Category:Cherry blossom]] [[Category:Festivals in Japan]] [[Category:Hanami spots of Japan]] [[Category:Flower festivals]] [[Category:Spring festivals]] [[Category:Articles containing video clips]] [[Category:Flower festivals in Japan]] [[Category:Cherry blossom festivals]]

revision.comment: fix some ref
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=August 2018}} [[File:Peruvanam KuttanMarar.JPG|thumb|right|[[Peruvanam Kuttan Marar]], leader of 'Chenda' group of [[Paramekkavu Bagavathi Temple]] performing at [[Thrissur Pooram]]]] [[File:GKN Thrissoor Pooram Ilanji Thara DSC 0839.JPG|thumb|right|Ilanjithara where melam is performed, in the date of pooram]] '''Ilanjithara Melam''' is an assembly of percussion performance artist held at ''Ilanji'' (known as Bullet Wood tree [[Mimusops elengi]]) tree at the courtyard of the [[Vadakkunnathan Temple]] in [[Thrissur]] city during the [[Thrissur Pooram]]. It is considered as one of the best platforms for traditional [[Kerala]] music and the largest assembly of percussion artistes in any other Poorams. The ''Melam'' in technical exactness and instrumental discipline are the best example of ''[[Pandi Melam]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hindu.com/2011/05/13/stories/2011051363560300.htm |title=A feast to the ears of percussion lovers |newspaper=The Hindu |accessdate=2013-04-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hindu.com/2006/05/08/stories/2006050804630300.htm |title=Ilanjithara Melam drums up high excitement |newspaper=The Hindu |accessdate=2013-04-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-features/tp-editorialfeatures/drumming-up-excitement/article3371998.ece |title=DRUMMING up excitement |newspaper=The Hindu |accessdate=2013-04-16}}</ref>
==The Melam== The ''[[Pandi Melam]]'' of [[Paramekkavu Bagavathi Temple]] is known as ''Ilanjithara Melam''. The ''Melam'' begin at the ''Ilanjithara'' in the [[Vadakkunnathan Temple]] around 2.30 PM, and goes for around four continuous hours. The base of ''[[Pandi Melam]]'' is the ''Tripuda Thaalam''. Correct number of instrumentalists participating in ''Melam'' is 222. But more than 250 instrumentalists assemble because of its prominence and various other reasons. 100 ''[[Chenda]]s'' (In ''Edanthala'' and ''Valanthala'' categories), 75 ''[[Elathalam]]s'' 21 ''[[Kombu (instrument)|Kombu]]'' and 21 ''Kurunkuzhal'' is the number of instruments in each category. There are 7 types of ''Melangal'' viz ''Panchari'', ''Champa'', ''Chempada'', ''Adantha'', ''Anchadatha'', ''Druvam'' and ''Pandy''. ''Adantha Thalam'' (14 Aksharas) is the ''Thalam'' performed in the ''Ilanjithara Melam''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hindu.com/2008/04/17/stories/2008041753970300.htm |title=Ilanjithara melam attracts hundreds |newspaper=The Hindu |accessdate=2013-04-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/kerala/lakhs-witness-thrissur-pooram/article3374528.ece |title=Lakhs witness Thrissur Pooram |newspaper=The Hindu |accessdate=2013-04-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.keralatourism.org/audio-clips/ilanjithara-melam-117.php |title=Ilanjithara Melam |publisher=Department of Tourism, Government of Kerala |accessdate=2013-04-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hindu.com/2011/05/08/stories/2011050858610300.htm |title=Melam artistes should not play to the gallery: Peruvanam |newspaper=The Hindu |accessdate=2013-04-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hindu.com/2008/04/16/stories/2008041650920200.htm |title=Peruvanam to pep up Pandimelam |newspaper=The Hindu |accessdate=2013-04-16}}</ref>
==Chiefs (''Pramanis'') of ''Ilanjithara Melam''== [[Peruvanam Kuttan Marar]] is the current Chief of ''Ilanjithara Melam''. He joined [[Paramekkavu Bagavathi Temple]] team in 1977 and later became its leader in 1999. He has been the Chief for 18 years and has been associated with ''Ilanjithara Melam'' for 35 years. Kuzhoor Narayana Marar, another veteran percussionist, was also part of the Paramekkavu team for 41 years. He was its Chief for 12 years.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-kerala/a-feast-to-the-ears-of-percussion-lovers/article2014535.ece |title=A feast to the ears of percussion lovers |newspaper=The Hindu |accessdate=2013-04-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-kerala/kuzhoor-narayana-marar-passes-away/article2349398.ece |title=Kuzhoor Narayana Marar passes away |newspaper=The Hindu |accessdate=2013-04-17}}</ref>
===Chiefs=== * Pandaarathil Eachara Marar - 1940s * Peruvanam Narayana Marar * Peruvanam Appu Marar - 1960s * Thrippekkulam Achutha Marar * Pallavoor Appu Marar * [[Peruvanam Kuttan Marar]] (1999-)
==References== <references/> {{Tourist attractions in Thrissur}} {{Culture of Kerala}} {{Tourism in Kerala}}

التحالف الإسلامي العسكري لمحاربة الإرهاب | native_name = | native_name_lang = | named_after = | image_size = 150 | map_caption = {{legend|#009900|Founding members}}{{legend|#00e000|Additional members}}{{legend|#ff0000|Former members}} | map2 = | map2_caption = | abbreviation = | founder = | founding_location = | merger = | tax_id = | registration_id = | location = Africa
[[Middle East]]
[[South Asia]] | region = [[Muslim world]] | products = | methods = | fields = | membership = {{Collapsible list |bullets=yes |title= |{{flag|Afghanistan}} |{{flag|Bahrain}} |{{flag|Bangladesh}} |{{flag|Benin}} |{{flag|Brunei}} |{{flag|Burkina Faso}} |{{flag|Chad}} |{{flag|Comoros}} |{{flag|Cote d'Ivoire}} |{{flag|Djibouti}} |{{flag|Egypt}} |{{flag|Gabon}} |{{flag|Gambia}} |{{flag|Guinea}} |{{flag|Guinea-Bissau}} |{{flag|Jordan}} |{{flag|Kuwait}} |{{flag|Lebanon}} |{{flag|Libya}} |{{flag|Malaysia}} |{{flag|Maldives}} |{{flag|Mali}} |{{flag|Mauritania}} |{{flag|Morocco}} |{{flag|Niger}} |{{flag|Nigeria}} |{{flag|Oman}} |{{flag|Pakistan}} |{{flag|Palestine}} |{{flag|Qatar}} |{{flag|Saudi Arabia}} |{{flag|Senegal}} |{{flag|Sierra Leone}} |{{flag|Somalia}} |{{flag|Sudan}} |{{flag|Togo}} |{{flag|Tunisia}} |{{flag|Turkey}} |{{flag|Uganda}} |{{flag|United Arab Emirates}} |{{flag|Yemen}} }} | membership_year = | owner = | sec_gen = | secessions = | budget_year = | revenue = | revenue_year = | disbursements = | expenses = | expenses_year = | endowment = | staff = | staff_year = | volunteers_year = | mission = | website = {{URL|https://imctc.org}} }} The '''Islamic Military Counter Terrorism Coalition''' ('''IMCTC''') {{nowrap|({{lang-ar|التحالف الإسلامي العسكري لمحاربة الإرهاب}})}}, and also formerly referred to as the '''Islamic Military Alliance to Fight Terrorism''' ('''IMAFT'''), is an intergovernmental counter-terrorist alliance of countries in the [[Muslim world]], united around [[military intervention against ISIL]] and other [[counter-terrorism|counter-terrorist]] activities.{{Cite web|title = Joint statement on formation of Islamic military alliance to fight terrorism|publisher=Kingdom of Saudi Arabia - Ministry of Foreign Affairs |url = http://embassies.mofa.gov.sa/sites/usa/EN/PublicAffairs/Statements/Pages/Joint-Statement-on-the-Formation-of-the-Islamic-Military-Alliance.aspx |date=15 December 2015 |accessdate = 11 March 2017}}{{cite web|title=Islamic military coalition holds first meeting in Riyadh |url=http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/saudi-arabia/islamic-military-coalition-holds-first-meeting-in-riyadh-1.1698994 |website=Gulf News|accessdate=11 April 2016}} Its creation was first announced by Saudi Arabian [[Minister of Defense (Saudi Arabia)|defence minister]] [[Mohammad bin Salman Al Saud]], on 15 December 2015.{{Cite web |title = Saudi Arabia Unveils 34-Country 'Islamic Military Alliance'|url = http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/isis-terror/saudi-arabia-unveils-islamic-military-alliance-against-terrorism-n480016|website = NBC News|accessdate = 2015-12-15}}{{Cite news|title = Saudi Arabia launches 'Islamic military alliance' to combat terrorism |url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/saudi-arabia-launches-islamic-military-alliance-to-combat-terrorism/2015/12/15/ad568a1c-a361-11e5-9c4e-be37f66848bb_story.html|newspaper = The Washington Post|date = 2015-12-15|access-date = 2015-12-16|issn = 0190-8286|first = Karen|last = DeYoung}} The alliance was to have a joint operations center in [[Riyadh]], Saudi Arabia. When the coalition was announced there were 34 members. Additional countries joined and the number of members reached 41 when [[Oman]] joined in December 2016. On 6 January 2017, the Pakistani former chief of Army Staff, General (retd.) [[Raheel Sharif]] was named the IMCTC's first commander-in-chief.{{cite web |url=https://www.geo.tv/latest/126414-defence-minister-Asif-confirms-Raheel-Sharifs-appointment-to-Islamic-military-alliance-saudi-arabia-led|title=Defence minister confirms Raheel Sharif's appointment to Islamic military alliance |publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://khaleejtimes.com/international/pakistan/paks-raheel-sharif-appointed-chief-of-saudi-led-military-coalition|title=Pak's Raheel Sharif appointed chief of Saudi-led military coalition|first=|last=PTI|date=|website=khaleejtimes.com|accessdate=14 April 2018}} Most of its participants are members of the [[Organisation of Islamic Cooperation]]. == History and objectives == The IMCTC has stated that its primary objective is to protect Muslim countries from all terrorist groups and terrorist organizations irrespective of their sect and name.{{Cite web|title = UAE joins Muslim military alliance to fight terrorism|url = http://7days.ae/uae-joins-muslim-military-alliance-fight-terrorism/77577|website = 7DAYS UAE|accessdate = 2015-12-20}}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{Cite web|title=Turkey joins Saudi-led Islamic military alliance against terrorism |url=http://www.todayszaman.com/diplomacy_turkey-joins-saudi-led-islamic-military-alliance-against-terrorism_407008.html |website=TodaysZaman |accessdate=2015-12-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151219094948/http://www.todayszaman.com/diplomacy_turkey-joins-saudi-led-islamic-military-alliance-against-terrorism_407008.html |archivedate=2015-12-19 |df= }}{{Cite web|title = UAE joins 34-nation anti-terrorist military coalition {{!}} The National|url = http://www.thenational.ae/world/middle-east/uae-joins-34-nation-anti-terrorist-military-coalition|website = www.thenational.ae|accessdate = 2015-12-20}} The IMCTC affirmed that it would operate in line with the [[United Nations]] and [[Organisation of Islamic Cooperation]] (OIC) provisions on terrorism.{{Cite web|title = Islamic military alliance|url = http://aaj.tv/2015/12/islamic-military-alliance/ |website = Aaj News|accessdate = 2015-12-22}} At the press conference to launch the IMCTC, Mohammad bin Salman said it would "coordinate" efforts to fight terrorism in Iraq, Syria, Libya, Egypt and Afghanistan. He said, "There will be international coordination with major powers and international organisations ... in terms of operations in Syria and Iraq." To date, all members are countries with [[Sunni Islam|Sunni]]-dominated governments. The alliance does not include any countries with [[Shia Islam|Shia]]-dominated governments, such as Iran, Iraq and Syria. According to a Euronews report, some analysts see formation of the alliance as part of Saudi Arabian efforts to take the leading role in the Middle East and the Muslim world, in [[Iran–Saudi Arabia proxy conflict|rivalry with Iran]]. In March 2016 it was reported that Saudi Arabia had asked General Raheel Sharif, Pakistan's Chief of Army Staff, to become commander-in-chief of the Islamic Military Alliance once he had retired from the Pakistan Army at the end of 2016.{{cite news |title=Saudi Arabia 'wants' Gen Raheel Sharif to command 34-nation Saudi alliance |first=Ali |last=Zain |url= https://en.dailypakistan.com.pk/headline/is-gen-raheel-sharif-going-to-command-saudi-arabia-led-34-country-anti-terrorism-alliance/ |newspaper=Daily Pakistan |date=10 March 2016 |accessdate=12 March 2017}} ==Members== Saudi Arabia's original announcement of the alliance on 15 December 2015 listed 34 countries as participants, each also a member of the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation (OIC), and forming about 60% of all [[member states of the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation|OIC member states]]. As of November, 2017, there are 41 member countries.{{Cite web|url=https://imctc.org/English|title=Home|website=imctc.org|language=en|access-date=2017-11-21}} {| class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size:100%; text-align:left" |- ! Country !! Membership announcement !! Military role{{ref|Alpha|α}} !! Supporter !! http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/12/saudi-arabia-forms-muslim-anti-terrorism-coalition-151215035914865.html|website = www.aljazeera.com|accessdate = 2015-12-16}}{{Cite web|title = Saudis announce || |- |{{flag|Uganda}} | | | | |- |{{flag|United Arab Emirates}} || Original || {{yes}} || {{yes}} || {{citation needed|date=January 2016}} |- |{{flag|Yemen}} || Original || {{yes}} || {{yes}} || |} :{{note|Alpha|α}} These countries have offered to provide military assistance if needed. ===Prospective additional members=== At the time of the original announcement, more than ten other Islamic countries, including Indonesia (the world's largest Muslim nation), had expressed their support for the alliance, and Azerbaijan was discussing joining the alliance.{{cite news|author1=Wam|title=34-nation alliance to fight terrorism|url=http://www.emirates247.com/news/34-nation-alliance-to-fight-terrorism-2015-12-16-1.614174|accessdate=17 December 2015|work=Emirates 24/7|date=16 December 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2015/12/16/indonesia-yet-decide-saudi-led-military-coalition.html|title=Indonesia yet to decide on Saudi-led military coalition|work=The Jakarta Post|author=Marguerite Afra Sapiie |date=2015-12-16 |accessdate=2015-12-19}}{{cite web |url= http://www.azernews.az/azerbaijan/90814.html |title=Baku considers joining Riyadh-based coalition to fight terrorism |publisher=AzerNews |author=Sara Rajabova |date=2015-12-15 |accessdate=2015-12-19}} By January 2017, Azerbaijan said that joining was "not on the agenda".{{cite news |title=Azerbaijan says joining Islamic Military Alliance not on its foreign policy agenda |url= http://en.apa.az/azerbaijan-politics/foreign-news/azerbaijan-decides-to-join-islamic-military-alliance.html |newspaper=Azeri-Press Agency |date=9 January 2017 |accessdate=11 March 2017}} Tajikistan's ambassador to Saudi Arabia confirmed that Tajikistan was seriously studying the possibility of joining.{{Cite web |title = Tajikistan, Azerbaijan to Join Islamic Coalition |url = http://english.aawsat.com/2015/12/article55345930/55345930 |website = Asharq Al-Awsat |accessdate = 2016-01-03 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20151224093127/http://english.aawsat.com/2015/12/article55345930/55345930# |archive-date = 2015-12-24 |dead-url = yes |df = }}{{Cite web|title = Tajikistan reportedly plans to join Muslim anti-terror coalition formed by Saudi Arabia |url = http://news.tj/en/news/tajikistan-reportedly-plans-join-muslim-anti-terror-coalition-formed-saudi-arabia |website = Asia-Plus |accessdate = 2016-01-03}} ==Commanders-in-Chief== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Force commander !! Nationality !! Start of tenure !! End of tenure |- | {{sort|Shareef, Raheel|General [[Raheel Shareef]]}} || {{flag|Pakistan}} || {{sort|2017-01-06|6 January 2017}} || Incumbent |} Raheel Sharif as Commander-in-Chief is appointed to head a Saudi-led alliance of Muslim countries.{{Cite news |url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1306798/raheel-sharif-appointed-chief-of-islamic-military-alliance-confirms-khawaja-asif|title=Yes |newspaper=DAWN.COM|access-date=2017-04-09}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/02/world/asia/pakistan-general-saudi-alliance-raheel-sharif.html?_r=0|title=Pakistan Approves Military Hero to Head Tricky Saudi-Led Alliance: Report|newspaper=www.nytimes.com|access-date=2017-04-09}} ==Reactions== ;State
*{{flag|Bangladesh}}: Bangladesh was one of the early members to join the alliance doing so on 15 December 2015. The country confirmed its membership in a joint statement by the founder nations that stated "a duty to protect the Islamic nation from the evils of all terrorist groups and organizations whatever their sect and name which wreak death and corruption on earth and aim to terrorize the innocent."{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/city/bangladesh-%E2%80%98joins%E2%80%99-riyadh-based-anti-terrorism-coalition-187609|title=Bangladesh in 34-state Islamic military alliance|date=15 December 2015|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://archive.dhakatribune.com/bangladesh/2015/dec/16/bangladesh-joins-saudi-backed-anti-alliance|title=Bangladesh joins Saudi-backed anti-IS alliance|publisher=[[Dhaka Tribune]]}}{{cite web|url=http://www.samakal.net/2015/12/15/1783|title=Bangladesh joins Saudi-led 'Islamic military alliance'|publisher=}} *{{flag|China}}: China has expressed its willingness to cooperate with the alliance to fighting terrorism and appreciated Saudi efforts to create alliance.{{cite news|title=China backs Islamic Military Alliance to fight terrorism|url=http://www.arabnews.com/world/news/852756|accessdate=2015-12-19|work=Arab News|date=2017-06-22}} *{{flag|Egypt}}: Egypt's [[Al-Azhar University]] called the alliance's formation "historic."{{cite news|title=Egypt's Azhar says Saudi decision to form Islamic military alliance 'historic'|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/173597/Egypt/Politics-/Egypts-Azhar-says-Saudi-decision-to-form-Islamic-m.aspx|accessdate=17 December 2015|work=Ahram Online|date=15 December 2015}} *{{flag|Germany}}: Germany's defense minister Ursula von der Leyen welcomed the alliance against terrorism but also stressed that it should be a part of the Vienna process involving all countries fighting against IS like the U.S., Europe, Russia, Turkey, Saudi Arabia, but also including Iran and China.{{Cite web|title = Germany welcomes 34-state Islamic military alliance against terrorism|url = http://www.businessinsider.com/r-germany-welcomes-34-state-islamic-military-alliance-against-terrorism-2015-12|website = Business Insider|accessdate = 2016-01-05}} *{{flag|Malaysia}}: Malaysian Defence Minister [[Hishammuddin Hussein]] expressed support for the alliance, but ruled out any military support from Malaysia. *{{flag|Pakistan}}: After initial ambiguity Pakistan welcomed the initiative; its government confirmed its participation and stated that the country is waiting for further details in order to decide the extent of its participation in the different activities of the alliance. Although the Commander in Chief of the IMCTC, Gen Raheel Sharif only agreed to command upon the condition that Iran must be the part of this Alliance. *{{flag|Turkey}}: Turkey's Prime Minister [[Ahmet Davutoğlu]] called it the "best response to those who are trying to associate terror and Islam". *{{flag|United States}}: The new alliance has been welcomed by the United States, with then U.S. Secretary of Defense [[Ash Carter]] saying, "We look forward to learning more about what Saudi Arabia has in mind in terms of this coalition. But in general it appears it is very much in line with something we've been urging for quite some time, which is greater involvement in the campaign to combat ISIL by Sunni Arab countries. ;Other * {{flagdeco|Ba'athist Iraq}} [[Army of the Men of the Naqshbandi Order]]: [[Izzat Ibrahim al-Douri]] the leader of the Naqshbandi Army released a statement in 2016 praising the alliance and calling on what he called [[Mujahideen]] to fight Shia militias in Iraq backed by Iran, while also saying "We consider everything that is happening in Iraq from Iran, its agents, militias, and its security apparatus, is the responsibility of the United States". He added: "If it [U.S.] did not move to save Iraq and its people from Iran's hegemony, control and occupation, and to stop bloodshed, destruction, burning and the changing demographic, then Iraqi people should resist [the occupation]."http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2016/04/07/Saddam-s-top-aide-appears-calls-to-line-up-against-Iran.html ==Criticism== Due to the dominance of the alliance by states having majority [[Sunni]] Muslim populations, it has been called "a [[Shia–Sunni relations|sectarian coalition]]" by Hakeem Azameli, a member of the Security and Defense Commission in the Iraqi parliament.{{cite news|author1=Serguei Doubine |author2=Behnam Masoumi |author3=Riad Muasses|author4=Rita Del Prete|title=What do Russia and Iran think about Saudi Arabia's coalition initiative?|url=http://www.euronews.com/2015/12/15/what-do-russia-and-iran-think-about-saudi-arabia-s-coalition-initiative/|accessdate=17 December 2015|work=euronews|date=15 December 2015}}{{cite news|title=Turkey joins Sunni 'anti-terrorist' military coalition |url= http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/turkey-joins-sunni-anti-terrorist-military-coalition-.aspx?PageID=238&NID=92529&NewsCatID=352 |accessdate=17 December 2015|agency=Agence France-Presse |date=15 December 2015}} However, Oman, an [[Ibadi]]-dominant country and friend of Iran has joined the alliance. Lebanon has also supported the alliance. Other countries who are part of the alliance or support it that have cordial or friendly relations with Iran include Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Kuwait, Libya, Pakistan and Indonesia. More likely, the absence of Iran and Iraq from the alliance is due to the [[Iran–Saudi Arabia relations|political tension between Saudi Arabia and Iran]].{{cite web|url=http://www.arabnews.com/saudi-arabia/news/851666|title=To join alliance, Iran ‘must change policy’|author=|date=17 December 2015|website=arabnews.com|accessdate=14 April 2018}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[https://imctc.org/English Islamic Military Counter Terrorism Coalition] (official website) [[Category:21st-century military alliances]] [[Category:Counter-terrorist organizations]] [[Category:Iran–Saudi Arabia relations]] [[Category:Military alliances involving Afghanistan]] [[Category:Military alliances involving Bahrain]] [[Category:Military alliances involving Bangladesh]] [[Category:Military alliances involving Egypt]] [[Category:Military alliances involving Jordan]] [[Category:Military alliances involving Kuwait]] [[Category:Military alliances involving Lebanon]] [[Category:Military alliances involving Libya]] [[Category:Military alliances involving Malaysia]] [[Category:Military alliances involving Morocco]] [[Category:Military alliances involving Nigeria]] [[Category:Military alliances involving Oman]] [[Category:Military alliances involving Pakistan]] [[Category:Military alliances involving Qatar]] [[Category:Military alliances involving Saudi Arabia]] [[Category:Military alliances involving Sudan]] [[Category:Military alliances involving Tunisia]] [[Category:Military alliances involving Turkey]] [[Category:Military alliances involving the United Arab Emirates]] [[Category:Military alliances involving Yemen]] [[Category:Organisations based in Riyadh]] [[Category:Organizations established in 2015]] [[Category:Organisation of Islamic Cooperation]] [[Category:Supraorganizations]] [[Category:Wars involving the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]]

revision.comment: standard quote handling in WP;standard Apostrophe/quotation marks in WP; MOS general fixes
revision.text:
On February 21, 2008, in the midst of [[John McCain]]'s [[John McCain presidential campaign, 2008|campaign]] in the [[Republican Party (United States) President primaries, 2008|2008 Republican presidential primaries]], both ''[[The New York Times]]'' and the ''[[Washington Post]]'' published articles detailing rumors of an improper relationship between [[John McCain]] and [[lobbyist]] [[Vicki Iseman]].{{cite news | author=[[Jim Rutenberg]], Marilyn W. Thompson, [[David D. Kirkpatrick]], [[Stephen Labaton]] | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/02/21/us/politics/21mccain.html?_r=1&bl&ex=1203656400&en=d0734db651c10475&ei=5087%0A&oref=slogin | title=For McCain, Self-Confidence on Ethics Poses Its Own Risk | publisher=''[[The New York Times]]'' | date=February 21, 2008}} According to ''The New York Times'' story, McCain, who was a member of the Senate Commerce Committee during the period when Iseman was lobbying the committee, developed a close personal relationship with Iseman. The ''New York Times'' came under intense criticism for the article because of its use of anonymous sources and its timing. In December 2008, Iseman filed a [[US$]]27 million [[defamation]] lawsuit against ''The New York Times'', alleging that the paper falsely communicated an illicit romantic relationship between her and McCain.{{cite news|first=Paul |last=Fletcher |author2=Cooper, Alan |title=BREAKING NEWS: Lobbyist Vicki Iseman files $27M suit against New York Times |url=http://www.valawyersweekly.com/weeklyedition/2008/12/30/lobbyist-vicki-iseman-files-27m-suit-against-new-york-times/ |work=[[Virginia Lawyers Weekly]] |date=30 December 2008 |accessdate=31 December 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090105043018/http://www.valawyersweekly.com/weeklyedition/2008/12/30/lobbyist-vicki-iseman-files-27m-suit-against-new-york-times/ |archivedate=January 5, 2009 }} ''The Times'' said they "fully stood behind the article" and the story was "true and accurate".{{cite web |date= December 30, 2008 |last= Johnston |first= David |pages= A15 |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2008/12/31/us/politics/31suit.html?ref=politics |title= Lobbyist Sues Times, Citing Report of McCain Ties |publisher= [[The New York Times]] |accessdate= December 30, 2008 }} The lawsuit was settled in February 2009 with no money changing hands between the parties. However, as a condition of the settlement ''The New York Times'' printed an unusual "Note to Readers" stating that ''The Times'' had not intended to allege any affair. ==McCain and the FCC== McCain wrote letters in 1998 and 1999 to the [[Federal Communications Commission]] encouraging it to uphold marketing agreements allowing a television company to control two stations in the same city, a position which Iseman had been advocating on behalf of her client Glencairn Ltd. (now [[Cunningham Broadcasting]]). McCain also introduced a bill to create tax incentives for minority ownership of stations, which several businesses Iseman represented were seeking. In February 1999, McCain and Iseman attended a small fund-raising dinner with several clients at a [[Miami]]- area home of a cruise - line executive, then flew back to Washington along with a campaign aide on the corporate jet of Paxson Communications (now [[ION Media Networks]]), one of her clients. Later in 1999, Iseman requested McCain to write to the FCC urging it to reach a speedy decision in a case involving Paxson Communications. Iseman, according to an email sent to ''The Times'', provided McCain's staff with the information to write the letter. McCain's two letters to the FCC resulted in [[William Kennard]], the FCC chairman, issuing a rare public rebuke to McCain for his interference in FCC deliberations. McCain also frequently denied requests from Iseman and the companies she represented, including attempts in 2006 to break up cable packages, something opposed by companies she represented. His proposals for satellite distribution of local television stations also failed to match the desires of Iseman's clients. Iseman said she never received special treatment from McCain's office, and McCain said he never demonstrated favoritism to Iseman or her clients. During a phone call to [[Bill Keller]], executive editor of ''The New York Times'', he said, "I have never betrayed the public trust by doing anything like that." Iseman's clients contributed tens of thousands of dollars to McCain's campaigns. ==Alleged concerns about alleged romantic relationship with McCain== {{wikinews|John McCain denies romantic relationship with lobbyist}} According to ''The Times'' story, Iseman began visiting McCain's offices and campaign events so frequently in 2000 that his aides were "convinced the relationship had become romantic". One staff member supposedly asked, "Why is she always around?" According to ''The Times'' narrative, staff aides also worried that McCain's relationship with Iseman would receive negative media attention due to the letters McCain wrote to government regulators on her behalf, especially since McCain's campaign stressed his probity and included proposals for more stringent regulation of [[lobbying in the United States]]. The ''Times'' story never explicitly alleged that an affair took place and Daniel Schnur, McCain's 2000 communication director with no current connection to the campaign, called ''The Times'' account "highly implausible". ==McCain's aides allegedly intervene to "save McCain from himself"== ''The New York Times'' and ''[[Washington Post]]'' reported that unnamed staff members began a campaign to "save McCain from himself" by restricting Iseman's access to McCain during the course of the 2000 presidential primary. According to the ''Washington Post'' story published the same day as ''The New York Times'' story, Weaver met with Iseman at [[Union Station (Washington, D.C.)]] to tell Iseman not to see McCain anymore.{{cite news |author1=Jeffrey H. Birnbaum |author2=Michael D Shear | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/02/20/AR2008022002898_pf.html | title=McCain's Ties To Lobbyist Worried Aides | publisher=''[[Washington Post]]'' | date=February 21, 2008}} Weaver, who arranged the meeting after a discussion among campaign leaders, said Iseman and he discussed "her conduct and what she allegedly had told people, which made its way back to us." Weaver heard that she was saying "she had strong ties to the Commerce Committee and his staff" and told her this was wrong and for it to stop.{{cite web |date=2008-02-21 |last=Cillizza |first=Chris |authorlink=The Fix (blog) |url=http://blog.washingtonpost.com/thefix/2008/02/john_weaver_speaks.html?hpid=topnews |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110523100640/http://blog.washingtonpost.com/thefix/2008/02/john_weaver_speaks.html?hpid=topnews |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2011-05-23 |title=John Weaver Speaks |publisher=[[The Washington Post]] |accessdate=2008-02-21 }} No discussion of a romantic involvement occurred because, according to Weaver, "there was no reason to".{{cite web |date= 2008-02-22 |last= Bash |first= Dana |authorlink= Dana Bash |author2=Bronstein, Scott |url= http://www.cnn.com/2008/POLITICS/02/22/mccain.lobbyist/ |title= Ex-McCain aide: New York Times report 'highly implausible' |publisher= [[CNN]] |accessdate=2008-02-22}} Iseman confirmed she met with Weaver, but disputed his account of the conversation. Supposedly, an unnamed campaign adviser was instructed to keep Iseman away from McCain at public events, and plans were made to limit her access to his offices. It was reported that campaign associates confronted McCain directly about the risks he was taking with campaign and career. McCain allegedly admitted he was behaving inappropriately and promised to distance himself from Iseman. Concerns about the relationship eventually receded as the campaign continued. ==Response from McCain's campaign== On February 20, the night before the article appeared in the printed newspaper, but just after the story was available online, the McCain presidential campaign issued the following statement: "It is a shame that ''The New York Times'' has lowered its standards to engage in a hit-and-run smear campaign. John McCain had a 24-year record of serving our country with honor and integrity. He has never violated the public trust, never done favors for special interests or lobbyists, and he will not allow a smear campaign to distract from the issues at stake in this election. Americans are sick and tired of this kind of gutter politics, and there is nothing in this story to suggest that John McCain has ever violated the principles that have guided his career." A McCain campaign adviser added that the report "reads like a tabloid gossip sheet".{{cite web |date= 2008-02-21 |url= http://youdecide08.foxnews.com/2008/02/21/fit-to-print-new-york-times-in-crosshairs-for-report-on-mccain-and-female-lobbyist/ |title= Fit to Print? New York Times in Crosshairs for Report on McCain and Female Lobbyist |publisher= [[Fox News]] |accessdate=2008-02-21}} [[Robert S. Bennett]], whom McCain had hired to represent him in this matter, defended McCain's character. Bennett, a registered Democrat, was the special investigator during the [[Keating Five]] scandal that ''The Times'' revisited in the article. Bennett, who was coincidentally on Fox News' ''[[Hannity and Colmes]]'' program to promote his autobiography shortly after the paper published the story on their website, said that he fully investigated McCain back then and suggested to the [[Senate Ethics Committee]] to not pursue charges against McCain.
And if there is one thing I am absolutely confident of, it is John McCain is an honest and honest man. I recommended to the Senate Ethics Committee that he be cut out of the case, that there was no evidence against him, and I think for the New York Times to dig this up just shows that Senator McCain's public statement about this is correct. It's a smear job. I'm sorry.{{cite web | title = Bob Bennett Reacts to New York Times Story on John McCain | url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,331651,00.html| accessdate = 2008-02-25 | date = February 21, 2008 |publisher = Fox News Channell |author1=Sean Hannity |author2=Alan Colmes }}
McCain spoke in a press conference the following day saying, "I'm very disappointed in the article. It's not true." He stated he never showed favoritism for her clients: "At no time have I ever done anything that would betray the public trust." He went on to characterize Iseman as a friend but no closer than other lobbyists. Both he and his wife strenuously denied any impropriety. He said he wasn't aware of the meeting Weaver had with Iseman nor of any concerns among his staff about his association.{{cite web |date= 2008-02-21 |last= Quaid |first= Libby |url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/02/21/AR2008022100343.html?hpid=topnews |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20121104085737/http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/02/21/AR2008022100343.html?hpid=topnews |dead-url= yes |archive-date= 2012-11-04 |title= McCain Says Report Is "Not True" |publisher= [[The Washington Post]] |accessdate=2008-02-21}} ==Ethics of publication questioned == ''The Times''' decision to publish the article while relying almost entirely on anonymous sources has raised ethical questions relating to the story's veracity and importance. [[George Stephanopoulos]], an ''[[ABC News]]'' correspondent, said that — while damaging — as long as the sources remain anonymous this story will not throw the campaign off course. He quoted McCain aides that they will go after ''The New York Times'' "with extreme aggression — if the newspaper was going to act like a partisan they were going to treat them as a partisan."{{cite web |date= 2008-02-21 |last= Stephanopolous |first= George |authorlink= George Stephanopoulos |url= http://abcnews.go.com/Video/playerIndex?id=4322573 |title= McCain Charges: Scandal or Smear |publisher= [[ABC News]] |accessdate=2008-02-21}} On the same day, fellow Senator [[Joe Lieberman]], who endorsed McCain for the presidency, said, "The story I think is outrageously unfair to him. There's no 'there' there."{{cite web |date= 2008-02-18 |last= Singer |first= Stephen |url= http://www.boston.com/news/local/connecticut/articles/2008/02/21/lieberman_defends_mccain_from_suggestion_of_improper_relationship/ |title= Lieberman defends McCain from suggestion of improper relationship |publisher= [[Associated press]] |accessdate=2008-02-21}} {{Dead link|date=November 2010|bot=H3llBot}} ''[[U.S. News & World Report]]'' publisher [[Mort Zuckerman]] said, "I don't think that there is enough acknowledged sourcing for this story." Commentator [[Bill O'Reilly (commentator)|Bill O'Reilly]] raised the question about why the paper had endorsed McCain on January 25, 2008 for the [[U.S. Republican Party|Republican]] nomination if they had information that alleged an inappropriate relationship.{{cite web | url = http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,331867,00.html | title = Did The New York Times Smear John McCain? | date = February 22, 2008 | author = Bill O'Reilly | publisher = Fox News Channel}} Academics and legal journals offered both support and criticism of the story. The editor of the ''[[American Journalism Review]]'' said that, while the article wasn't entirely convincing, it did put to question McCain's reputation as a reformer.{{cite web |date=February–March 2008 |last= Rieder |first= Rem |url= http://www.ajr.org/Article.asp?id=4482 |title= The Senator and the Lobbyist |publisher= [[American Journalism Review]] |accessdate=2008-02-24}} The editor of the ''[[Columbia Journalism Review]]'' said the circumstances outlined in the story were sufficient to justify its publication.{{cite web |date=2008-02-22 |last=Rainey |first=James |pages=2 |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/politics/la-na-media22feb22,1,3173594.story?page=1&cset=true&ctrack=1 |title=McCain story proves incendiary among journalists, conservatives |publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]] |accessdate=2008-02-24 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080228050717/http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/politics/la-na-media22feb22%2C1%2C3173594.story?page=1&cset=true&ctrack=1 |archivedate=2008-02-28 |deadurl=yes |df= }} However, a [[Dean (education)|dean]] at the [[Columbia Graduate School of Journalism]] disagreed, saying, "[If] you haven't covered all your bases or been transparent about where you got the information ... then the criticism takes over and the story loses its significance." [[Kathleen Hall Jamieson]], director of the Annenberg Public Policy Center faulted the paper for focusing on the purported affair. Several [[conservative]] voices, who had recently criticized McCain, came to his defense. [[L. Brent Bozell III|Brent Bozell]] of the [[watchdog journalism|watchdog]] [[Media Research Center]](widely viewed as conservative) speculated that the story was done hastily because it feared the embarrassment of an imminent ''[[The New Republic|New Republic]]'' article reporting on internal dissension about the story.{{cite web |date=2008-02-21 |last=Kessler |first=Glen |url=http://blog.washingtonpost.com/the-trail/2008/02/21/mccain_camp_takes_on_the_new_y.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081006092605/http://blog.washingtonpost.com/the-trail/2008/02/21/mccain_camp_takes_on_the_new_y.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2008-10-06 |title=McCain Camp Takes On the New York Times |publisher=[[The Washington Post]] |accessdate=2008-02-21 }}{{cite web |date= 2008-02-21 |last= Sherman |first= Gabriel |url= http://www.tnr.com/politics/story.html?id=8b7675e4-36de-43f5-afdd-2a2cd2b96a24 |title= The Long Run-Up |publisher= [[The New Republic]] |accessdate=2008-02-21}} Talk show host [[Rush Limbaugh]] said, "This is what you get when you walk across the aisle and try to make these people your friends. I'm not surprised in the least that the NYT would try to take out John McCain."{{cite web |date= 2008-02-21 |last= Szep |first= Jason |url= https://www.reuters.com/article/reutersEdge/idUSN1931768920080221 |title= McCain could gain from report on lobbyist link |publisher= [[Reuters]] |accessdate=2008-02-22}} Jay Ambrose, an opinion columnist for the ''[[Boston Herald]]'', summarized their sentiment by writing, "One of the first rules of decent, principles-abiding journalism is that you don't print rumors. That is nevertheless what The New York Times [NYT] just did in a smear job on John McCain. ... "{{cite web |date=2008-02-22 |last=Ambrose |first=Jay |url=http://news.bostonherald.com/news/opinion/op_ed/view.bg?articleid=1075170&srvc=home&position=rated |title=All the rumors unfit to print |publisher=''[[Boston Herald]]'' |accessdate=2008-02-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080227045214/http://news.bostonherald.com/news/opinion/op_ed/view.bg?articleid=1075170&srvc=home&position=rated |archivedate=2008-02-27 |df= }} ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' columnist [[Debra Saunders]] wrote, "The paper set out to shine a spotlight on McCain's ethics, but it ended up turning a harsh light on its own ethical lapses."{{cite web |date= 2008-02-22 |last= Saunders |first= Debra |authorlink= Debra Saunders |url= http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2008/02/22/EDJUV6KCB.DTL |title= New York Times sullies itself with McCain story |publisher= ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' |accessdate=2008-02-22}} Some [[Liberalism|liberal]] commentators and critics of the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] have also questioned the purpose of the story. [[Jonathan Alter]] of ''[[Newsweek]]'' said the article lacked physical evidence, noting, "[L]et's face it, people are more interested in sex than they are in telecommunications lobbying activity."{{cite web |date= 2008-02-20 |last= Alter |first= Jonathan |authorlink= Jonathan Alter |url= http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/23275773/ |title= 'Countdown with Keith Olbermann' for Feb. 20 |publisher= [[MSNBC]] |accessdate=2008-02-24}} [[John Dean]] argued that, if false, the article is both unfair and damaging, suggesting that legal recourse was possible.{{cite web |date=2008-02-22 |last=Dean |first=John |authorlink=John Dean |url=http://writ.news.findlaw.com/scripts/printer_friendly.pl?page=/dean/20080222.html |title=The New York Times Story Linking John McCain with Lobbyist Vicki Iseman: Should It Have Been Published? |publisher=[[FindLaw]] |accessdate=2008-02-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080228081032/http://writ.news.findlaw.com/scripts/printer_friendly.pl?page=%2Fdean%2F20080222.html |archivedate=2008-02-28 |df= }} Journalist [[Hanna Rosin]], writing in ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'', said the ''Times'' rushed the story to publication and left key questions unanswered, writing "Either write the cheating story or don't. As it is, it just looks like a lame story where they quote a bunch of anonymous old campaign sources but don't have any actual evidence of the affair themselves. And they make it much easier for McCain to just stomp on the story."{{cite web |date=2008-02-20 |last=Rosin |first=Hanna |authorlink=Hanna Rosin |url=http://slate.com/blogs/blogs/xxfactor/archive/2008/02/20/its-about-vicki-stupid.aspx |title=It's About Vicki, Stupid |publisher=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] |accessdate=2008-02-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080225150205/http://slate.com/blogs/blogs/xxfactor/archive/2008/02/20/its-about-vicki-stupid.aspx |archivedate=2008-02-25 |df= }} Also writing for ''Slate'', [[Michael Kinsley]] criticized the ''Times'' for "semantic acrobatics" in "defending itself with a preposterous assertion that it wasn't trying to imply what it obviously was trying to imply".{{cite web |date= 2008-02-25 |last= Kinsley |first= Michael |authorlink= Michael Kinsley |url= http://www.slate.com/id/2185134/ |title= McCain and the Times: the Real Questions - My apparent concern about the appearance of the possibility of the appearance of a possible affair. |publisher= [[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] |accessdate=2008-07-21}} In defense of the article, reporters for ''[[Politico (newspaper)|Politico]]'' wondered that if the story was about McCain's possible 2008 presidential opponent, Senator [[Barack Obama]], whether conservatives may have been more curious about the details of the story which they felt had substance,{{cite web |date= 2008-02-24 |last= Allen |first= Mike |author2=VandeHei, Jim |authorlink2=Jim VandeHei |url= http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0208/8649.html |title= Why the right reluctantly defended McCain |publisher= [[Politico (newspaper)|Politico]] |accessdate=2008-02-25}} a sentiment echoed by ''[[The New Republic]]''.{{cite web |date=2008-02-24 |last=Sheiber |first=Norm |url=http://blogs.tnr.com/tnr/blogs/the_stump/archive/2008/02/24/why-are-conservatives-so-delusional-about-the-mccain-story.aspx |title=Why Are Conservatives So Delusional About the McCain Story? |publisher=[[The New Republic]] |accessdate=2008-02-25 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080226193639/http://blogs.tnr.com/tnr/blogs/the_stump/archive/2008/02/24/why-are-conservatives-so-delusional-about-the-mccain-story.aspx |archivedate=2008-02-26 |deadurl=yes |df= }} ''Times'' editor [[Bill Keller]] defended the story, saying the facts were well [[vetted]] and the timing was a result of waiting until the story was ready. Other ''Times'' editors defended the use of anonymous sources, saying they knew their identities and that they provided thorough and consistent stories.{{cite web |date= 2008-02-21 |last= Abramson |first= Jill |authorlink= Jill Abramson |pages= 2 |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2008/02/21/business/media/21askthenewsroom.html |title= The McCain Article |publisher= [[The New York Times]] |accessdate=2008-02-25|display-authors=etal}} However, [[Clark Hoyt]], the [[ombudsman]] for ''The New York Times'', criticized the article for its lack of details and independent proof.{{cite web |date= 2008-02-24 |last= Hoyt |first= Clark |authorlink= Clark Hoyt |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2008/02/24/opinion/24pubed.html?em&ex=1203915600&en=0cc088c86203723a&ei=5087%0A |title= What That McCain Article Didn't Say |publisher= [[The New York Times]] |accessdate=2008-02-24}} == Follow-up article == On February 23, ''The New York Times'' followed up their original article with an article on McCain's efforts to help a client of Iseman's before the FCC. According to the article, "In late 1998, Senator John McCain sent an unusually blunt letter to the head of the Federal Communications Commission, warning that he would try to overhaul the agency if it closed a broadcast ownership loophole."[https://www.nytimes.com/2008/02/23/us/politics/23lobby.html?pagewanted=print Files and McCain Letter Show Effort to Keep Loophole] By STEPHEN LABATON February 23, 2008 ''New York Times'' Former staffer to President [[Bill Clinton]] and current [[Hillary Clinton]] supporter [[Lanny Davis]] said the article "had no merit". Stating that he did not support McCain's bid for the White House, Davis, who had himself lobbied for the same cause Iseman lobbied McCain for, said that McCain only wrote a letter to the FCC to ask them to "act soon" and refused to write a letter that supported the sale of the television station the article talked about.{{cite news | title = McCain disputes report of lobbyist relationship | url=http://washingtontimes.com/article/20080222/NATION/813344605/1002| accessdate = 2008-02-25 | date = February 22, 2008 |publisher = The Washington Times|author1=Ralph Z. Hallow |author2=Jennifer Harper }} == Defamation lawsuit and settlement == In December 2008, Iseman filed a [[US$]]27 million [[defamation]] lawsuit against ''The New York Times'', alleging that the paper falsely communicated an illicit romantic relationship between her and McCain. ''The Times'' said they "fully stood behind the article" and the story was "true and accurate". In February, 2009, the lawsuit was settled with no money changing hands between the parties. From ''The Times'' coverage of the settlement: "On Thursday, the two sides released a joint statement saying: 'To resolve the lawsuit, Ms. Iseman has accepted The Times's explanation, which will appear in a Note to Readers to be published in the newspaper on Feb. 20, that the article did not state, and The Times did not intend to conclude, that Ms. Iseman had engaged in a romantic affair with Senator McCain or an unethical relationship on behalf of her clients in breach of the public trust.' That statement was published on The Times's Web site, as was a statement from Ms. Iseman's lawyers. They wrote, in part: 'Had this case proceeded to trial, the judicial determination of whether she is entitled to the protections afforded a [[privacy|private citizen]] would have been the subject of a ferocious, pivotal battle, with Ms. Iseman insisting on her status as a private person and The New York Times asserting that she had entered the [[public figure|public arena]], and was therefore fair game.'" (The public/private Wikipedia links provided in the quote are for information, not legal, purposes.)[https://www.nytimes.com/2009/02/20/business/media/20lawsuit.html?scp=4&sq=iseman%20settlement&st=cse "Libel Suit Against The Times Ends"] by Richard Pérez-Peña, ''The New York Times'', Feb. 19, 2009. Retrieved 2-22-09. Ms. Iseman's lawyers for the published the statement were [[Rodney A. Smolla]] is an attorney, and Dean of the [[Washington and Lee University School of Law]]. W. Coleman Allen, Jr. is a trial lawyer with [[Allen, Allen, Allen & Allen]], based in [[Richmond, Virginia]].[https://www.nytimes.com/2009/02/20/business/media/20lawyers.html?ref=media "Statement From Iseman’s Lawyers"] ''The New York Times'', Feb. 19, 2009. Retrieved 2-22-09. Iseman spoke out personally against ''The New York Times'' story for the first time during a March 2, 2009, interview on ''[[The Early Show]]'', where she vehemently denied having an affair with McCain, and said of the story, "Any assertions that there was anything inappropriate, ethically or professionally or personally are just not true."{{Citation | title = Lobbyist Denies Affair With McCain | newspaper = [[CBS News]] | date = 2009-03-02 | url = http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2009/03/02/earlyshow/main4837723.shtml}} Iseman criticized the way the story was handled, and felt the newspaper became so invested in proving it was true that it became "out of control." She also said the entire story appeared to be based on a single source, who she claimed was John Weaver, a McCain political consultant she believed was offended when Iseman criticized a speech Weaver may have written. She said of Weaver's influence on the story, "[it] all went back to one singular person, a political operative who had left the senator's campaign under acrimonious circumstances. ... All roads lead back to him." Weaver, who was quoted in the original ''Times'' story saying he met with Iseman after concerns were raised about her presence in the campaign, previously said he did not speak to the paper without permission from the McCain campaign.{{Citation|last=Cillizza |first=Chris |title=The Fix: John Weaver Speaks |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=2008-02-21 |url=http://blog.washingtonpost.com/thefix/2008/02/john_weaver_speaks.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081015125651/http://blog.washingtonpost.com/thefix/2008/02/john_weaver_speaks.html |archivedate=2008-10-15 |df= }} == References == {{reflist|2}} == External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080226015137/http://www.opensecrets.org/lobbyists/lobbyist.asp?txtname=Iseman%2C+Vicki&year=a&txttype=l List of companies Vicki Iseman lobbied for] {{John McCain}} {{DEFAULTSORT:McCain, John lobbyist controversy}} [[Category:2008 controversies]] [[Category:Congressional controversies in the United States]] [[Category:Media-related controversies in the United States]] [[Category:John McCain presidential campaign, 2008|Lobbyist Controversy]] [[Category:The New York Times]] [[Category:February 2008 events in the United States]]

revision.comment: How dare you say it's a form of acceptabiLity, i deleted the error

page.title: List of British Virgin Islands hurricanes

revision.comment: minor update
revision.text:
{{Use British (Oxford) English|date=October 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} [[File:Irma_2017-09-06_1745Z.jpg|thumb|right|250px|[[Hurricane Irma]] is the most powerful tropical cyclone ever recorded in the British Virgin Islands.]] The '''list of British Virgin Islands hurricanes''' includes all [[tropical cyclone]]s which have struck the [[British Virgin Islands]] which caused at least hurricane force winds ({{convert|74|mph|kn km/h|abbr=on|lk=out}} or greater) to affect at least some part of the Territory. Hurricanes which passed close to the Territory but which only caused wind speeds of tropical storm force or below are not included.
Every known hurricane to strike the Territory except one ([[Hurricane Lenny]], 1999) or possibly two (hurricane of 1916) have been [[Cape Verde hurricane]]s. As a result, even though hurricane season technically runs from 1 June through 30 November, virtually all of the hurricane strikes occur in the month of September.<ref>Since 1900 the only exceptions to this have been Hurricane Bertha and Hurricane Jose (and Hurricane Lenny, which was a non-Cape Verde hurricane).</ref>
For the period that reasonably reliable records exist, hurricanes strike the Territory on average approximately once every 8 years, although that includes strikes which only affected the northernmost (and lightly populated) island of [[Anegada]].
In the twentieth century the British Virgin Islands experienced 13 hurricanes, but they came largely in two clusters. The Territory experienced five hurricanes from 1916 to 1932 (inclusive), and then only one during the next 57 years. But then between 1989 and 1999 (inclusive) seven hurricanes struck the Territory (including six in the space of four years from 1995-1999). That was then followed by another 11 year hiatus without any hurricane strikes.
Twice in recent times the Territory has experienced a rapid double-strike: in 1995 [[Hurricane Luis]] was followed nine days later by [[Hurricane Marilyn]], and in 2017 [[Hurricane Irma]] was followed fourteen days later by [[Hurricane Maria]].
{| class="wikitable" |- ! width="60" style="background: #efefef;"|Year !! width="130" style="background: #efefef;"|[[List_of_historic_tropical_cyclone_names#North_Atlantic|Hurricane Name]] !! width="60" style="background: #efefef;"| [[Saffir–Simpson scale|Category]]<ref>Refers to maximum wind-strength experienced in the British Virgin Islands - not overall maximum wind-strength of the storm.</ref> !! style="background: #efefef;" | Notes |- | colspan=4 style="background: #efefef;"| '''Modern era''' |- | align="center"|[[2017 in the British Virgin Islands|2017]] || align="center"|[[Hurricane Maria]] || align="center"|5 || Eye passed over the south of [[Saint Croix, U.S. Virgin Islands|St Croix]]. Caused only slight damage. Struck two weeks after Hurricane Irma. In the intervening period another major hurricane ([[Hurricane Jose (2017)|Hurricane Jose]]) narrowly missed the Territory.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/world/hurricane-maria-british-virgin-islands-battered-by-irma-escape-fresh-devastation-as-storm-hurtles-a3639916.html|title=Hurricane Maria: British Virgin Islands battered by Irma escape fresh devastation as storm hurtles towards more UK territories|publisher=''[[Evening Standard]]''|date=|accessdate=6 October 2017}}</ref> |- | align="center"|[[2017 in the British Virgin Islands|2017]] || align="center"|[[Hurricane Irma]] || align="center"|5 || Strongest Atlantic forming hurricane ever recorded. Eye passed directly over [[Virgin Gorda]], [[Tortola]] and [[Jost Van Dyke]]. Caused 4 deaths and catastrophic damage.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/sep/17/tortola-hurricane-irma-british-virgin-islands|title='We are still in survival mode': island of Tortola rebuilds after Hurricane Irma |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]''|accessdate=28 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://bvinews.com/new/help-us-bvi-pleads-for-assistance-following-wide-spread-hurricane-devastation/|title=Help Us! Cries for assistance after Irma leaves widespread devastation|publisher=BVI News|accessdate=28 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://bvinews.com/new/all-4-casualties-of-hurricane-irma-now-identified/|title=All 4 casualties of Hurricane Irma now identified|publisher=BVI News|date=9 October 2017|accessdate=9 October 2017}}</ref> |- | align="center"|[[2010 in the British Virgin Islands|2010]] || align="center"|[[Hurricane Earl (2010)|Hurricane Earl]] || align="center"|1 || Eye passed to the north of [[Anegada]]. Caused only slight damage.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.weather.gov/mhx/Sep032010EventReview|title=Hurricane Earl - September 3, 2010|publisher=National Weather Service|accessdate=6 October 2016}}</ref> |- | align="center"|[[1999 in the British Virgin Islands|1999]] || align="center"|[[Hurricane Lenny]] || align="center"|1 || Known locally as "wrong-way" Lenny, it is the only known Caribbean forming hurricane to strike the Territory. Passed well to the south, causing only light damage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bvihurricane.com/historical/hurricane-lenny-the-last-hurricane-to-hit-the-bvi/|title=Hurricane Lenny 1989|publisher=BVIHurricane.com|accessdate=6 October 2017}}</ref> |- | align="center"|[[1999 in the British Virgin Islands|1999]] || align="center"|[[Hurricane Jose (1999)|Hurricane Jose]] || align="center"|1 || Eye passed very close to the south of the Territory. Caused only light damage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/data/tcr/AL141999_Jose.pdf|title=AL14 Hurricane Jose (1999)|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=6 October 2017}}</ref> |- | align="center"|[[1998 in the British Virgin Islands|1998]] || align="center"|[[Hurricane Georges]] || align="center"|2 || Eye passed to the south. Caused moderate damage.<ref>{{cite report|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/data/tcr/AL071998_Georges.pdf|format=pdf |first=John L. |last=Guiney |title= Preliminary Report Hurricane Georges 15 September – 01 October 1998 (updated September 2014)|work= National Hurricane Center|publisher= [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|NOAA]]|date= January 5, 1999|accessdate=August 18, 2016}}</ref> |- | align="center"|[[1996 in the British Virgin Islands|1996]] || align="center"|[[Hurricane Bertha (1996)|Hurricane Bertha]] || align="center"|1 || Eye passed directly over the Territory. Caused moderate damage.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Miles B. Lawrence |title=Hurricane Bertha Tropical Cyclone Report |year=1996 |publisher=National Hurricane Center |accessdate=2008-02-13 |url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/1996bertha.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100825044553/http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/1996bertha.html |archivedate=2010-08-25 |df= }}</ref> |- | align="center"|[[1995 in the British Virgin Islands|1995]] || align="center"|[[Hurricane Marilyn]] || align="center"|1 || Eye passed to the north. Caused moderate damage. Struck nine days after Hurricane Luis.<ref>{{cite report|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/data/tcr/AL151995_Marilyn.pdf|title=Hurricane Marilyn: September 12 - 22, 1995|type=Preliminary Report|author=Rappaport, Edward N|date=January 17, 1996|author2=National Hurricane Center|publisher=United States National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's National Weather Service|accessdate=November 29, 2016}}</ref> |- | align="center"|[[1995 in the British Virgin Islands|1995]] || align="center"|[[Hurricane Luis]] || align="center"|2 || Eye passed to the north. Caused moderate damage.<ref>{{cite web|author=Miles B. Lawrence|title=Hurricane Luis Preliminary Report|date=January 8, 1996|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=2016-11-29 |url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/data/tcr/AL131995_Luis.pdf}}</ref> |- | align="center"|[[1989 in the British Virgin Islands|1989]] || align="center"|[[Hurricane Hugo]] || align="center"|4 || First hurricane to strike the main island of [[Tortola]] in over 50 years. Eye passed over the south of [[Saint Croix, U.S. Virgin Islands|St Croix]]. Caused significant damage.<ref>{{cite report|last=Lawrence|first=Miles|date=November 15, 1989|title=Preliminary Report: Hurricane Hugo|url=http://www.ecu.edu/renci/StormsToLife/Hugo/images/NOAA-Hugo-Report.pdf|publisher=[[National Hurricane Center]]|format=PDF|pages=1–2, 7|accessdate=August 26, 2012}}</ref> |- | colspan=4 style="background: #efefef;"| '''Early 20th century''' |- | align="center"|1960 || align="center"|[[Hurricane Donna]] || align="center"|2 || Eye passed to the north of Anegada.<ref name=Donna>{{cite web |url= https://www.wunderground.com/hurricane/atlantic/1960/Major-Hurricane-Donna |title= Hurricane and Tropical Cyclones: Major Hurricane Donna |publisher=[[Weather Underground (weather service)|The Weather Underground]] |author=NOAA |accessdate= 1 November 2017}}</ref> |- | align="center"|1932 || align="center"|[[1932 San Ciprian hurricane|San Ciprian hurricane]] || align="center"|3 || Eye passed narrowly to the south of the Territory. Few contemporaneous reports of the extent of the damage.<ref>{{cite web|author=Unisys|year=1932|title=1932 Unisys Archive|accessdate=2007-04-12|url=http://weather.unisys.com/hurricane/atlantic/1932/index.html| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070311122640/http://weather.unisys.com/hurricane/atlantic/1932/index.html| archivedate= 11 March 2007 | deadurl= no}}</ref> |- | align="center"|1931 || align="center"|[[1931_Atlantic_hurricane_season#Hurricane_Seven|San Nicolas Hurricane]] || align="center"|2 || Eye passed directly over the Territory. Few contemporaneous reports of the extent of the damage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/general/lib/lib1/nhclib/mwreviews/1931.pdf|title=Monthly Weather Review (June 1931)|publisher=|accessdate=6 October 2017}}</ref> |- | align="center"|1924 || align="center"|[[1924_Atlantic_hurricane_season#Hurricane_Four|"Gale of 1924"]] || align="center"|2-3 || Eye passed directly over the Territory.<ref>{{cite report|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1924.pdf|title=Monthly Weather Review|date=1924|publisher=[[National Weather Service|United States Weather Bureau]]|accessdate=August 18, 2013|format=PDF}}</ref> The storm was well documented by Agnes "Cuckoo" Hancock, wife of Commissioner [[Otho Lewis Hancock]]. Her letters are preserved in the Government House museum.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bviguides.com/Domains/bvipropertyguide/editorial/deadly_1924_hurricane.html|title=Deadly 1924 hurricane|publisher=BVI Guides|date=29 July 2011|accessdate=2 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oghm.org/the-1924-hurricane.html|title=The 1924 Hurricane|publisher=|date=|accessdate=2 January 2018}}</ref> |- | align="center"|1922 || align="center"|[[1922_Atlantic_hurricane_season#Hurricane_Two|Unnamed hurricane]] || align="center"|2 || Eye passed directly over [[Anegada]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://weather.unisys.com/hurricane/atlantic/1922/index.html|title=Unisys tracking data for 1922|accessdate=6 October 2017}}</ref> |- | align="center"|1916 || align="center"|[[1916_Atlantic_hurricane_season#Hurricane_Thirteen|Unnamed hurricane]] || align="center"|2-3 || Eye passed to the west of the Territory. Possibly a non-Cape Verde hurricane.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/general/lib/lib1/nhclib/1916.pdf|title=Monthly Weather Review|accessdate=6 October 2017|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061004204317/http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/general/lib/lib1/nhclib/1916.pdf|archivedate=4 October 2006|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.onepaper.com/bvireview/?v=d&i=61&s=Welcome+to+the+BVI:BVI+History&p=51870|title=The Hurricane of 1916|publisher=BVI Review|date=|accessdate=2 January 2018}}</ref> |- | colspan=4 style="background: #efefef;"| '''Late 19th century''' |- | align="center"|1899 || align="center"|[[1899_Atlantic_hurricane_season#Hurricane_Five|Unnamed hurricane]] || align="center"|2 || Eye passes to the north of [[Anegada]]. No other island significantly affected.<ref>{{cite report|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/Landsea/Partagas/1898-1900/1899_1.pdf|title=Year 1899|author=Jose F. Partagas|date=1996|work=[[Atlantic Oceanographic and Meteorological Laboratory]]|publisher=[[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]]|pages=39–53|accessdate=May 22, 2013|location=Miami, Florida|format=PDF}}</ref> |- |align="center"|1894 || align="center"|[[1894_Atlantic_hurricane_season#Hurricane_Six|Unnamed hurricane]] || align="center"|2 || <ref>{{cite web|url=http://weather.unisys.com/hurricane/atlantic/1894/index.html|title=Unisys 1894 season tracks|accessdate=6 October 2017}}</ref> |- |align="center"|1889 || align="center"|[[1889_Atlantic_hurricane_season#Hurricane_Four|Hurricane San Martín]] || align="center"|2 || <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/easyhurdat_5105.html#1889_1|title=HURDAT Data for the 1889 Atlantic hurricane season|accessdate=6 October 2017}}</ref> |- | align="center"|1876 || align="center"|[[1876 San Felipe hurricane|San Felipe hurricane]] || align="center"|3 || |- | align="center"|1871 || align="center"|[[1871_Atlantic_hurricane_season#Hurricane_Four|Hurricane Santa Juana]] || align="center"|2 || Eye passed directly over the Territory. |- | align="center"|[[1867 in the British Virgin Islands|1867]] || align="center"|[[1867 San Narciso hurricane|San Narciso hurricane]] || align="center"|3 || Eye passed directly over the Territory. Sank the [[RMS Rhone|RMS ''Rhone'']]. Caused 26 deaths on land, and an estimated further 123 died on the ''Rhone''.<ref>{{Cite conference|first=Frank |last=Mújica-Baker |title=Huracanes y Tormentas que han afectado a Puerto Rico |publisher=Estado Libre Asociado de Puerto Rico, Agencia Estatal para el manejo de Emergencias y Administracion de Desastres |url=http://www.gobierno.pr/NR/rdonlyres/49EA64D0-305B-4881-8B85-04B518004BD5/0/Ciclones_en_PR.pdf |pages=9–10 |accessdate=August 31, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6bxpFoAqi?url=http://www.gobierno.pr/NR/rdonlyres/49EA64D0-305B-4881-8B85-04B518004BD5/0/Ciclones_en_PR.pdf |archivedate=October 1, 2015 |df= }}</ref> |- | align="center"|1866 || align="center"|[[1866_Atlantic_hurricane_season#Hurricane_Six|Great Bahamas Hurricane of 1866]] || align="center"|1 || Eye passed to the north of [[Anegada]], and only that island was affected.<ref>{{cite web|author=José Fernández Partagás|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|year=2003|title=Year 1866|accessdate=2011-06-04|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/Landsea/Partagas/1865-1870/1866.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> |- | align="center"|1852 || align="center"|[[1852_Atlantic_hurricane_season#Hurricane_Four|Unnamed hurricane]] || align="center"|1 || <ref>{{cite web|author=[[Chris Landsea]]|year=2007|title=Counting Atlantic Tropical Cyclones Back to 1900|publisher=American Meteorological Society|accessdate=2007-07-23|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/Landsea/landsea-eos-may012007.pdf|format=PDF| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070714114214/http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/Landsea/landsea-eos-may012007.pdf | archivedate= 14 July 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> |- | colspan=4 style="background: #efefef;"| '''Pre-1850''' |- | colspan=4 | ''Prior to 1850 hurricane reports are sporadic and not generally reliable. Only well known or observed storms are generally recorded. Because the British Virgin Islands was sparsely populated during this period, records often do not indicate even if well known storms struck the Territory.'' |- | align="center"|1819 || align="center"|[[1810–19_Atlantic_hurricane_seasons#1819_Atlantic_hurricane_season|Hurricane San Mateo]] || align="center"|Unknown || Reportedly destroyed the original St George's Anglican church in Road Town.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.vg/books?id=sXSjuLByDmYC&pg=PA57&lpg=PA57&dq=1924+BVI+hurricane&source=bl&ots=zsLf1GHgLH&sig=eNApu4StSG2gv0tO_8k76fUEaSs&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjBvY2rs7nYAhUMRSYKHcWZAHkQ6AEIQzAF#v=onepage&q=1924%20BVI%20hurricane&f=false|title=British Virgin Islands: Alive! |publisher=Hunter Publishing |author=Harriet Greenberg, Douglas Greenberg |isbn=1588435075 |year=2008 |page=57 |quote=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://atmos.uprm.edu/pasthurricanes.php |title=Tropical storms and hurricanes that passed within 2 degrees latitude of Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands from 1515-2004 |author=Caribbean Atmospheric Research Center |publisher=[[University of Puerto Rico]], [[Mayagüez]] Campus |date= |accessdate=2010-12-28 }}</ref> |- | align="center"|1780 || align="center"|[[Great Hurricane of 1780]] || align="center"|Unknown || Eye is believed to have passed some distance to the south the Territory. No deaths are recorded, but a Quaker settlement was reported as abandoned because of the hurricane.<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.vg/books?id=1aaOGjO63UgC&pg=PA316&lpg=PA316&dq=1780+BVI+hurricane&source=bl&ots=K1LVSfty_a&sig=TFQ_EXNJmzueJj6SquJ3RW7NVi0&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjw2c_bktzWAhVC5yYKHZQGDu8Q6AEIXDAI#v=onepage&q=1780%20BVI%20hurricane&f=false |title=Island Fact and Theory in Nature |publisher=University of California Press |author=Dr James Lazell |year=2005 |edition=|isbn=0520243528 |page=316}}</ref> |}
