Early in the morning before the march, Nixon met with protesters briefly at the [[Lincoln Memorial]] but nothing was resolved and the protest went on as planned. * [[Student Strike of 1970|National Student Strike]]: more than 450 university, college and high school campuses across the country were shut by student strikes and both violent and non-violent protests that involved more than 4 million students, in the only nationwide student strike in U.S. history. * A Gallup poll in May shows that 56% of the public believed that sending troops to Vietnam was a mistake, 61% of those over 50 expressed that belief compared to 49% of those between the ages of 21–29.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://people-press.org/commentary/?analysisid=57 |title=Pew Research Center: Generations Divide Over Military Action in Iraq |publisher=People-press.org |date=2002-10-17 |accessdate=2011-03-07}}</ref> * On June 13, President Nixon established the [[President's Commission on Campus Unrest]]. The commission was directed to study the dissent, disorder, and violence breaking out on college and university campuses.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://www.eric.ed.gov/ERICWebPortal/detail?accno=ED083899|title=The Report of the President's Commission on Campus Unrest|location=Washington, D.C.|publisher=U.S. Government Printing Office|year=1970|accessdate=2007-04-16}} This book is also known as ''The Scranton Commission Report.''</ref> * In July 1970. the award-winning documentary ''[[The World of Charlie Company]]'' was broadcast. "It showed GI's close to mutiny, balking at orders that seemed to them unreasonable. This was something never seen on television before."<ref>Bliss, Edward Jr.(1991). Now the news. p. 349</ref> The documentary was produced by [[CBS]] News. * On August 24, 1970, near 3:40 a.m., a van filled with ammonium nitrate and fuel oil mixture was detonated on the University of Wisconsin-Madison in the [[Sterling Hall bombing]]. One researcher was killed and three others were injured. * [[Vortex I|Vortex I: A Biodegradable Festival of Life]]: To avert potential violence arising from planned anti-war protests, a government-sponsored [[rock festival]] was held near [[Portland, Oregon]] from August 28 to September 3, attracting 100,000 participants. The festival, arranged by the People's Army Jamboree (an ''[[ad hoc]]'' group) and Oregon governor [[Tom McCall]], was set up when the FBI told the governor that President Nixon's planned appearance at an [[American Legion]] convention in Portland could lead to violence worse than that seen at the [[1968 Democratic National Convention]] in Chicago. * The [[Chicano Moratorium]]: on August 29, some 25,000 [[Mexican-American]]s participated in the largest anti-war demonstration in Los Angeles. Police attacked the crowd with [[Club (weapon)|billyclubs]] and [[tear gas]]; two people were killed. Immediately after the marchers were dispersed, sheriff's deputies raided a nearby bar, where they shot and killed [[Rubén Salazar]], [[KMEX]] news director and ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' columnist, with a tear-gas projectile.
===1971 and after=== [[File:Vietnam War protest in Washington DC April 1971.jpg|thumb|Protests against the Vietnam War in Washington D.C. on April 24, 1971]] * On April 23, 1971, Vietnam veterans threw away over 700 medals on the West Steps of the Capitol building.<ref>"Veterans Discard Medals In War Protest At Capitol", ''New York Times'', April 24, 1971, P. 1</ref> The next day, antiwar organizers claimed that 500,000 marched, making this the largest demonstration since the November, 1969 march.<ref>"Reports of Its Death Have Been Greatly Exaggerated", James Buckley, ''New York Times'', April 25, 1971, P. E1</ref> * Two weeks later, on May 5, 1971, 1146 people were arrested on the Capitol grounds trying to shut down Congress. This brought the total arrested during the [[1971 May Day Protests]] to over 12,000. [[Abbie Hoffman]] was arrested on charges of interstate travel to incite a riot and assaulting a police officer.<ref>"Protesters Fail to Stop Congress, Police Seize 1,146", James M. McNaughton, ''New York Times'', May 6, 1971, P. 1</ref> * In August, 1971, the [[Camden 28]] conducted a raid on the Camden, New Jersey draft board offices. The 28 included five or more members of the clergy, as well as a number of local blue-collar workers. * Beginning December 26, 1971, 15 anti-war veterans occupied the Statue of Liberty, flying a US flag upside down from her crown. They left on December 28, following issuance of a Federal Court order.<ref name="NPS SoL">{{cite web |url=http://www.nps.gov/history/history/online_books/stli/adhi1.htm | title=Statue of Liberty NM: An Administrative History (Chapter 1) |publisher=[[United States National Park Service]] |work=STATUE OF LIBERTY – Celebrating the Immigrant: An Administrative History of the Statue of Liberty National Monument 1952 – 1982 |year=1985 |accessdate=January 20, 2013 | author=Blumberg, Barbara | pages=Ch. 1}}</ref> Also on December 28, 80 young veterans clashed with police and were arrested while trying to occupy the Lincoln Memorial in Washington, D.C.<ref>''1973 World Almanac'', p. 996.</ref> * On March 29, 1972, 166 people, many of them seminarians, were arrested in [[Harrisburg, Pennsylvania]] for encircling the Federal Courthouse with a chain, to protest the trial of the [[Harrisburg Seven]].<ref>"Students Picket Harrisburg Trial", Eleanor Blaus, ''New York Times'', March 30, 1972, p. 15</ref> * On April 19, 1972, in response to renewed escalation of bombing, students at many colleges and universities around the country broke into campus buildings and threatened strikes.<ref>"Campus Outbreaks Spread", Martin Arnold, ''New York Times'', April 19, 1972, p. 1</ref> The following weekend, protests were held in Los Angeles, New York City, San Francisco, and elsewhere.<ref>"War Foes March in the Rain Here", Martin Arnold, ''New York Times'', April 23, 1972, p. 1</ref><ref name="Olson1999">{{cite book|editor= [[James Stuart Olson]] |title=Historical Dictionary of the 1970s|year= 1999|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-313-30543-6 |chapter= Chronology |chapterurl= https://books.google.com/books?id=YKkF8vQRcp0C&pg=PA369 }}</ref> * On May 13, 1972, protests again spread across the country in response to President Nixon's decision to mine harbors in North Vietnam<ref>"Peaceful Antiwar Protests Held Here And in Other Cities Across the Nation", John Darnton, ''New York Times'', May 14, 1972, p.30</ref> and renewed bombing of North Vietnam ([[Operation Linebacker]]). * On July 6, 1972, four Sisters of Notre Dame de Namur on a White House Tour stopped and began praying to protest the war. In the next six weeks, such kneel-ins became a popular form of protest and led to over 158 protestors arrests.<ref name="DeBenedetti 360">{{harvnb|DeBenedetti|1990|p=360}}</ref>
==Public opinion on the Vietnam War== The American public's support of the Vietnam War decreased as the war continued on. As public support decreased, opposition grew.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lunch |first=William|date=March 1979|title=American Public Opinion and the War in VietnamWar|jstor=447561|language=en-us}}</ref>
The [[Gallup (company)|Gallup]] News Service began asking the American public whether it was a "mistake to send troops to Vietnam" in August 1965. At the time less than a quarter of Americans polled, 24%, believed it was a mistake to send troops to Vietnam while 60% of Americans polled believed the opposite. Three years later, in September 1968, 54% of Americans polled believed it was a mistake to send troops to Vietnam while 37% believed it was not a mistake.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.gallup.com/poll/18097/iraq-versus-vietnam-comparison-public-opinion.aspx|title=Iraq Versus Vietnam: A Comparison of Public Opinion|last=Inc.|first=Gallup,|date=|work=Gallup.com|access-date=2018-04-19|language=en-us}}</ref>
A 1965 Gallup Poll asked the question, "Have you ever felt the urge to organize or join a public demonstration about something?"<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.gallup.com/vault/190886/gallup-vault-urge-demonstrate.aspx|title=Gallup Vault: The Urge to Demonstrate|last=Inc.|first=Gallup,|work=Gallup.com|access-date=2017-10-23|language=en-us}}</ref> Positive responses were quite low; not many people wanted to protest anything, and those who did want to show a public demonstration often wanted to demonstrate in support of the Vietnam War. However, when the American Public was asked in 1990, "Looking back, do you wish that you had made a stronger effort to protest or demonstrate against the Vietnam War, or not", 25 percent said they wished they had. {| class="wikitable" |Urge to Organize or Demonstrate !Yes% !No% |- !U.S. adults |10 |90 |- !21 to 29 years old |15 |85 |- !30 to 49 years |12 |88 |- !50 and older |6 |94 |- !College graduates |21 |79 |- !High school graduates |9 |91 |- !High school nongraduates |5 |95 |- | colspan="100" |GALLUP, OCT. 29-NOV. 2, 1965 <ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.gallup.com/vault/190886/gallup-vault-urge-demonstrate.aspx|title=Gallup Vault: The Urge to Demonstrate|last=Inc.|first=Gallup,|work=Gallup.com|access-date=2017-10-23|language=en-us}}</ref> |} A major factor in the American public's disapproval of the Vietnam War came from the casualties being inflicted on US forces. In a Harris poll from 1967 asking what aspect most troubled people most about the Vietnam war the plurality answer of 31% was "the loss of our young men." A separated 1967 Harris poll asked the American public,"How has the war affected your own family, job or financial life?" The majority of respondents, 55%, said that it had had no effect on their lives. Of the 45% who indicated the war had affected their lives, 32% listed inflation as the most important factor while 25% listed casualties inflicted.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lorell|first=Mark|date=March 1985|title=Casualties, Public Opinion, and Presidential Policy during the Vietnam War|url=https://www.rand.org/content/dam/rand/pubs/reports/2007/R3060.pdf|journal=Casualties, Public Opinion, and Presidential Policy during the Vietnam War|volume=|pages=27|via=Rand Corporation}}</ref>
As the war continued the public became much more opposed to the war as they could see was not ending. In a poll from December 1967, 71% of the public believed the war would not be settled in 1968.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ropercenter.cornell.edu/CFIDE/cf/action/ipoll/questionDetail.cfm?keyword=vietnam%20and%20war&keywordoptions=1&exclude=&excludeOptions=1&topic=Any&organization=Any&label=&fromdate=01/01/1935&toDate=&stitle=&sponsor=&studydate=December%20712,%201967&sample=1549&qstn_list=&qstnid=361925&qa_list=&qstn_id4=361925&study_list=&lastSearchId=317674060377&archno=USAIPO1967-0755&keywordDisplay=|title=The Roper Center for Public Opinion Research|last=2008|first=Solomon Berhe, Derek Doran, Alberto De la Rosa Algaran, Darlene Hart, Marc Maynard, Meena Stout,|date=|website=ropercenter.cornell.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-11-13}}</ref> A year later the same question was asked and 55% of people did not think the war would be settled in 1969.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ropercenter.cornell.edu/CFIDE/cf/action/ipoll/questionDetail.cfm?keyword=vietnam%20and%20war&keywordoptions=1&exclude=&excludeOptions=1&topic=Any&organization=Any&label=&fromdate=01/01/1935&toDate=&stitle=&sponsor=&studydate=December%205-10,%201968&sample=1497&qstn_list=&qstnid=362300&qa_list=&qstn_id4=362300&study_list=&lastSearchId=317674060377&archno=USAIPO1968-0772&keywordDisplay=|title=The Roper Center for Public Opinion Research|last=2008|first=Solomon Berhe, Derek Doran, Alberto De la Rosa Algaran, Darlene Hart, Marc Maynard, Meena Stout,|date=|website=ropercenter.cornell.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-11-13}}</ref>
When the American public was asked about the Vietnam-era Anti-War movement in the 1990s, 39% of the public said the approved while 39% said they disapproved. The last 22% were unsure.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ropercenter.cornell.edu/CFIDE/cf/action/ipoll/questionDetail.cfm?keyword=vietnam%20and%20war&keywordoptions=1&exclude=&excludeOptions=1&topic=Any&organization=Any&label=&fromdate=01/01/1935&toDate=&stitle=&sponsor=&studydate=01-JAN-34&sample=1225&qstn_list=&qstnid=217461&qa_list=&qstn_id4=217461&study_list=&lastSearchId=317674060458&archno=&keywordDisplay=|title=The Roper Center for Public Opinion Research|last=2008|first=Solomon Berhe, Derek Doran, Alberto De la Rosa Algaran, Darlene Hart, Marc Maynard, Meena Stout,|date=|website=ropercenter.cornell.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-11-13}}</ref>
==Slogans and chants== *"'''Hell, no, we won't go!'''" was heard in antidraft and antiwar protests throughout the country.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/10000981@N02/790033026/|title="Hell no, we won't go!" The infamous chant is shouted by draft opponents in the streets of New York City.|date= |accessdate=2012-11-25}}</ref> *"'''Bring the troops home now!'''" was heard in mass marches in Washington D.C., Seattle, San Francisco, Berkeley, New York, and San Diego. *"'''Dow shall not kill'''" and "'''Making money burning babies!'''" were two slogans used by students at [[UCLA]] and other colleges to protest the [[Dow Chemical Company]], the maker of [[napalm]] and [[Agent Orange]].<ref name="Fry 228"/> *"'''Stop the war, feed the poor'''" was a popular slogan used by socially conscious and minority antiwar groups, protesting that the war diverted funds that struggling Americans desperately needed.<ref>{{harvnb|Gills|1992|p=192}}</ref> *"'''Girls say yes to men who say no'''" was an antidraft slogan used by the SDS and other organizations.<ref>{{harvnb|Adams|1992|p=185}}</ref> *"'''War is not healthy for children and other living things'''" was a slogan of [[Another Mother for Peace]], and was popular on posters.<ref>{{harvnb|DeBenedetti|1990|p=185}}</ref> *"'''End the nuclear race, not the human race'''" was first used by the [[Women Strike for Peace|WSP]] in antinuclear demonstrations and became incorporated into the antiwar events.<ref>{{harvnb|DeBenedetti|1990|p=54}}</ref> *"'''Not my son, not your son, not their sons'''" was an antiwar and antidraft slogan used by the [[Women Strike for Peace|WSP]] during protests.<ref>{{harvnb|Swerdlow|1992|p=159}}</ref> *"'''Ho, Ho, Ho Chi Minh, the Viet Cong are gonna win'''" was a common anti-war chant during anti-war marches and rallies in the later sixties. *"'''Hey, hey, LBJ! How many kids did you kill today?'''" was especially chanted by students and other marchers and demonstrators in opposition to [[Lyndon B. Johnson]].<ref>https://www.economist.com/news/united-states/21586830-what-current-fascination-lyndon-johnson-says-about-barack-obamas-america-hey-hey</ref> *"'''One, two, three, four, we don't want your fucking war'''" was chanted in marches from Brisbane to Boston. *"'''Fuck, fuck, fuck it all we don't want this anymore'''" was also chanted in marches from Brisbane to Boston.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1A41AgAAQBAJ&pg=PT69 |title=Ghost Platoon |publisher=Hachette Australia |author=Walker, Frank |year=2013 |pages=69 |isbn=0733628001}}</ref>

"[http://quakertheology.org/Morrison-Patler-Remembering-Norman.pdf Norman's Triumph: the Transcendent Language of Self-Immolation]". ''Quaker History'', Fall 2015, 18-39.
==External links== {{commons category|Opposition to the Vietnam War}} * [http://www.lib.berkeley.edu/MRC/pacificaviet/ Social Activism Sound Recording Project: Anti-Vietnam War Protests in the San Francisco Bay Area & Beyond] Includes chronology, texts, online audio and video (via UC Berkeley) *[http://depts.washington.edu/antiwar/ Pacific Northwest Antiwar and Radical History Project], multimedia collection of photographs, video, oral histories and essays on Vietnam War resistance. *[http://www.sirnosir.com/ ''Sir, No Sir!''] – Documentary on GI resistance during the Vietnam War. *[http://libcom.org/history/articles/vietnam-gi-resistance/index.php GI resistance during the Vietnam War] *[http://www.greenwych.ca/vietnam.htm Book excerpt of student seizure of WSU in Detroit] * [http://www.life.com/image/first/in-gallery/23010/vietnam-war-disturbing-images Vietnam War: Disturbing Images] – slideshow by ''[[Life magazine]]'' *[http://content.lib.washington.edu/protestsweb/index.html University of Washington Libraries Digital Collections – Vietnam War Era Ephemera] This collection contains leaflets and newspapers that were distributed on the University of Washington campus during the decades of the 1960s and 1970s. *[http://www.democracynow.org/2010/3/29/as_obama_visits_afghanistan_tavis_smiley Tavis Smiley on Rev. Martin Luther King and His Opposition to the Vietnam War] – video by ''[[Democracy Now!]]'' *[http://atom.archives.sfu.ca/index.php/statement-opposing-war-in-vietnam-fonds Records of Statement on the War in Vietnam are held by Simon Fraser University's Special Collections and Rare Books] *[http://www.boyswhosaidno.com/ ''The Boys Who Said NO''] – Documentary on draft resistance and its impact during the Vietnam War. *[http://www.vietnampeace.com/ Vietnam Peace Commemoration Committee] – Organization of Vietnam War peace activists, including veterans and scholars.
{{Anti-Vietnam| state=expanded}} {{Chicago Seven}} {{Anti-war}} {{1968 protests}}

page.title: Seven Wonders of the Ancient World

revision.comment: Added page protection template where none existed
revision.text:
{{pp|small=yes}} {{Redirect|7 Wonders of the Ancient World|the video game|7 Wonders of the Ancient World (video game)}} [[File:SevenWondersOfTheWorld.png|thumb|The Seven Wonders of the Ancient World (from left to right, top to bottom): [[Great Pyramid of Giza]], [[Hanging Gardens of Babylon]], [[Temple of Artemis]], [[Statue of Zeus at Olympia]], [[Mausoleum at Halicarnassus]], [[Colossus of Rhodes]], and the [[Lighthouse of Alexandria]]]] [[File:ancient_seven_wonders_timeline.svg|thumb|324px|Timeline and map of the Seven Wonders. Dates in bold green and dark red are of their construction and destruction, respectively.]] The '''Seven Wonders of the World''' or the '''Seven Wonders of the Ancient World''' is a list of remarkable constructions of [[classical antiquity]] given by various authors in guidebooks or poems popular among ancient [[Ancient Greece|Hellenic]] tourists. Although the list, in its current form, did not stabilise until the [[Renaissance]], the first such lists of seven wonders date from the 1st-2nd century BC. The original list inspired [[Wonders of the World|innumerable versions]] through the ages, often listing seven entries. Of the original Seven Wonders, only one—the [[Great Pyramid of Giza]] (also called the Pyramid of [[Khufu]], after the pharaoh who built it), the oldest of the ancient wonders—remains relatively intact. The [[Colossus of Rhodes]], the [[Lighthouse of Alexandria]], the [[Mausoleum at Halicarnassus]], the [[Temple of Artemis]] and the [[Statue of Zeus at Olympia|Statue of Zeus]] were all destroyed. The location and ultimate fate of the [[Hanging Gardens of Babylon|Hanging Gardens]] are unknown, and there is speculation that they may not have existed at all. ==Background== The Greek conquest of much of the known western world in the 4th century BC gave Hellenistic travellers access to the [[civilization]]s of the [[Ancient Egypt|Egyptians]], [[History of Iran|Persians]], and [[Babylonia]]ns. Impressed and captivated by the landmarks and marvels of the various lands, these travellers began to list what they saw to remember them.{{cite web | title = History of the Past: World History | url = http://worldhistory.byethost8.com/}}{{cite web | title = The Seven Wonders | author = Paul Lunde | date = May–June 1980 | publisher = Saudi Aramco World | url = http://www.saudiaramcoworld.com/issue/198003/the.seven.wonders.htm | accessdate = 2009-09-12 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20091013125703/http://www.saudiaramcoworld.com/issue/198003/the.seven.wonders.htm | archive-date = 2009-10-13 | dead-url = yes | df = }} Instead of "wonders", the ancient Greeks spoke of "''theamata''" (θεάματα), which means "sights", in other words "things to be seen" (Τὰ ἑπτὰ θεάματα τῆς οἰκουμένης [γῆς] ''{{lang|grc-Latn|Tà heptà theámata tēs oikoumenēs [gēs]}}''). Later, the word for "wonder" ("''thaumata''" θαύματα, "wonders") was used.{{cite book | last = Clayton | first = Peter | authorlink = |author2=Martin J. Price | title = The Seven Wonders of the Ancient World | publisher = Routledge | year =1990 | location = | page =4 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=n9QOAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA4&dq=theamata+seven+wonders | doi = | isbn = 978-0-415-05036-4 | author = }} Hence, the list was meant to be the Ancient World's counterpart of a travel guidebook. The first reference to a list of seven such monuments was given by [[Diodorus Siculus]].{{cite book|last1=Diodorus Siculus|title=Bibliotheca Historica, Books I-V|publisher=Perseus Project, Tufts University|location=2.11.5|url=http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Diod.+2.11.5&fromdoc=Perseus%3Atext%3A2008.01.0540}}{{cite book|last1=Clayton|first1=Peter A.|last2=Price|first2=Martin|title=The Seven Wonders of the Ancient World|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781136748097|page=158|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Df-AAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA158|accessdate=25 November 2016|language=en|date=2013-08-21}} The epigrammist [[Antipater of Sidon]]{{cite book|title=Greek Anthology, Volume III|publisher=Perseus Project, Tufts University|location=Book 9, chapter 58|url=http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A2008.01.0474%3Abook%3D9%3Achapter%3D58}} who lived around or before 100 BC,{{cite book|title=Biographical Dictionary Volume III|publisher=Society for the Diffusion of Useful Knowledge|page=48|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9w1FAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA48|accessdate=25 November 2016|language=en|year=1843}} gave a list of seven such monuments, including six of the present list (substituting the walls of Babylon for the lighthouse):{{cite book|last1=Clayton|first1=Peter A.|last2=Price|first2=Martin|title=The Seven Wonders of the Ancient World|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781136748103|page=10|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IQSBAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA10|accessdate=25 November 2016|language=en|date=2013-08-21}} {{Quote|I have gazed on the walls of impregnable Babylon along which chariots may race, and on the Zeus by the banks of the Alpheus, I have seen the hanging gardens, and the Colossus of the Helios, the great man-made mountains of the lofty pyramids, and the gigantic tomb of Mausolus; but when I saw the sacred house of Artemis that towers to the clouds, the others were placed in the shade, for the sun himself has never looked upon its equal outside Olympus. – ''Greek Anthology'' IX.58}} [[File:Pyramide Kheops.JPG|thumb|The [[Great Pyramid of Giza]], the only one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World still standing]] Another 2nd century BC observer, who claimed to be the mathematician [[Philo of Byzantium]],{{cite book | last = | first = | authorlink = | title = The New Encyclopædia Britannica Micropædia Volume 10 | publisher = Encyclopædia Britannica, Inc. | year =1995 | location =USA | page =666 | url = | doi = | isbn = 0-85229-605-3 | author = }} wrote a short account entitled ''The Seven Sights of the World''. However, the incomplete surviving manuscript only covered six of the supposedly seven places, which agreed with Antipater's list. Earlier and later lists by the historian [[Herodotus]] (484 BC–ca. 425 BC) and the architect [[Callimachus]] of [[Cyrene, Libya|Cyrene]] (ca. 305–240 BC), housed at the Museum of [[Alexandria, Egypt|Alexandria]], survived only as references. The [[Colossus of Rhodes]] was the last of the seven to be completed, after 280 BC, and the first to be destroyed, by an earthquake in 226/225 BC. Hence, all seven existed at the same time for a period of less than 60 years. ==Scope== The list covered only the sculptural and architectural monuments of the Mediterranean and [[Middle East]]ern regions, which then comprised the known world for the Greeks. Hence, extant sites beyond this realm were not considered as part of contemporary accounts.{{cite web | title = The Seven Wonders of the Ancient World | url = http://www.amazeingart.com/seven-wonders/7-wonders.html|accessdate=2009-09-14}} The primary accounts, coming from Hellenistic writers, also heavily influenced the places included in the wonders list. Five of the seven entries are a celebration of Greek accomplishments in the arts and architecture (the exceptions being the Pyramids of Giza and the Hanging Gardens of Babylon). ==Wonders == {{left|{{GeoGroup}}}} {{clear}} {| class="wikitable" |- ! Name ! Date of construction ! Builders ! Date of destruction ! Cause of destruction ! Modern location |- style="vertical-align: middle;" |[[Great Pyramid of Giza]] |2584{{ndash}}2561 BC |[[Ancient Egypt|Egyptians]] | colspan="2;" style="text-align:center;"|''Still in existence, majority of façade gone'' |[[Giza Necropolis]], Egypt
{{Coord|29|58|45.03|N|31|08|03.69|E|landmark_scale:2000|display=inline|name=Great Pyramid of Giza}} |- style="vertical-align: middle;" |[[Hanging Gardens of Babylon]]
(existence unresolved)There is some conjecture as to whether the Hanging Gardens actually existed, or were purely legendary (see Finkel, Irving (1988) [https://books.google.com/books?id=vGhbJzigPBwC&pg=PA38 “The Hanging Gardens of Babylon,”] In ''The Seven Wonders of the Ancient World'', Edited by Peter Clayton and Martin Price, Routledge, New York, pp. 38 ff. {{ISBN|0-415-05036-7}}). |{{Circa|600}} BC (evident) |[[Babylon]]ians or [[Assyria]]ns |After 1st century AD |Unknown |[[Hillah]] or [[Nineveh]], Iraq
{{coord|32.5355|N|44.4275|E|source:kolossus-frwiki|display=inline|name=Hanging Gardens of Babylon}} |- style="vertical-align: middle;" |[[Temple of Artemis|Temple of Artemis at Ephesus]] |{{circa|550}} BC; and again at 323 BC |[[Ancient Greece|Greeks]], [[Lydians]] |{{nowrap|356 BC (by Herostratus)}}
AD 262 (by the Goths) |Arson by [[Herostratus]], plundering |Near [[Selçuk]], Turkey
{{coord|37|56|59|N|27|21|50|E|type:landmark_source:dewiki|display=inline|name=Temple of Artemis at Ephesus}} |- style="vertical-align: middle;" |[[Statue of Zeus at Olympia]] |466{{ndash}}456 BC (temple)
435 BC (statue) |[[Ancient Greece|Greeks]] |5th{{ndash}}6th centuries AD |Disassembled and reassembled at Constantinople; later destroyed by fire |[[Olympia, Greece|Olympia]], Greece
{{coord|37|38|16.3|N|21|37|48|E|type:landmark_source:dewiki|display=inline|name=Statue of Zeus at Olympia}} |- style="vertical-align: middle;" |[[Mausoleum at Halicarnassus]] |351 BC |[[Greeks]],{{cite book | last = Kostof | first = Spiro | title = A History of Architecture | publisher = Oxford University Press | year = 1985 | location = Oxford | page = 9 | isbn = 0-19-503473-2}}{{cite book | last = Gloag | first = John | title = Guide to Western Architecture| origyear = 1958 | edition = Revised | year = 1969 | publisher = The Hamlyn Publishing Group | page = 362}} [[Achaemenid Empire|Persians]], [[Carians]] |12th{{ndash}}15th century AD |Earthquakes |[[Bodrum]], Turkey
{{coord|37.0379|N|27.4241|E|type:landmark_source:dewiki|display=inline|name=Mausoleum at Halicarnassus}} |- style="vertical-align: middle;" |[[Colossus of Rhodes]] |292{{ndash}}280 BC |[[Ancient Greece|Greeks]] |226 BC |[[226 BC Rhodes earthquake]] |[[Rhodes (city)|Rhodes]], Greece
{{coord|36|27|04|N|28|13|40|E|type:landmark_source:dewiki:dim:50|display=inline|name=Colossus of Rhodes}} |- style="vertical-align: middle;" |[[Lighthouse of Alexandria]] |{{Circa|280}} BC |[[Ancient Greece|Greeks]], [[Ptolemaic Kingdom|Ptolemaic Egyptians]] |AD 1303{{ndash}}1480 |[[1303 Crete earthquake]] |[[Alexandria]], Egypt
{{coord|31|12|50|N|29|53|08|E|type:landmark_source:dewiki|display=inline|name=Lighthouse of Alexandria}} |} ==Influence== [[File:Seven Wonders of the Ancient World.png|thumb|A map showing the locations of the seven wonders of the ancient world]] ===Arts and architecture=== [[File:Maerten van Heemskerck - Panorama with the Abduction of Helen Amidst the Wonders of the Ancient World - Walters 37656.jpg|right|thumb|In this painting by [[Maerten van Heemskerck]], the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World are depicted as a background for the abduction of Helen by Paris.{{cite web |publisher= [[The Walters Art Museum]] |url= http://art.thewalters.org/detail/21286 |title= Panorama with the Abduction of Helen Amidst the Wonders of the Ancient World}} The Walters Art Museum]] The seven wonders on Antipater's list won praises for their notable features, ranging from superlatives of the highest or largest of their types, to the artistry with which they were executed. Their architectural and artistic features were imitated throughout the Hellenistic world and beyond. The Greek influence in Roman culture, and the revival of Greco-Roman artistic styles during the Renaissance caught the imagination of European artists and travellers.{{cite web | title = Wonders of Europe | url = http://www.7wonders.org/wonders/europe/|accessdate=2009-09-14}} Paintings and sculptures alluding to Antipater's list were made, while adventurers flocked to the actual sites to personally witness the wonders. Legends circulated to further complement the superlatives of the wonders. ===Modern lists=== Of Antipater's wonders, the only one that has survived to the present day is the Great Pyramid of Giza. Its brilliant white stone facing had survived intact until around 1300 AD, when local communities removed most of the stonework for building materials. The existence of the Hanging Gardens has not been proven, although theories abound.[[Stephanie Dalley]] (2013), ''The Mystery of the Hanging Garden of Babylon: an elusive World wonder traced.'' OUP {{ISBN|978-0-19-966226-5}} Records and archaeology confirm the existence of the other five wonders. The Temple of Artemis and the Statue of Zeus were destroyed by fire, while the Lighthouse of Alexandria, Colossus, and tomb of Mausolus were destroyed by earthquakes. Among the [[Artifact (archaeology)|artifacts]] to have survived are sculptures from the tomb of Mausolus and the Temple of Artemis in the [[British Museum]] in London. Still, the listing of seven of the most marvellous architectural and artistic human achievements continued beyond the Ancient Greek times to the Roman Empire, the Middle Ages, the Renaissance and to the modern age. The Roman poet [[Martial]] and the Christian bishop [[Gregory of Tours]] had their versions. Reflecting the rise of Christianity and the factor of time, nature and the hand of man overcoming Antipater's seven wonders, Roman and Christian sites began to figure on the list, including the [[Colosseum]], [[Noah's Ark]] and [[Solomon's Temple]]. In the 6th century, a list of seven wonders was compiled by St. [[Gregory of Tours]]: the listClayton, Peter and Price, Martin: The Seven Wonders of the Ancient World (Routledge, 1988), pp. 162–163. included the Temple of Solomon, the [[Pharos of Alexandria]] and Noah's Ark. Modern historians, working on the premise that the original Seven Ancient Wonders List was limited in its geographic scope, also had their versions to encompass sites beyond the Hellenistic realm—from the Seven Wonders of the ''Ancient World'' to the Seven Wonders of the ''World''. Indeed, the "seven wonders" label has spawned innumerable versions among international organizations, publications and individuals based on different themes—works of nature, engineering masterpieces, constructions of the Middle Ages, etc. Its purpose has also changed from just a simple travel guidebook or a compendium of curious places, to lists of sites to defend or to preserve. ==See also== *[[Eighth Wonder of the World]], about attempted additions to the famous ancient list. *[[Wonders of the World]], about similar lists made throughout the ages. *[[Seven Wonders of the World (film)|''Seven Wonders of the World'']] (1956 film) ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== *Clayton, Peter A., and Martin Price. ''The Seven Wonders of the Ancient World''. New York: Dorset, 1989. *Deliyannis, Deborah Mauskopf. “The mausoleum of Theoderic and the Seven Wonders of the World.” ''Journal of Late Antiquity'' 3, no. 2 (2010): 365-85. *D'Epiro, Peter, and Mary Desmond Pinkowish. ''What Are the Seven Wonders of the World? and 100 Other Great Cultural Lists''. New York: Anchor Books/Doubleday, 1988. *Jordan, Paul. ''The Seven Wonders of the Ancient World''. Harlow, UK: Longman, 2002. *Mueller, Artur. ''The seven wonders of the world: Five thousand years of culture and history in the ancient world''. New York: McGraw-Hill, 1968. *Romer, John, and Elizabeth Romer. ''The Seven Wonders of the World: A History of the Modern Imagination''. 1st American ed. New York: Henry Holt, 1995. ==External links== {{commons category|Seven Wonders of the World}} {{Library resources box |by=no |onlinebooks=yes |others=yes |about=yes |label=Seven Wonders of the Ancient World |viaf= |lccn= |lcheading= |wikititle= }} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20130512195954/http://www.history.com/topics/seven-ancient-wonders-of-the-world "Seven Ancient Wonders of the World"] on [[History (U.S. TV channel)|The History Channel]] website. Also includes links to medieval, modern and natural wonders. *Parkin, Tim, [https://web.archive.org/web/20041011114644/http://www.clas.canterbury.ac.nz/wonders.html ''Researching Ancient Wonders: A Research Guide''], from the University of Canterbury, New Zealand. – a collection of books and Internet resources with information on seven ancient wonders. *[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2007/mar/10/jonathanglancey.international "Eternal wonder of humanity's first great achievements"], by Jonathan Glancey in ''[[The Guardian]]'', 10 March 2007 {{Seven Wonders of the Ancient World}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Seven Wonders Of The Ancient World}} [[Category:Ancient history]] [[Category:Former buildings and structures]] [[Category:Cultural lists|7 Seven Wonders of the Ancient World]] [[Category:Ancient technology]] [[Category:World Heritage Sites]] [[Category:Seven Wonders of the Ancient World]] [[Category:History of construction]]

revision.comment: added lang template
revision.text:
{{rough translation|1=zh|listed=yes|date=May 2018}} {{multiple issues| {{incoherent|date=March 2015}} {{original research|date=March 2015}} }}
'''Shanzhai''' or '''shan zhai''' ({{zh|s={{linktext|山寨}}|p={{linktext|shānzhài}}|j=saan1 zaai6}}) refers to [[counterfeit consumer goods]], including imitation and trademark infringing brands and/or particularly electronics, in China.<ref>{{cite news|last=Schmidle|first=Nicholas|title=Inside the Knockoff-Tennis-Shoe Factory|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/22/magazine/22fake-t.html|accessdate=8 September 2010|newspaper=New York Times|date=2010-08-19}}</ref> Literally "mountain village" or "mountain stronghold", the term refers to the mountain stockades of regional warlords or bandits, far away from official control. "Shanzhai" can also be stretched to refer to people who are lookalikes, low-quality or improved goods, as well as things done in [[parody]].
==Origin== According to the ''[[Xiandai Hanyu Dictionary]]'' ({{Lang-zh|c=现代汉语词典/現代漢語詞典|s=|t=|labels=no}}), "Shanzhai" can stand for two meanings: # A fenced place in the forest. # Villages in the mountain that have stockade houses.
Historically, "shanzhai" is sometimes used as a metaphor to describe bandits who oppose and evade the corrupted authority to perform deeds they see as justified. One example of such bandits is the story of ''[[Water Margin]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://baike.baidu.com/view/268947.html?wtp=tt |title=Baidu Encyclopedia "Shanzhai" |publisher=Baike.baidu.com |date=2010-03-23 |accessdate=2010-03-29}}</ref>
The use of "Shanzhai" to refer to imitation products comes from [[Cantonese]] slang, in which "shanzhai factory" means an ill-equipped, low-end and family-based factory. However, with the accumulation of profit, quite a few of those factories invest a lot of money to improve their equipment. Some factories also get investment from someone other than family members. Nowadays, a significant portion of Shanzhai factories are no longer ill-equipped or family-based.
Their products are no longer poor-quality. Yet they still can not escape from the fate of no-brand (or fake brand), not-for-sale in top department stores with non-''shanzha''i products. One of the motivations for going 'Shanzhai' is the difficult regulations the Chinese government had established to become an official mobile phone manufacturer. So to avoid the hassles companies try to operate under the radar. They can avoid taxes and regulation in this way.
Another account of the origin is that because imitation electronic appliance manufacturers are largely located in [[Shenzhen]], wholesalers from other parts of China started calling their products "Shenzhen product". Gradually "Shenzhen product" became "Shanzhai product" because they sound similar when people speak [[mandarin Chinese]] with a Cantonese accent.
==Shanzhai products== The use of "shanzhai" became popular with the outstanding sale performance of "shanzhai" mobile phones. According to [[Gartner]]’s data, 1.15 billion mobile phones were sold worldwide in 2007, and according to data provided by the Chinese government, 150 million "Shanzhai" mobile phones were sold in the same year, thus making up more than one tenth of the global sales.<ref name="Shanzhai’s Destruction">{{cite web|url=http://tech.163.com/09/0420/10/57BBE6EL0009388P.html |title=Shanzhai’s Destruction |publisher=Tech.163.com |date= |accessdate=2010-03-29}}</ref> In 2010, the Financial Times estimated that Shanzhai phones accounted for about 20 per cent of the global [[2G]] mobile phone market.<ref name=mediatek>{{Cite web |url=http://uk.finance.yahoo.com/news/bandit-phone-king-has-the-last-laugh-ftimes-34bef9cc11fc.html |archiveurl= https://www.webcitation.org/5tcXbg9AL |archivedate=21 October 2010 |title=Bandit phone king has the last laugh |work=The Financial Times |date=17 October 2010 |accessdate=21 October 2010 }}</ref>
The market for "shanzhai" mobile phones is not only in China, but are also found in the surrounding developing countries in Asia, Africa, and Latin America. The outstanding sales performance of "shanzhai" mobile phones is usually attributed to their low price, multifunctional performance and imitations of trendy mobile phone design. Although "shanzhai" companies do not use branding as a marketing strategy, they are known for their flexibility of design to meet specific market needs. For example, during [[Barack Obama]]’s 2008 U.S. presidential election campaign, "shanzhai" mobile phone companies started selling "Obama" mobile phones in [[Kenya]], with the slogan "yes we can" and Obama’s name on the back of the mobile phone.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://3zai.org.cn/shanzhai/shanzhaishouji/2009-01/136.html|title=Obama Brand Shanzhai Cell Phone|publisher=|accessdate=29 June 2016}}</ref> They also designed "[[Beijing National Stadium|Bird's Nest]]" ({{Lang-zh|c=鸟窝|s=|t=|labels=no}}) and "[[Fuwa]]" ({{Lang-zh|c=福娃|s=|t=|labels=no}}) mobile phones in light of the [[2008 Summer Olympics|Beijing Olympic Games]].
Before the booming shanzhai mobile phone industries, since the early 2000s, imitation electronic products such as DVD players and [[MP3 player|MP3]] players were already manufactured in the [[Pearl River Delta]] ({{Lang-zh|c=珠三角|s=|t=|labels=no}}) area.<ref name="Shanzhai’s Destruction"/> Many shanzhai mobile phone companies accumulated their capital in that process. After understanding that many buyers prefer lookalike phones without the blaring of fake logos, many manufacturers adopted a practice of not using fraudulent logos. They instead opt for a generically designed logo. This allows overseas buyers to find a lookalike phone easily, without the fake logo.
Shanzhai mobile phones can be sold at very low prices compared to other mobile phones. On average, the imitations sell at retailers at about $US100-$US150, while production costs are about $US20.<ref name=a>{{Cite news|last=Barboza|first=David|title=In China, Knockoff Cellphones Are a Hit|newspaper=The New York Times|date=2009-04-27|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/28/technology/28cell.html?hpw|postscript=<!--None-->}}</ref>
Shanzhai mobile phone factories are able to manufacture at a very low cost for two reasons, they do not buy mobile phone manufacture licenses from the Chinese government, thus saving all the related costs.
CECT is one of the many brands of [[cellular phone]]s manufactured in [[China]]. CECT offers unauthorized [[clone (computing)|clones]] or [[replicas]] of the [[Apple Inc.]] [[iPhone]] and various [[Nokia]] cell phones manufactured in [[China]] and sold at a fraction of the price of the original.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/technologyNewsMolt/idUKPEK33380420080623|title=Hi-phone anyone? Fake mobiles threaten China brands|publisher=Reuters UK|accessdate=22 July 2008| date=23 June 2008}}</ref> At least one reseller has been subject to legal demands from [[Apple Inc.]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.macnn.com/articles/08/05/12/iphone.knockoff.threatened/|title=Apple threatens European iPhone knockoff reseller|publisher=MacNN|accessdate=22 July 2008}}</ref>
One company that earned notoriety for producing shanzhai smartphones is [[Goophone]], which in 2012 was reported to have filed a patent for the "Goophone i5", a [[MediaTek]]-powered clone marketed prior to the real [[iPhone 5]]'s official release.<ref name="Hodgkins">{{cite web|url=http://www.macrumors.com/2014/07/16/wico-goophone-iphone-6-clones/|title=Wico and Goophone Beat Apple to Market with Android-Based iPhone 6 Clones|last=Hodgkins|first=Kelly|date=16 July 2014|work=[[MacRumors]]|accessdate=9 March 2015}}</ref>
Although there are many fake garments, watches, bags, and shoes in China, they are not called "shanzhai" products, perhaps because these fake products came into existence earlier than fake mobile phones and the newer use of the term "shanzhai". "Shanzhai" mobile phones may stand out as the most successful and most often discussed "shanzhai" products, because mobile phones strongly symbolise wealth in China, but they are much more affordable than other symbolic signs of wealth such as cars and apartments.
Quite a few shanzhai mobile phone companies tried to exploit the market by making shanzhai [[Netbooks]], but these gained little market acceptance and sales.
"Shanzhai" electric cars, which run on lead-acid batteries and sell for as little as $US2000-$US3000, are being produced in the Shandong province.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sites.asiasociety.org/chinagreen/shanzhai-electric-car-revolution/ |title=Shanzhai Electric Car Revolution 山寨电动汽车革命|publisher=China Green|date= |accessdate=2010-05-20}}</ref>
In January 2011 the Chinese Ministry of Industry and Information Technology and the State Administration of Industry and Commerce announced a crackdown on shanzhai phone sellers and manufacturers. The administration blamed "money-stealing" services that used the cheap phones to steal services using customers' SIM cards. Industry commentator Liu Sheng said that it was more likely to be linked to the country's intellectual property rights protection campaigns.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.shanghaidaily.com/sp/article/2011/201101/20110114/article_461498.htm |archiveurl=https://archive.is/DFbMU |archivedate=2 Feb 2013 |title=Number's up for fake cell phones |work=Shanghai Daily |author=Xu Chi |date=14 January 2011 |accessdate=19 January 2011 }}</ref>
==Shanzhaiism== Shanzhaiism ({{Lang-zh|c=山寨主義|s=|t=|labels=no}}) is a philosophical term denoting a Chinese style of innovation with a peasant mind-set.
Shanzhaiism has an equivalent English term: tinker. Lacking a garage, they build products in villages in the mountains that have stockade houses. However, with shanzhaiism in mind, people can produce fake and counterfeit products in a massively organized way.
Shanzhaiism can be analyzed using a term coined by Jean-Paul Sartre: [[Bad faith (existentialism)|Bad faith]]. Fake and unlicensed products are produced. For example, there was once a so-called Fake-One Road<ref>{{cite web|url=https://groups.google.com/forum/?_escaped_fragment_=topic/ada2aje/6RDAUWHUWeg#!topic/ada2aje/6RDAUWHUWeg|title=Whole street of Fake Famous brand name shops to be opened in China - Wenan Jie|publisher=|accessdate=29 June 2016}}</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20120223062019/http://tw.myblog.yahoo.com/jw!m3yjq.KQGRu5wWDGLuhCpQ--/article?mid=989&prev=990&next=976 Nanjing Shanzhai Street (南京山寨一條街,真是大開眼界..山寨手機/山寨家電/山寨電腦..等等.還有其他的山寨版品牌,以後可以在大陸一次買足 - 雅登廚飾/廚具設計/系統櫥櫃/美國/荷蘭廚房家電--雲林/嘉義生活館) - tw.myblog.yahoo.com]</ref> ({{Lang-zh|c=山寨一條街|s=|t=|labels=no}}) in China.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2408997/Wanda-Plaza-China-lined-counterfeit-brands-called-knock-alley.html|title=Fancy a cheap Starbocks or some Häagen Dezs ice cream? Then head down 'knock-off alley' where the shop fronts look more than a little familiar|publisher=|accessdate=29 June 2016}}</ref><ref>{{citation |url=http://hyperallergic.com/75107/how-pop-art-got-ripped-off/ |title=How Pop Art Got “Ripped Off” |author=Alicia Eler |authorlink=Alicia Eler |date=July 9, 2013}}</ref>
This kind of phenomena is not confined to fake products. The mind set of shanzhaiism even extends to advertisements. For example, a [https://web.archive.org/web/20121220153346/http://www.clonedinchina.com/2009/06/spokeman-obama-and-a-blackberry-storm-9500-clone.html shanzhai phone advertisement] used the former president of the United States, Obama, to promote its shanzhai products.
==Shanzhai culture==
The frequent reference to shanzhai cell phones on internet and in traditional media made people start labeling low-cost imitation cultural activities as shanzhai as well. Some of the most well-known events include the [[Shanzhai National Spring Gala]] ({{Lang-zh|c=山寨春节联欢晚会|s=|t=|labels=no}}), Shanzhai Lecture Room ({{Lang-zh|c=山寨百家讲坛|s=|t=|labels=no}}), Shanzhai Olympic Torch Relay ({{Lang-zh|c=山寨奥运火炬传递|s=|t=|labels=no}}), and Shanzhai Nobel Prize ({{Lang-zh|c=山寨诺贝尔奖|s=|t=|labels=no}}). One thing these events have in common is that they all imitate high-end, popular yet authoritative events in which grass-roots power usually has no participating role.
While the purpose of the above-mentioned shanzhai events is arguably just for the participants to have fun and to experience being the authority, other shanzhai cultural phenomena, like the shanzhai products, are profit-oriented. For example, some low-end performing agencies will hire [[Doppelgänger|people who look like pop stars]] to perform in rural areas, where people cannot afford to watch the actual stars. Thus shanzhai [[Jay Chou]] ({{Lang-zh|c=山寨周杰伦|s=|t=|labels=no}}), shanzhai [[Andy Lau]] ({{Lang-zh|c=山寨刘德华|s=|t=|labels=no}}) and shanzhai [[Faye Wong]] ({{Lang-zh|c=山寨王菲|s=|t=|labels=no}}) appear in many underdeveloped places in China.
Shanzhai movies are another profit-driven shanzhai phenomenon. These movies usually have low budgets, yet achieve commercial success by [[parody]]ing, making fun of or borrowing elements from high-end [[Hollywood]] blockbuster movies. One of the first shanzhai movies is [[Ning Hao]]’s ({{Lang-zh|c=宁浩|s=|t=|labels=no}}) ''[[Crazy Stone (film)|Crazy Stone]]'' ({{Lang-zh|c=疯狂的石头|s=|t=|labels=no}}). It imitates the multi-angle shooting, rapid cutting and stunts that are usually used in Hollywood action movies, yet it retains the grass-roots Chinese set up. With a 3 million Hong Kong dollar budget, ''Crazy Stone'' achieved 22 million-box-office revenue. Following its success, shanzhai movies like "the Big Movie" series ("{{Lang-zh|c=大电影"系列|s=|t=|labels=no}}") and ''No.2 in the World'' ({{Lang-zh|c=天下第二|s=|t=|labels=no}}) were made. Some also argue that Hollywood parody movies like ''[[Scary Movie]]'' are the true inspirational force behind shanzhai movies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.shanzhaihuo.com/chinanews/shanzhai-movie-yuanzihaolaiwu-fengkuangdeshitoushibizu.html |title="Shanzhai" Movie is From Hollywood; the "Crazy Stone" is Their Ancestor |publisher=Shanzhaihuo.com |date= |accessdate=2010-03-29}}</ref>
==Critical reception== The heated online debate about whether shanzhai should be encouraged or denounced is arguably due to Ni Ping ({{lang|zh|倪萍}}), a well-known [[China Central Television|CCTV]] host's proposal during the [[Lianghui]] (two conferences) this year.{{which|date=December 2012}} She proposed to establish relevant legislation that will eliminate the shanzhai phenomenon by arguing that the copycat culture associated with shanzhai will stifle genuine creativity and hamper awareness of property rights. While some agree with her, others point out that in order to give objective comment on the shanzhai phenomenon, one has to distinguish shanzhai products from "pirated" products and shanzhai culture from shanzhai products. They also argue that although many shanzhai culture events manifest themselves as copycat events, some also have true original elements. Western media outlets like ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]''<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB123257138952903561|title=Imitation Is the Sincerest Form of Rebellion in China|publisher=The Wall Street Journal|author=Sky Canaves and Juliet Ye|date=2009-01-22|accessdate=2009-07-10}}</ref> and ''[[The New Yorker]]''<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.newyorker.com/online/blogs/evanosnos/2009/03/a-chinese-pirat.html|title=A Chinese Pirate Unmasks|publisher=[[The New Yorker]]|author=Evan Osnos|authorlink=Evan Osnos|date=2009-03-05|accessdate=2009-07-10}}</ref> have reported about the shanzhai phenomenon and presented it as a form of rebellion and resistance to the mainstream culture.
==See also== * [[CCSTV New Year's Gala|China Shanzhai Television New Year's Gala]] * [[ChiPod]] * [[Shenzhen]] * [[Dazhai]] * [[Intellectual property in China]]
==References== {{refbegin}} *[[Byung-Chul Han]]: Shanzhai: Dekonstruktion auf Chinesisch. Merve-Verlag, 2011. {{ISBN|978-3-883962948}}{{refend}} {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.youmaker.com/video/sv?id=67b9cb50771e41009dfe4fa506c83a61001 In Chinese:大中華的"山寨"情結來自何方？] * "[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2008-12/30/content_10582935.htm Copycat "Shanzhai" Culture Takes on Life of Its Own]", Xinhua News Agency * "[http://en.ce.cn/Industries/Telecoms/200807/19/t20080719_16212016.shtml Mountain village handsets storm market]", China Economic Net * "[http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/cndy/2008-10/31/content_7160951.htm Cheap chips off the old block]", ''China Daily'' * "[http://english.cri.cn/3100/2008/12/11/902s431679.htm 'Shanzhai': Faking It for Money or Fun?]", China Radio International *[http://scholarship.law.campbell.edu/clr/vol34/iss3/3/ William Hennessey, Deconstructing Shanzhai - China's Copycat Counterculture: Catch Me If You Can, 34 Campbell L. Rev. 609 (2012).] *[https://www.academia.edu/5806015/Cultures_of_Remaking Cultures of Remaking, Scott Lukas - Academia.edu] *"[https://www.wired.com/magazine/2010/01/ff_newrevolution/all/1 In the Next Industrial Revolution, Atoms Are the New Bits]" By [[Chris Anderson (writer)|Chris Anderson]]. January 25, 2010, [[Wired Magazine]] Feb 2010 * "[http://tech.163.com/digi/08/1230/16/4UE5J7BN0016191G.html In Chinese:163.com:《中国数万网民自发将山寨编入维基百科》专题策划] *[http://hk.apple.nextmedia.com/template/apple/art_main.php?iss_id=20100913&sec_id=4104&subsec_id=15337&art_id=14444314&coln_id=14372091 鄭明麗 : 喬布斯為何不想去中國？(13 Sept 2010)] *[https://www.engadget.com/2010/10/13/shanzhai-steve-jobs-makes-a-special-appearance-in-hong-kong-vid Shanzai Steve Jobs], [[Engadget]] October 13, 2010 *[https://blogs.wsj.com/chinarealtime/2013/05/31/giant-yellow-ducks-creator-not-flattered-by-chinese-imitators/ Giant Yellow Duck’s Creator Not Flattered by Chinese Imitators - China Real Time Report] May 31, 2013 Dow Jones & Company

{{Infobox World's Fair | box_width = | class = | category = 10 | image = Nicolás Avellaneda 2.jpg | image_width = | caption = Nicolás Avellaneda honorary chair of the committee | year = 1882 | name = South American Continental Exhibition | native_name = Exposición Continental Sud-Americana | motto = | building = | area = | invent = | visitors = 50 000 | organized = Industrial Club of Buenos Aires<ref name="1882exhibition" /> | cnt = | org = | biz = | country = Argentina | city = Buenos Aires | venue = [[Plaza Once]] | coord = {{coord|34|36|35|S|58|24|26.8|W|display=inline}} | cand = | award = | open = 14 March 1882 | close = 31 July 1882 | prevexpo = [[Melbourne International Exhibition (1880)]] | prevcity = Melbourne | nextexpo = [[1888 Barcelona Universal Exposition]] | nextcity = Barcelona | suppl = | prevsuppl = | prevsupcity = | nextsuppl = | nextsupcity = | prevunho = | prevunhocity = | nextunho = | nextunhocity = | simuni = | simspe = | simhor = | simoth = Exposition internationale des vins, Bordeaux, France | website = }}
The '''South American Continental Exhibition''' (Exposición Continental Sud-Americana) was held in [[Buenos Aires]] from 14 March<ref name="relics">{{cite web|url=http://www.bbk.ac.uk/ibamuseum/texts/Andermann03.htm|access-date=19 November 2017|title=Relics and Selves: Iconographies of the National in Argentina, Brazil and Chile, 1880-1890}}</ref> to 31 July 1882.<ref name="1882exhibition">{{cite web|url=http://www.elarcondelahistoria.com/la-exposicion-continental-sudamericana-1531882/|access-date=18 November 2017|language=Spanish|title=LA EXPOSICIÓN CONTINENTAL SUDAMERICANA (15-3-1882) El arcón de la historia Argentina}}</ref>
==Organisation==
The fair was organised by the Industrial Club of Buenos Aires who had organised an industrial exhibition in Buenos Aires in 1877.<ref name="1882exhibition" /> [[Julio Argentino Roca|Julio A Roca]] (president) inaugurated the exhibition with the honorary chair of the committee [[Nicolás Avellaneda]]<ref name="relics" /> stating that the exhibition represented industrial progress.<ref name="1882exhibition" />
[[National Congress of Argentina|Congress]] gave funds for the exhibition<ref name="1882exhibition" /> which were used for premises in [[Plaza Once]].
==Exhibits and prizes== Exhibits covered: arts; beer, cigarettes and wine; clothing and footwear; and soap from Argentina and other countries in America and Europe.<ref name="1882exhibition" />
Prize winners included the Brazilian photographers [[Marc Ferrez (photographer)|Marc Ferrez]], {{illm|Insley Pacheco|pt|Joaquim José Insley Pacheco}}.<ref name="1882BAprize">{{cite web|url=http://enciclopedia.itaucultural.org.br/evento528684/exposicao-continental-de-buenos-aires-1882-buenos-aires-argentina|access-date=19 November 2017|language=Spanish|title=Exposição Continental de Buenos Aires (1882 : Buenos Aires, Argentina) | Enciclopédia Itaú Cultural}}</ref> and the Brazilian 'Esberard Glass and Crystal' company.<ref name="glass">{{cite web|url=https://www.carnivalglassworldwide.com/esberard.html|access-date=20 November 2017|title=Esberard, Brazil - Carnival Glass - Carnival Glass Worldwide}}</ref>
==Historical show== A historical show was announced on the 15 March 1882. This was to cover the history of the [[Río de la Plata|River Plate]] with sections including "Argentinian prehistorical", "Columbian era", numismatics, paintings, prints, manuscripts, maps (including nautical maps) and furniture.<ref name="1882exhibition" />
The tone of the exhibition was debated with [[Estanislao Zeballos]] of the exhibition organising committee arguing that war trophies that could embarrass potentially participating nations (Brazil and Paraguay) be excluded.<ref name="1882exhibition" />
==Closure==
By the time it closed at the end of July 50 000 people had visited.<ref name="1882exhibition" />
==References==
{{Reflist}}
==External links== [http://curlew.cch.kcl.ac.uk/cgi-bin/rands/q_img.pl?@iBA18-30 Aerial view of the exhibition]
